PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium: Mining and Export
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Durack (from 31 citizens), Senator Powell (from 31 citizens) and Senator Zakharov (93 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Austudy: Family Allowance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators in Parliament. The Petition of the undersigned shows:

That the Government is planning to introduce an assets test on Family Allowance at a level of $500,000. It will maintain the current assets tests on Family Allowance Supplement (FAS), Austudy and Isolated Children's Allowance which are discriminating against farming families particularly during the present rural crisis.

Your petitioners ask that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Australian Government to exempt the family farm of registered primary producers who are living and working on their own farm from inclusion in the assets tests for Austudy, Family Allowance and Family Allowance Supplement.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Austudy: Family Allowance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain electors of Queensland points out to the Senate that the 1990/91 Federal Budget stipulates that from January next year Family Allowance payments will be subject to an assets test. Family Allowance will be withdrawn if net assets excluding the family home and debt exceed $300,000. Furthermore the parental assets test threshold for Family Allowance Supplement, Austudy and Assistance for Isolated Children has been severely slashed in the 1990/91 Federal Budget.

Considering the economic crisis facing rural communities in Australia, assets tests of such a nature are not viable because the assets are incapable of generating enough income to sustain families and send children away for schooling.
Your petitioners therefore ask the Senate to exempt the family farm from the assets test for Austudy, Family Allowance and Family Allowance Supplement.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia: Christian Commonwealth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we, the undersigned, call for the full and total recognition, by Federal Parliament and the High Court and all government agencies that Australia is a Christian Commonwealth according to law and its heritage traditions and customs.

That as Australia prepares for the Centenary of Federation on 1st January, 2001 AD we celebrate our Centenary as a Christian Commonwealth as described by the Founders of Federation such as Sir John Downer, who said ` `The Commonwealth will be from its first stage a Christian Commonwealth and as stated in our Federal Constitution-``Relying on the Blessings of Almighty God . . . ''
That our Federal Parliament therefore implement the following policies before 1st January, 2001 AD.
1. The Adoption of a Christian National Anthem-``God Bless Australia'' to the tune of ``Waltzing Matilda''.
2. The adoption of a Christian National Motto-``One Nation Under God'', for use on our coins, banknotes, etc.
3 The appointment of practising Christians as Vice Regal Representatives of our Christian Queen, Elizabeth II.
4. The retention of our Christian Prayers at the daily opening of Parliament in the standing respectful presence of all Members of Parliament.
5. The retention of ``God Save the Queen'' for Vice Regal Functions as our Royal Anthem and as our National Hymn for all other civic functions.
6. The retention of Christian Christmas Carols in our State Schools and other civic functions during the Christmas Season.
7. Officially inform the United Nations and all the other nations of the world that Australia is a Christian Commonwealth.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will reaffirm our Christian Heritage as a Christian Commonwealth.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Home Ownership
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor Government's deliberate policy of huge rises in mortgage interest rates has pushed the cost of buying their own home beyond the reach of most Australian families and has forced many out of their homes.

Now therefore, your petitioners request that the Senate in Parliament assembled require the Hawke-Keating government to cease its excessive reliance on high interest rates so that the traditional right of home ownership is returned to average Australian families.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Air Landing Fee: New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament:

This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the proposed air landing fee for regional and commuter airlines landing at Sydney Mascot Airport during peak times discriminates severely against people in rural Australia and will force many airlines to either revise their schedules, cancel flights or increase passenger fares to cover this additional financial impost of the Federal Labor Government. This will result in less accessibility for country businessmen and travellers alike, will increase the costs of business for rural people and threatens the viability of many smaller airlines who provide valuable services to rural towns. We therefore call on the Federal Government to abolish all plans for the introduction of this discriminatory fee and allow commuter airlines to continue to provide their full range of services to towns throughout New South Wales.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Ownership
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned notes that the level of foreign ownership and control of Australian assets is of concern to many Australians.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should introduce legislation to:
(a) establish a register of foreign ownership.
(b) limit foreign ownership of real estate.''
(c) control foreign investment in Australia so as to protect the national interest.
(d) increase the powers and resources of the Foreign Investment Review Board.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Health Act
PETITION.PARA: THE DRAFT CHARTER OF RESIDENTS' RIGHTS AND RESPONSIBILITIES AND THE DRAFT AGREEMENT to be entered into between the Proprietors of Nursing Homes and their Residents which have been tabled in the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia by the Honourable Peter Staples, Minister for Housing and Aged Care on 18 September 1990.
To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The Humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the above draft Charter and Agreement are designed to require Proprietors of Nursing Homes to act in a manner contrary to proper moral standards and to incur obligations that are likely to lead to unnecessary expense and litigation.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament amend the said Draft Charter and Agreement in such ways as are necessary:
1. To preserve the Proprietor's rights to ensure that providers of Health Care Services to Residents comply with the Philosophy of the Proprietor in relation to such services.

2. To ensure that the Agreement can be offered to Residents of Nursing Homes without offending the conscience of Proprietors and Staff who have moral objections to the grant to any person of a right to indulge in extramarital sexual intercourse in their Nursing Homes.
3. To eliminate vague and uncertain language.

4. To remove from the Draft Agreement the provisions which impose on Proprietors and Staff onerous responsibilities that will increase demands on the human and material resources of the Nursing Homes without securing any essential benefit to the Residents.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecommunications: Future Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned shows that there is widespread community concern over the introduction of competition into Australia's telecommunications industry, and that ordinary consumers may be faced with higher prices and reduced services as a result. In particular, we are concerned about the impact on the affordability of telephone services for low income earners and rural consumers.
The petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should introduce legislation to:
(a) protect ordinary consumers from increasing prices and decreasing service and to ensure that the telephone remains an affordable utility
(b) clearly define community service obligations of all telecommunications providers

(c) ensure that, regardless of the structural arrangements, a strong and viable government telecommunications carrier is maintained and continues to provide a universal, affordable service to all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the twenty-seventh report of the Committee of Privileges, concerning a person referred to in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the report be adopted.

This is the eighth report of the Committee concerning a matter raised by a person under Privilege Resolution 5 of 25 February 1988. On 26 November 1990, the President, Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa, referred a letter from Sir William Keys relating to remarks made by Senator Newman and Senator Herron during discussion on a matter of public importance on 15 November 1990 to the Committee of Privileges as a submission under Privilege Resolution 5. The Committee has considered the submission and recommends that a response agreed to by Sir William and the Committee be incorporated in Hansard and I seek leave so to do.
Leave granted.
The response read as follows-
RESPONSE BY SIR WILLIAM KEYS, A.C., O.B.E., M.C. AGREED TO BY SIR WILLIAM KEYS AND THE COMMITTEE OF PRIVILEGES PURSUANT TO RESOLUTION 5(7) (b) OF THE SENATE OF 25 FEBRUARY 1988

In the Senate on Thursday, 15 November, I was the target of most insulting remarks from Senators Newman and Herron. I write to ask that my response to these attacks and to the issues from which they arose might be presented to the Senate.

Senator Newman referred to me as a Government ``stooge'' because of my support for hospital integration. Let me begin by saying that for 27 years, 17 as National Secretary and 10 as National President of the RSL, I was the principal negotiator for the war veterans and dependants of Australia. In this role I developed sound working relations with Prime Ministers from Robert Menzies to Robert Hawke. I believe I also had the respect and confidence of my own constituency and the Ministers and Governments of the day, regardless of their political persuasion.
The results achieved for veterans and dependants over that period are a matter of record and speak for themselves.

I briefly retrace this history of my efforts for veterans and dependants to make the point that Senator Newman's interjection was not only deeply offensive, it was untrue. I am nobody's ``stooge'' and never have been. The views I express are at all times my own.

It is not the personal attack on me which concerns me: rather, it is the attack on the concept of integration. As National President of the RSL I negotiated the integration arrangements with Prime Minister Hawke and Veterans' Affairs Minister Humphreys. The views expressed in my letter, quoted by Senator Tate, represented views adopted by organisations such as the Korea and South East Asia Forces Association and the TPI Association.
Subsequently, in supporting Senator Newman's attack, Senator Herron was incorrect in his statement to the Senate in relation to a National Conference of the AMA on 26 May at which I spoke.
He said I had returned from overseas that morning. In fact, I had returned 5 days before.

He said I had delivered a speech that I had not actually read. In fact, the speech I read was the third draft of an address on which I had worked with the National Office of Overseas Skills Recognition (NOOSR) in which I provided the general thrust and the professional people provided the supporting data-a fairly normal procedure for such a speech.

He is correct in saying that I did anger my audience. I told them if they did not adopt a more flexible attitude to the assessment of the professional skills of overseas-trained doctors, they were in danger of becoming irrelevant.

The merits of the points I made were subsequently endorsed by the Australian Medical Council which, as a result of its own review, greatly changed its assessment procedure to make it a far more practical process and thus give overseas-trained doctors a far greater prospect of obtaining recognition and registration.
I make this submission in an endeavour to clear my name and reputation. I trust that appropriate action can be taken.
SIR WILLIAM KEYS
I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 28 November, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That the report of Estimates Committee F be adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is considering Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1990-91 and examining the proposed expenditure for the Department of Industrial Relations. The question before the Chair is that the report of Estimates Committee F be adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) will remember that on 12 November I asked him a question relating to his comment that he would possibly refer executive salaries to the Prices Surveillance Authority. I pointed out that he had mentioned that the level of executive salary increases was in the range of 16.5 per cent. I then asked him whether such an inquiry would include in its terms of reference those senior staff in his and other ministerial offices who have received salary increases of up to 35 per cent, plus additional fringe benefits. The Minister said a lot of things in reply, but the gist of it was that he would not be including those extremely large increases for his own and other ministerial staff, as well as staff of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), in that Prices Surveillance Authority inquiry. I then asked the Minister this supplementary question:

SPEECH.PARA: Who makes the assessment, or is this just a case of the spoils of office that the Minister has referred to on so many occasions in this place?
After making a couple of odd comments, the Minister assured me:
The assessment is made by the appropriate officers of the Department of Industrial Relations-
I stress these are the Minister's words-
with no reference to any Minister whatsoever.
At the end of Question Time on 12 November the Minister came back and said that he would like to supplement his answer. He said:
. . . I said in my answer that Senator Bolkus was the responsible Minister and then I said, `as I understand it'-
which is not true; if people look at Hansard they will see he did not say that-

and I went on to complete the answer. Senator Bolkus has now advised me that the assessment of ministerial salaries is made, of course, as I said in my answer, by the Department of Industrial Relations-in fact, it is made by the Secretary of that Department who then advises Senator Bolkus as to the outcome. Senator Bolkus has the power to accept, reject or amend it.

He was restating part of his answer and correcting that part where he said `with no reference to any Minister whatsoever'. He was making that correction. However, yesterday, when I asked Senator Bolkus whether the individual Ministers had the opportunity of making assessments of their own staff, Senator Bolkus said that they do. That is completely contrary to the answer I received from Senator Cook. When I asked Senator Bolkus why the Minister had answered me in the fashion he had-incorrectly saying the individual Ministers had no input at all-he said he could not answer for Senator Cook; obviously Senator Cook did not have the information. I ask the Minister, because he is the Minister for Industrial Relations, whether he would now like to correct his answer to me, because it was obviously wrong, and why he did not have the correct information of his own Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the Minister, I would like to remind honourable senators that we are examining matters which the report considered should be further examined in the Committee of the Whole and on which reservations recommended that there should be further examination. I must admit that I cannot find the area under which Senator Walters is framing her question but I presume it is satisfactory so I will ask the Minister to answer in a moment. I would ask honourable senators if they could assist the Chair by indicating under what authority they are asking the question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the first thing I should say is that if Senator Walters is going to quote from Hansard she should quote all of what was said and not only those parts that suit the case she wishes to make.
—I quoted the relevant parts.

—I will concede that Senator Walters quoted some of the relevant parts, but not all of them. The key part of my answer that Senator Walters is holding up to me now is that when the question was first put to me I said that I was not the appropriate Minister to answer it but that since the question was directed to me I would do the best I could to provide the Senate with the relevant information. With that caveat, I think it is reasonable for me to be able to say that, though not talking on my portfolio, I would nonetheless endeavour to provide the best information I was apprised of.

SPEECH.PARA: The terms of the Prices Surveillance Authority's charter do not require it to be a vehicle in which salaries of ministerial staff and Opposition staff can be determined or scrutinised. There is not in the ministerial staff issue any price element that would be something that the Surveillance Authority would look at. The relevant authority for setting up the framework for the levels of ministerial staff and Opposition staff is the Remuneration Tribunal. The Remuneration Tribunal has done that by setting ranges.

The placement of particular staff within those ranges is the next exercise. That is done by the Secretary of my Department, uninformed, unencumbered and unenlightened by me-that is to say, independent of government. He makes an assessment as a person within the government structure who is knowledgeable about industrial relations and about appropriate relativities and weightings of relativities for people of this type. That recommendation goes to Senator Bolkus, who has the ministerial responsibility for adopting, rejecting or amending it. He exercises that responsibility as the case may be, according to his own determination.

Senator Walters has come back to an answer that she tells me Senator Bolkus gave to a question yesterday. I have no knowledge of that interchange so I take her word that she has relayed the terms of that interchange accurately. On that assumption, I will answer what she has put. To the best of my knowledge, the only time I was aware of what levels were to be bid for by my staff was when they indicated to me where they were applying to be placed in the range. Since it is not a matter for my determination, I simply became aware of it because of my proximity to, understanding of and relationship with my staff.

TALK.START.PARA: —You washed your hands of it, did you?

—It is not my right to determine anything. It was certainly a matter of interest to me-as it would be a matter of interest to Senator Kemp to find out how his staff were to be regarded by the independent authority assessing their capability and competence. That was a matter of interest to me, certainly, and my staff had a keen interest in it. But I had no role-and nor does any Minister other than Senator Bolkus, who has the designated authority-in influencing the outcome of any determination.
—That is not right. You have a role in influencing it. According to Senator Bolkus, you have the ability to put forward your personal assessment. I presume that creates some influence.

—I am not aware of exactly what Senator Bolkus says, and I am taking Senator Walters's word for it, but I never sought-and nor does any other Minister-to influence the outcome. The outcome is a matter for determination by the Secretary on recommendation to Senator Bolkus. I cannot recall any other role being exercised by me. I was certainly aware of what my staff thought was an appropriate level, and it may be that I signed some document sending that recommendation off. But I did not make any submission, argue any case or try to persuade any authority. It was simply a clerical transaction if it occurred. As I say, I cannot remember whether or not it did.
—What rises were finally granted to your staff? What percentage increase?
—I could not tell Senator Kemp. I cannot tell what rises were granted to my staff, but I am sure they can.
—You do know, Minister.
—I do not.

—I think the Minister is playing with words. I mean to make it very clear. I am not suggesting that, if he signs a bit of paper saying what he believes his staff think appropriate and sends it off, that is making a determination. I am suggesting that the Minister is incorrect when he still claims that no Minister has any ability to influence the outcome. If a Minister's signature is on the bottom of a piece of paper saying he believes his staff should be upgraded to such and such a level, and therefore have his staff increase their salaries by up to 35 per cent, then I still believe the Minister has some influence; otherwise he would not be bothering to sign it. It is as simple as that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I repeat that I am talking out of my portfolio. What I am neither sure nor clear on, and I state for the record that I do not have a recollection of, is exactly the process by which the views of the staff come before the secretary. If there is a clerical process in which I am involved, well there is, but I am not aware of that. I will find out those facts. They are matters of discoverable fact and I will make them available to the chamber for that purpose.

SPEECH.PARA: It may therefore be that Senator Walters will make a judgment for herself that this is influence. That is her judgment and she makes it. What I am saying-and I want this clear and understood on the record-is that there is no role of advocacy by me or any other Minister to the secretary of the department who makes the determination. We do not seek to persuade, cajole, convince or in any other way advocate change. He makes the determination.

TALK.START.PARA: — When the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) finds that out, would he also find out what happens in all the other ministerial situations? If he has not signed the document, according to Senator Bolkus, other Ministers did put forward suggestions. If the Minister does not think that that has any influence, then why bother doing it? Of course it has some influence, but we are obviously not getting anywhere. I thank the Minister for offering to bring back information in this regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not quite sure what the first part of that question was, but if Senator Walters is asking me to do something that is outside my ministerial competence, of course I will not do it. If it is within my ministerial competence, of course I will. If Senator Walters wishes to trade on the word `influence', that is her prerogative. There has to be a mechanism in which these things are dealt with. There must be a procedure to bring them forward and enable the determination to be made.

SPEECH.PARA: The role of Ministers may be-and as I say, I have no clear understanding of this; it is a matter of my going back and consulting the record-to pass that information on. But there is no role of advocacy or persuasion. The determination is made by the independent authority and recommended to the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus). That applies in the case of all Ministers, and there is really nothing much more to be said on the subject.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps, when bringing back the information that the Minister said he could, he will also check on the percentage increases which were granted to his staff and inform us accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is this obsession by the Opposition, when I raise the question of excessive remuneration for executives in Australia, not to join the Government in its clarion call for restraint by executives and for executives to show the same restraint that their employees have shown in wage fixation over the last years. I would have thought that the provable fact of a huge executive rip-off stood out so startlingly that the Opposition could find it within its soul, somehow or other, to support the Government's call for restraint.

SPEECH.PARA: Instead of a call for restraint we now have this exercise of morbid curiosity about what has happened in the determination of salaries for ministerial staff. I should say on that subject-that is, ministerial and Opposition staff-that unlike the executives, of whom I was complaining, their salaries have been through a proper process of determination. That determination is by, in the first instance, the Remuneration Tribunal headed by Judge Mahoney, a Supreme Court judge of the New South Wales jurisdiction. He has made a determination as to salary ranges for different classes of position. Within those classes of position, according to the experience, ability and competence of the individuals concerned and their performance, an assessment is made and they are placed within a broad range.

The process that we are talking about is where within that broad range they are placed. They are placed in a way in which there is an incentive to encourage them to better performance. That is a process of assessment and determination in each of their cases, unlike the example I was making about senior executive salaries in which there is self-assessment and self-determination without any independent objectivity being brought into the argument.

Having made that position quite clear and identifying the still dogged refusal of the Opposition to call upon senior executives in this country to restrain their remuneration packages, I do not think that there is any need to select out individuals who, by their performance, have been independently assessed as requiring an upgrading in their salary. I just think it would be a more sensible process; I might say that I am not going to lend myself to that either. All the information about what rates these people get is on the record and Senator Kemp can have access to it; I do not need to do his research for him. I would hope, since Senator Kemp is rising to the call, that when he does speak he would preface all his remarks by saying that he does join the Government in calling upon senior executives in this country, who have had massive salary increases, to do as their employees do and exercise restraint. That would mean at last some bipartisanship on a fairly obvious point of inequity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that particular advice. If he reads the Hansard from yesterday, he will see that I have made a particular point of condemning what I regard as excessively high salaries paid to executives-so we share joint ground there.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue is-just so the Minister can get it clear in his mind-that he, by his own behaviour, has provoked this issue. The Minister has gone around trumpeting the accord. He has gone around telling people in this community-the workers-that they have had to have cuts in living standards. He has moved vigorously against those who have broken outside those guidelines-the latest effort, we will recall, was by members of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. The issue that we want is to see whether the Minister lives by the same rules that he wants others to live by. That is the particular issue and that is why he has brought this matter on.

We are concerned that the Government is calling for restraint, and we do not argue about that issue. The country is in a deep crisis-and probably the figures today will show this-which I suggest the Minister's policies have brought on. What we are interested in is this: the Minister has gone around trumpeting restraint and telling workers that they have to restrain their behaviour, and Bill Kelty has joined him in that. Now we find from yesterday that with the figures Senator Bolkus gave this chamber, and which have not been denied, there is a considerable doubt that the rules that the Minister and his colleagues have applied to others have in fact applied to their own senior managers. That is the reason for what he calls obsessive interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that we are debating the issue. I am pleased that the Opposition has made it clear that it joins the Government in calling on senior executives to exercise restraint-that is a welcome change. I hope that the executives will now heed the joint authority of both the major parties-
—And the Democrats.
—And the Australian Democrats-of all the parties represented in this Parliament-in exercising the moral imperative of restraint. That is a significant step forward.

SPEECH.PARA: I come to the second point. The distinction I made before is that executives undergo self-assessment and appoint their own salaries. The people who Senator Kemp is talking about went through a period of independent assessment by competent authorities to examine what work they did, what ability they brought to the job, what experience they had and with what competence and performance they pursued it. On assessing each of those people individually, independent of themselves, the authorities placed them in a scale, moreover, that is based on the Public Service scale. That is, a work value assessment was carried out on each individual. There is a world of difference between self-assessment and self-appointed salaries, independent assessment and an objective, competent independent authority fixing a rate.

However, the honourable senator has then moved to blur that distinction and has gone on to talk about the level of increase. The level of increase related to a general wage movement for these officers is the same level of increase that everyone else has enjoyed. But the assessment of their work value which has not taken place--

TALK.START.PARA: —We are talking about the bottom line.

—If Senator Kemp is going to talk on wages policy, it is very important that he understand what the constituent parts of that policy are and how, when greater expertise and competence are called for and more demands are made on people, they are entitled to get higher pay because of that extra responsibility and demand. As long as that is assessed by an independent competent authority, there is nothing wrong with that. In fact, that is quite right, fair and just.

SPEECH.PARA: One cannot therefore say that because the type of work these people do has changed significantly over time and because the value of the work that they produce for the government or their employer has increased immeasurably, they are not entitled to receive an assessment and a regrading. One cannot say that-and that is what has happened in this case. So before anyone makes the point that we are not applying the same principles to ourselves that we ask others to apply, the answer is this: certainly we are. If we were not, we would be worthy of condemnation. But we are, and we are according to our own likes; we are according to the likes of the Remuneration Tribunal; and we are as well according to the likes of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU).

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, wow!

—If we were setting new precedents here on which other wage and salaries earners could build, there would be a wages break-out. They would be citing the precedents that we had established to justify wage claims in the broader community. So we were careful to ensure that the principles we were applying in this particular case were in fact looked at by the ACTU and, indeed, the Confederation of Australian Industry (CAI) as I recall. So the two major players that appear before national wage case benches and appear in the endless tug-of-war over what the right level of salaries or wages might be before arbitration commissions could pass their Geiger counter over the principles we were applying and get the test reading back to find that it was neutral. But in fact the principles we are applying to ourselves are the principles that are universally the principles of wage fixation for the general community.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable senator may still wish now to proceed down this course because he is offended by quantum, by the amount, but before he does, I warn him it is a treacherous course for him to proceed down because he has obviously proceeded down it to the extent that he has without a knowledge of wage fixing principles, and he will come to grief if he does not comprehend those principles in the examination of this subject.

Mr Chairman, I think we are now moving into debating the point, rather than examining and explaining the estimates. But I am afraid my outburst was brought on by the debate that was commenced on the other side.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just have to say to the Minister, in terms of what has happened here-and he can argue as to who did or did not start the debate-that I am terribly disappointed with his attitude and the emphasis he has placed on a number of things. First of all, there was his reference to Senator Kemp, that he should do his own research. That would indicate to me that the Minister has something to hide and, hopefully--
—Oh!

—Well, it would. It is a very simple point for you to answer, and I just think that is an irresponsible answer. Further to that, you talk about these particular issues and independent assessments, but you have consistently used this place to bash executive salaries-and I do not deny you that right. But at the same time today, you took the opportunity once again to bash the Opposition's position. It was recognised in this place some two weeks ago, I believe, that Dr Hewson had come out and made comments very similar to what had already been said.

SPEECH.PARA: If you had listened to what a number of us in this place have said, including me, you would know that we put emphasis not just on executive salary restraint but on restraint across the board at this particular time. I think it is absolutely pointless carrying on a debate such as this if there is not recognition on both sides of the chamber that there has been an emphasis put on restraint-and not just restraint in one particular arena but restraint across the board, because we have no option.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Walters, I would indicate that it is best to direct remarks through the Chair. When the word `you' is used it usually means the Chair, so I have been accused of quite a few things this morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to carry this on any further, except to say that as I understand it the Minister can suggest an increase for his staff, sign the document, send it down to the Department of Industrial Relations and pretend that that does not influence the issue in any way. It may be dealt with in the Minister's own Department on some occasions, I might add, but certainly a department that the Government runs.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister has told us that the executive increases of 16.5 per cent, using his own figures, and the extraordinarily large figures of up to 35 per cent for ministerial staff are totally different because one is an independent assessment. He told us just a little while ago that some of the staff suggested their salaries and, if he signed them, he sent them down to the Industrial Relations Department-and that is fair enough. But I would say the difference is, as the Minister has told us, that the Australian Council of Trade Unions has sanctioned one lot so the Government has said, `Fine, so long as our bosses tell us it's all right, we'll do that,' and the ACTU did not sanction the other lot.

That is the basic difference between the two. A very old union trick-and the Minister would be very well aware of it-is that if you cannot go for a total increase and stay in the area where you are, you upgrade your area. Yesterday we were asking Senator Bolkus to give us a description of the difference between the job done by the staff previously and the job they are doing presently. He said that he had never claimed there was any difference. Of course the Minister now says there is greater demand on them, there is greater this and greater that-but Senator Bolkus said yesterday that he had not claimed there had been any change in the demands of the jobs that those staff members were doing.

As I say, the Minister is well aware of all these facts and all we are saying is: be consistent; say to the community out there, `We've got to pull our belts in'; have a look at the figures that will come out today, and acknowledge that we have to do it with our own staff.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise some questions on union rationalisation. I am fully aware of the need today to be precise, so I am going to do my best. There have been certain objectives put forward as far as financing is concerned. I do just want to say that I totally disagree with the funding of this program. I think it is one area in which we should exercise restraint. I do not believe it is the role of government to be providing finance to unions or industry groups.
—But the farmers.
—It does not give money to the farmers for their organisations. I do not believe the honourable senator can give me one example of where it does. If he can, I would oppose it.
—In a wider industry context.

—I am not talking about research and development; I am talking about direct grants. Nonetheless, as I said, these are the facts. There are some questions that I would like to put to the Minister, and they relate to the credibility of the auditing process. Can the Minister outline to us what accountability processes are in place in terms of the expenditure of this money? Is it spent on the objectives it is assessed for or, to coin a phrase, is it an open cheque book-type of contribution?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no open cheque book-type of situation here. This is a situation of strict scrutiny and control and proper guardianship of public moneys. The purpose of the scheme of course is to encourage the amalgamation of unions along industry lines and to achieve, therefore, one union per industry, if possible-certainly at least one bargaining unit per industry and/or enterprise where possible-so that the demarcations that occur with the inherent craft union structure we have in this country can be removed and workers can be skilled across a range of skills without there being that craft focus of the past. The work force can therefore become more flexible, more productive, and that will benefit the wider economy.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, part of our micro-economic reform program is to encourage this amalgamation to break down the old craft unionism of this country and achieve a major industry focus for our union organisation. The cost of doing this is quite large. For example, two quite small unions wishing to amalgamate immediately face a legal bill of about $50,000 in order simply to draw up the scheme of amalgamation and have it approved. They face other legal costs for the purposes of getting the matter dealt with. These are costs in addition to the normal running and administration costs of a union. Since we are encouraging unions to achieve amalgamation, we see that a reasonable thing for us to do is to meet some-and I underline that word-of those costs; not all of them, because they are special costs.

The second element of this scheme is that there is often a high cost at the point of explaining to members who have perhaps been encoded into a craft view of things of the need for amalgamation so that they can make intelligent choices when they come to vote about amalgamation. The members can have better explained to them the wider opportunities of what that portends for them in their futures, careers and earning power. So that is another area into which some of these funds go.

The process of obtaining these funds is for the unions to make a submission setting out what they propose-there are strict guidelines involving accounting and control measures laid down by the Department and each of the submissions is judged against those guidelines-and if a union's submission meets those guidelines it is then a candidate for approval. The approvals are recommended to me, and I make a decision based on the recommendations of my Department. I believe at each stage of this process there is sufficient control to be certain that these funds are spent in the manner and for the purposes for which they are allocated, and there are review mechanisms to ensure that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who has responsibility for the accountability of that expenditure?
—The departmental officers look at each of these events, Minister-I am sorry, Senator.
—Thank you, you got one thing right.

—Maybe one day, when Senator Crane is 99, we will lose an election and he can become a Minister, and maybe I am prescient to that extent. The guidelines are administered by the Department, and the Department also follows through the overseeing of the allocation and management of these funds.

—If we could move to subprogram 1.4, the Affirmative Action Agency, I want to ask a couple of questions on the non-English speaking programs. There seems, at least to me, to be some confusion about these programs. Are these programs run in English, or is a mixture of appropriate languages used?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suspect that if I miss a beat and pause for a minute, I will receive some advice from my advisers about this. I must say that I cannot tell Senator Crane the answer to that question straight off the top of my head. I may require confirmation of this because the officers cannot find the particular reference to enable me to cite precisely the regulations, but it is my belief and understanding that these courses are conducted in English.

SPEECH.PARA: The purposes of those courses is to encourage people to learn English in the workplace and/or to become competent in English. Our worry is that non-English speakers, or people with poor competency in English, in a mechanised workplace may not understand always what the safety signs are, what the hazard signs mean, and what the operation signs mean for properly conducting and operating plant and equipment. Therefore they can be a danger to both themselves and to their workmates. These workers may be able to pass the screening of personnel officers and get into the workplace, but there is a real need to lift that understanding, as there is a wider social need to encourage more literacy in English by all residents of this country so that they can be aware of their rights, which are more often set out in English than any other language.
I also point out that on page F21 of Estimates Committee F Hansard of 13 September 1990, Senator Foreman asked this question:
What about seminars? Do you conduct them in any language other than English?
Ms Pratt, the Director of the Affirmative Action Agency, answered:

No, we do not, unfortunately. We do have quite a lot of discussions with employers, where there is a multicultural work force, about the strategies that may be developed. One of the main areas of concerns is things like induction programs which, unfortunately, many employers still maintain in English. We make certain recommendations but, unfortunately, we do not have the resources to present our material in any other language.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make a couple of brief comments because, while I do not disagree with the Minister on the importance of the program assisting non-English speaking women to learn English, I believe that some of the benefits of this program, as has been pointed out to me, are lost due to the lack of ability of the people in the courses to understand what is going on. There is a need to broaden that understanding, and obviously teaching English is part of it. I have a number of additional questions which I suspect may not be able to answered now. Maybe if I just read them out we can get the answers later. If the Minister wants to answer now, that is fine. When was the first non-English speaking program conducted? How many courses have been conducted to date? In what months were the courses advertised and conducted? What allocation of funding has been granted to the non-English section of the Agency?
(10.48) I will accept the generous offer of Senator Crane to table those questions on notice and reply to him as soon as possible.

—I move now to program 2- Australian Government Employment: Remuneration Structures and Conditions. I was interested in the debate that took place when this matter was first raised, but the debate really relates to the pay structures and methods of deciding the payments of chief executive officers. As I understand it, the method of assessing those salaries was taken out of the Remuneration Tribunal's hands last year and in fact has now been put within the control of the board of the statutory authority, or whatever it might be. I want to find out what the movement was, one year after the decision was made, in the salaries of the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia; the Managing Director of Telecom Australia; the Managing Director of the Commonwealth Bank Group; the Managing Director of Australia Post; the Chief Executive Officer of the Australian Industry Development Corporation; and the Managing Director of OTC Ltd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This question is similar to one asked by Senator Chapman, I think at the Estimates Committee hearing. I am responsible in these proceedings to talk on behalf of the Remuneration Tribunal which, as I recall, has an advisory role in this but not a decisive one. The Tribunal reports to Government on the general outcome of its proceedings-not about the particular salary position-to indicate in which way salaries are moving for senior executive positions in statutory authorities.

SPEECH.PARA: I am unable to give Senator Crane the salaries of all of those positions that he has just read out because it is not something over which I have authority or influence. However, I am advised that the annual reports of those statutory authorities, such as the Commonwealth Bank and the Reserve Bank and the other authorities that the honourable senator read out, contain the reports stating what senior executive remuneration is for those statutory authorities. That is the proper place to find that information. I am not in a position to advise Senator Crane of rates of remuneration because I have no formal advice from my Department or from the Remuneration Tribunal as to what those rates are.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his answer. No doubt we will be looking at the annual reports to get a handle on what the salaries are. I think it is very important, in terms of the previous debate about restraint, that we have some mechanism or idea. Perhaps the Minister could confirm whether the salary of the Governor of the Reserve Bank virtually doubled as a result of the changes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a matter which would be disclosed in the Reserve Bank of Australia report. I am not in a position to confirm or deny that, as I have no formal advice from my Department or from any other authority which I am responsible for. I can simply say that the place to find that information is in the annual report of the Reserve Bank.

SPEECH.PARA: Apropos the discussion we had earlier, the Government insisted that statutory authorities such as the Reserve Bank, the Commonwealth Bank, in particular, Telecom and Australian Airlines take on a more commercial hue and compete free of the restraint that would normally be applied to government business enterprises. We insisted that they orientate their operations to a more commercial dimension. One element of that decision was to enable those authorities to compete for executives within the general executive market in Australia. As soon as we do that, we run straight into the prevailing excessive level of executive remuneration.

I think it is a shared view of the major parties in this place that it is a good thing to put those authorities on a more commercial footing. I think that is a common view in this chamber. As soon as one wants to attract the best executives, one has to compete for those talents within the senior executive market. If that market had exercised more restraint, the rates payable in statutory authorities that are on a more commercial footing would be less. The central task is still to obtain restraint of those large executive remuneration packages that we are objecting to and, I see today, bipartisanly objecting to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are there any further questions relating to Industrial Relations? If not, we will move to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy.

—I would like to direct the Minister's attention to the discussion held in the Estimates Committee on Canadian pig meat. I note from the report of Estimates Committee F that officers of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy (DPIE) were unable to provide the Committee with definitive information on the nature and magnitude of subsidies made by Canadian authorities in support of this industry. The Committee noted what we already know-that Canadian pig meat was heavily subsidised. Of course, the great concern was and still is-let alone the competition it gives Australian producers because of the meat being heavily subsidised from Canada-the health side of things. I know that the DPIE has a strict inspection of meat that comes into Australia but, if disease in cooked meat floats past, we have a problem on our hands. I would like the Minister to comment on what the Department could not tell us about the nature and magnitude of subsidies, and also on the issues relating to health.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: -This is a well-trodden track. We have had this discussion many times; it appears we are going to have it again. So be it. Perhaps I should start by saying that the Australian Government does not use quarantine as a non-tariff barrier to trade. The purpose of quarantine is to make sure that no diseases get into Australia. It is not the purpose of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service to artificially use its powers to prevent trade. It is its responsibility to ensure that traded goods are non-disease carrying. When the Canadians want to sell uncooked pig meat to the Australians, we have to be satisfied that it will not transmit any disease. That process has been under scrutiny and the process is complete.

SPEECH.PARA: The next question, therefore, is: is the trade fair? Is there a level playing field here or not? Do the Canadians subsidise their pig production, whereas in Australia it is largely unsubsidised? Do the Canadians thus have a competitive advantage? The referee in those types of arguments is the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT). My understanding is that there is some form of government assistance to Canadian pig producers. The image I have of what Senator Panizza said is that he thinks there is a huge subsidy. That is wrong, although I always concede that `huge' is like `beauty': it is in the eye of the beholder.

By reference to a general level of subsidy, one would not say that the Canadians were engaging in huge subsidies. The test is: is it something that GATT would allow or is it something that GATT would not allow? As I am advised-I am sure that I can give the precise details when I consult my adviser in a moment-what the Canadians do is benign in GATT terms. If we were to take reprisal action against them, which would be non-benign GATT reprisal action, we would be the offenders and not they. However, as to whether there is anything I need to say to supplement my answer, I will just quickly check.

I simply add that the assistance given in Canada is provided at both Federal and provincial level, but is not given for the purposes of export or of enhancing a product's penetration of foreign markets. It is assistance given for other reasons within the constitutional provisions of Canada.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that reply but, with respect, I think he is playing on words when he says that it is an enhancement program to penetrate foreign markets. To me that is the same thing. Australia is part of that foreign market.

SPEECH.PARA: Moving away from Canadian pig meat, while we are on the question of subsidies, and I would like an answer later in respect of the health side of things, I briefly mention the other imports, such as bananas, orange juice and that sort of thing, dumped, for the sake of a better word, in Australia from the Latin American states What is the Minister's Department doing about that at the moment?

TALK.START.PARA: —A believed case of dumping is not a responsibility of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy; it is a Customs matter. The normal procedure is for the offended party, or the party that believes there is a case of dumping, to take some action with Customs in order to establish that. There are then mechanisms to lift the level of tariff or other protection to ensure that the dumping is neutralised and that the competition is therefore fair. However, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy-Mr Kerin's Department, the Department for which I am answering now-does not itself have that primary responsibility. As I said, that responsibility resides within the portfolio governed by Senator Button, but the primary initiating responsibility lies with whoever believes that this event has taken place to take action to protect his interests.

—I thank the Minister for that reply. Judging by the number of letters coming through from different industries, I presume a lot of producers are offended. Can the Minister comment later whether the Government has already initiated any sort of inquiry on concerns coming through from the banana industry, the orange juice industry, and, I believe, the apple industry as well?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no doubt that there are many offended people, but these things are a bit like legal proceedings. Many people make complaints, but the real test of sincerity behind a complaint is to take action and have the matter determined in one's favour to see whether what one has complained about is a matter of substance or not. While I have no doubt that there is a chorus of complaint, I am not aware at this point of particular actions being initiated. One must measure the sincerity of a complaint against the lack of action.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the honourable senator asked about the importation of fresh banana fruit from South America. In fact the bananas come from Ecuador. I am aware that the Australian banana industry has approached the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) expressing concern at the likely disease risks if Ecuadorean bananas were permitted to come into Australia. Late in 1989 AQIS received a proposal from Fruit Distributors Ltd of Wellington, New Zealand, to permit the importation of fresh banana fruit from Ecuador. That company has been importing Ecuadorean bananas into New Zealand for a number of years. AQIS has distributed a preliminary risk assessment and discussion paper in its regulatory bulletin of October 1990. That review is still preliminary, but industry will be kept fully informed of developments in this proposal and given the opportunity to contribute to the technical assessment. It will be several months before AQIS is in a position to determine whether a detailed bio-economic study will be required, and a final decision is not expected until some time in 1992-93.

Industry has responded to the AQIS discussion paper by convening meetings in New South Wales and Queensland with participants from grower, transport, packaging, marketing and horticultural industries. A fighting fund has been established for a program which includes a visit to Ecuador by a number of industry representatives to assess the field situation.

In short, the processes of health assessment of the likely disease risk caused by bringing these bananas into this country are being undertaken by AQIS in a proper way. It is unlikely that there will be a final decision on that issue until 1992-93, and the grower organisations whose interests are affected by this matter are involved in the process.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier in the discussions the Minister was obviously advised by one of his advisers that an inquiry into the health side of importing pig meat from Canada had been completed. Can the Minister tell the Committee the findings of that inquiry?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The worst fate a Minister can have is to be handed some advice that he cannot read, which has just happened to me. I was going to supplement my answer on Ecuadorean bananas by adding to what I have said about orange juice, which was another matter the honourable senator raised. That advice may become legible and I may be able to tell the chamber in a minute.

SPEECH.PARA: The health side of the pig meat issue was exhaustively examined over a seven-year period. When the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) earlier this year agreed to the importation of Canadian pig meat, it was completely satisfied about the safety of importation. It has conducted that inquiry on medical grounds only, and it has come to the conclusion that it is safe. The risk assessment has been made and the bottom line is that transmissible gastroenteritis, which is the disease that people were mainly concerned about, is recognised internationally as not being transmitted in fresh meat. At one time I was literate in how all these diseases operate, but I have not read a brief on this for over a year. However, the advice of the proper scientific authority is that the risk assessment is favourable to importation. Any other questions about competition are outside the competence of AQIS.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I now move to live sheep exports. During the Estimates Committee hearings this matter was discussed at some length and questions were asked about the rejection of live sheep exports to Saudi Arabia and other Arabian ports.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee heard evidence that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy (DPIE) had put in place customer-specific criteria for satisfying quarantine rules in each buyer nation, and that strict quality controls over age and disease had been implemented. It was reported either yesterday or the day before that a shipment of another 80,000 sheep was rejected by Saudi Arabia because of scabby mouth. I note that in today's Australian Financial Review there is a letter from a Malcolm Fraser of Melbourne-I presume that is the former Prime Minister because sometimes he uses that address and sometimes he uses the Hamilton address-pointing out that scabby mouth, the disease for which the sheep were rejected, is a passing disease. It is a terrible disease to look at because one can see it. If symptoms of disease are internal, they are not so obvious and it is not so bad. However, scabby mouth looks terrible and Australian butchers would not buy the meat of sheep infected by it.

I understand that the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation (AMLC) and the DPIE have the power to place a condition on export that the sheep have to be inoculated against the disease. I understand that this is a simple procedure. Since scabby mouth disease has caused the rejected shipment, as it did various shipments last year, why does the Department not insist that sheep for export be inoculated?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer I would have given a moment ago is that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, said on 13 November that he would take to Cabinet proposals for short term, non-distorting assistance measures in the case of orange juice.
—How do you do that?

— Mr Kerin is going to take it to Cabinet. Obviously we will wait for Cabinet's deliberations and the ensuing announcement. As a Cabinet Minister, I will be interested to see the submission when it comes up.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to scabby mouth, the name of which is about as pleasing as the sight of it, I understand. The allegation the Saudi Arabian authorities have made is that a shipment of sheep-I think they were on the vessel Al Gasseem-contained some sheep with scabby mouth. I have no independent corroboration from Australian authorities as to whether or not that is an agreed diagnosis. At this stage, all I have is an allegation being made by Saudi Arabian authorities without independent corroboration as to whether we agree.

However, Senator Panizza asked whether we have investigated the use of a vaccine that can terminate the disease if there is an outbreak of it on the voyage. I am not sure about that. Although I am advised that vaccination has been discussed by the industry, at this stage there is no guarantee that a vaccine will resolve the issue. The other element is that the vaccine is a live virus. I understand that some Western Australian farmers have indicated that they would not want such a vaccine on their property. This raises the question of whether we should be very cautious about introducing it onto a confined ship taking a long voyage from Australia to the Persian Gulf. That is a matter for some assessment. At this stage the best we can say is that this matter is under consideration. Whether we should go the extra step and do it is a matter for determination.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his reply. When I was considering the idea of inoculating sheep I was thinking that it could be done just before they go on the boat when live shippers are in yards on a feed lot. They are not allowed to return from the yards because of other diseases such as footrot. The Minister may like to comment on that later.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that legislation is to come before us, but I would like to ask a question about live sheep quotas. How does the Minister consider that going back to one operator will improve matters in terms of getting back trade into the Middle East? I understand that the quotas are going to be auctioned and that we are now limited to 800,000 sheep, or whatever the Gulf says it wants to take. How does the Minister think the situation is going to be improved? I thought that with competition amongst buyers we might be in a better position to satisfy them and also to find new markets.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —A Bill dealing with the imposition of quotas is to come before the chamber. My understanding is that it has passed the House of Representatives, so we might just debate it next week. Senator Panizza has asked for my opinion on the effectiveness of this measure. Rather than delaying the Committee now, we can have that debate when the Bill is before us.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Panizza has suggested vaccinating the sheep at the port before their departure. That is a matter worthy of consideration, but there are qualifications: I am advised that the vaccine can break down; there is a 42-day period to wait in dealing with the vaccine; and there are some extra costs associated with it. So those are matters to keep in one's mind.

I would make a general comment on the live sheep trade to the Middle East. Frankly, Australian producers have nothing at all to apologise for. By and large, the live sheep that come out of Australia are healthy, are not carrying a disease and are of good quality. There is a need to continue the persistent efforts that the Minister, John Kerin, has made in opening up that market, because some people have posed the open question that maybe this is a market in which some non tariff barriers are being used to limit the penetration of Australian sheep.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to subprogram 1.1-livestock and pastoral. I would like to pick up at the point where the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) and Senator Panizza left off-and this is more in the form of a statement than a question. It applies not only to the live sheep trade but also to the wool industry and a number of other export industries in this arena. I think it is about time we applied some lateral outward thinking and a little less inward thinking. I have to say with a certain amount of joy that a press release yesterday described a wool sale as the best that has been held this season-it was in Launceston, Tasmania-where the Australian Wool Corporation bought only 26 per cent of the wool. That was good news.

SPEECH.PARA: But when we look at the wool industry we find that the answer to our problem lies in higher taxes and quotas. When we look at the live sheep trade we find that the answer is to put quotas in place and restrict the movement of sheep from this country. I agree with the Minister that we have nothing to apologise for. I believe that part of the response to the current wool situation comes from Mr Kerin's overseas trip. If I have a criticism of the Minister it is that neither he nor the Government has been proactive enough in the part they can play. I cannot confine my comments to the Government because I do not believe the industry has been proactive enough or has had the ability to apply a little lateral thinking to get constructive answers to overcome some of the problems we have experienced in recent times.

I want to emphasise the importance of the live sheep trade. We have to recognise that, whether we like it or not, countries such as Saudi Arabia, Libya and Iran-where there has been some activity lately-deal on a government to government basis and it is very important that the Ministers responsible take a proactive role. It is my belief-obviously I do not have the time to make a long speech on this-that a little diplomatic wisdom by some Ministers could well overcome the problems we have with Libya, for example, and reopen our live sheep trade there. It has the potential to take some one million sheep per annum. We can go through the various countries one at a time.

I am certain that there are actions that can be taken in terms of the Saudi Arabia situation. Once again, they have to be taken by the top level of government. It is a fact of life that those countries do not deal with lower levels. One thing that certainly damaged our relationship with Saudi Arabia had nothing to do with disease; it was a dumping action brought by the Australian cement company over the importation of clinker into Australia. The action was dismissed some nine months later but, nonetheless, the clinker from the royal family's operation in Saudi Arabia was tied up for nine months. These are some of the things that need to be addressed.

With regard to the wool industry, I think it is very important that the necessity for some lateral thinking and for pressure to be put in this area be recognised. Once again I emphasise, as I did recently in this chamber, that on 24 August I wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and made a suggestion to him in good faith that we put in place a commercial task force of successful businessmen and get them to go around the world to look for niche markets. Once again I emphasise the importance of doing these types of things so that we can compete with New Zealand and other countries in a constructive way.

Tied up with that, it is very important that we have a strategy as to where and how we can assist in credit sales: what opportunities there are for barter; the role of the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation in covering some credit sales; and what part investment from the industry itself can play in assisting sales.

It seems absolutely crazy to me that currently in the wool industry, for every bale that goes into the stockpile there is a cost of $850. Within two years, $300 of that $850 will have disappeared because of interest and storage costs. It seems to me that it would be a far more constructive and better investment to put that $300 into the pipeline rather than having it paid to banks and warehouses.

I will make some comments on the meat industry situation, about which I have asked a number of questions in recent times in the Senate. The current situation that is developing in our meat industry is of major concern to me. It could well be said that I should have made these comments when we were considering the Industrial Relations portfolio, but I thought it was better to mention them during consideration of the Primary Industries and Energy portfolio because the impact at the producer level of this type of disputation is often forgotten. The bottom line is that, at the end of the day, the producers are the ones who suffer, miss out on export sales and have their program disrupted in terms of turn-off.

I want to emphasise-this may not always be well understood by a lot of people-that there is only one oppor- tunity when livestock can be turned off for slaughter, and that is when the animal is ready. It cannot be done two or three weeks down the track because of delays due to industrial disruption or some other reason. There is only one opportunity. Delays have a very disruptive and costly impact on the individual producer.

It is interesting to note the drop in exports out of Victoria that has occurred in the last 18 months. Of course, that has a flow-on effect through all of the other States in terms of setting the market price achieved at the saleyards and elsewhere. I am bitterly disappointed by the situation at the moment. In Victoria two days ago Premier Kirner said that this was a Federal problem. In this chamber, the Minister said that the Government was not prepared to intervene and that the resolution of the problem should be left to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. Yesterday, Deputy President Riordan adjourned the case because the relevant officers of the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union (AMIEU) were overseas.

I believe that we have a tripartite buck-passing exercise going on while the meat industry in this country is being very seriously and consistently undermined. In my view, there has been a total abuse of the directions given by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. I find that very disturbing and I believe that the Government needs to play a much more positive role in resolving this matter and getting the meatworks operating again.

I can supply information-it is well documented-which shows that the various systems that operate elsewhere produce killing rates per animal in the order of 50 per cent of the cost in Australia. We do not need any further trips overseas, junkets or whatever one wants to call them, to get that information. We know what the situation is, and I am quite certain that officers of the Minister's Department, the AMIEU and the Meat and Allied Trades Federation of Australia are well aware of the situation overseas. The problem could be addressed.

What saddens me so much about the meat industry is that it needs to be recognised that it is one of our most important industries. One has only to look at the contribution made by the producers, the employment opportunities offered and its importance in terms of exports. I refer particularly to the Asian market. It is worth noting that every 18 months economic growth in Asia is equal in size to the economy of Japan. We need to position ourselves so that we can take advantage of developments there.

I think it is very important that we apply lateral thinking to overcome some of the problems in the live sheep trade and the wool industry. I do not believe that they are insurmountable, but I certainly believe that they have not been addressed thoroughly or effectively.

With regard to the meat industry, if we have an industrial relations system-and I do not necessarily agree with all aspects of it-which is administered by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, it is important that the people involved respect the decisions of the Commission. If they do not respect the system, it is important that the Government take an active role in doing whatever it can to bring that issue to a head and make sure that those people who are irresponsible are brought to account.

The unfortunate thing about this is that in a very short time the matter will be referred to our civil courts and elsewhere. That will lead to long, drawn-out damages claims. While part of the problem will be solved in the longer term, it will cause additional disruption, which is about the last thing we want at this time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crane did not really ask a question. I should acknowledge that Senator Crane made what I thought was a considered and balanced contribution to the debate about how we should promote Australia overseas and how we should try to obtain greater niche marketing of Australian products, particularly of live sheep to the Persian Gulf, wool and other matters.

SPEECH.PARA: Since he spoke not as a politician trying to score cheap points in a political argument but rather as a representative of rural Australia, bringing some criticisms certainly of the Government but as well of rural and farmer-based organisations for their lack of activity, I was going to pay him the compliment of saying that I would pass on his remarks to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) and see that he was made aware of the views that Senator Crane has about that, because this Government does stand ready to explore whatever avenue there might be in order to promote agricultural trade abroad. Any contribution to that debate is a worthwhile one. I think Senator Crane has made a worthwhile contribution to it today.

The meat industry dispute is a matter that he and I have jousted about in Question Time. The Question Time format, whereby a strictly formed question has to be asked and answered within the limitations of the question asked, is not necessarily a format which enables discussion of the point. Senator Crane has entered into a discussion of his concerns for the first time.

If I can identify those concerns, they are that, taking a producer's view, he is frustrated by the level of industrial disputation which lowers the value of the carcass to the producer because of the delay between the turning off of that sheep or cow to the time that it is slaughtered, dressed and ready for market. I can understand that. The Government for its part has a similar view. We, too, are frustrated by the level of industrial disputation. We do not like to see our trade account damaged in any way. Our political life to some extent depends on the trade account not being damaged, so we have real self-interest as well as genuine concern.

The difference between us, if I can put it to Senator Crane in the open way in which he has ventilated his views, is not of concern. That is not the difference. The difference between us is how these matters are best resolved. One view is that they are resolved by inflicting penalties: bringing the full force of civil law to bear and to fine massively or gaol people. The other course is to let the arbitration system work properly, because I think and fear that the first course is often a course that starts from the presumption that one side is always right.

Where an industry has a high level of industrial conflict, like the meat industry unfortunately has, I find in my experience that both sides are a mirror image of one another. That is not to say anything about the grower, but at the level of the abattoir, the abattoir management and the meatworkers tend to reflect the worst traits of each other. There is no perfect, snow white purity on one side and complete blame on the other; both are equally guilty of mismanaging the industrial relations in that industry.

In those circumstances, to bring the full force of pains and penalties on one side is in itself inequitable. The difference between us is in how we manage industrial relations to achieve a better outcome. Since Deputy President Riordan has obtained an undertaking that there will be no disputation, since he has set a daily review of what is in fact going on, and since he has set a date for hearing and determination of the claim, I think it is fair to say that the arbitration system is working. We should give it room to work properly. We can sit in the grandstand and look at the field of play and criticise the umpire, but he is right there where the play is and in the best position to make a decision, and we should give him room to do so in this industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —All I have to say to the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) in this respect is, `Come off it'. Deputy President Riordan gave a direction just over two weeks ago that there was to be no strike action. The Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union (AMIEU) with the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) entered into an agreement when the meat inquiry was put in place.
