SPEECH.PARA: The Minister knows as well as I do who plays the game in terms of the union movement and who plays the game in terms of the employer organisations. I have to say to the Minister that, quite frankly, Wally Curran and his boys are one group who can be described as nothing but industrial bandits when it comes to this situation. They have a long track record of abuse. The Minister has been involved in it and I have been involved in it. One cannot describe them as anything else but industrial bandits. We must come to grips with this issue. As I said, Deputy President Riordan got this commitment yesterday, but what happened to the direction a fortnight ago? What happened to the agreement that was reached when the meat inquiry was put in place? They are not worth the paper they are written on. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to support my colleague Senator Winston Crane on the matter of the meat industry. We can sit here all day and debate the situation of industrial relations concerning the rural industry. We know we can harvest a wheat crop and store it while waiting for an industrial relations problem to pass. We can shear wool off sheep and store it and do the same. We can even do it in the dairy industry. We can milk and put the milk into the freezers, or the chillers in this case, and we can wait and hopefully the industrial disputation eventually will be resolved.

SPEECH.PARA: But when it comes to meat, as Senator Crane points out, it is vastly different. When a beast gets to a certain situation it has to be killed. Otherwise, as pointed out, it loses value; it gets too old to make that particular grade; or other stock on the farm are coming on and have to be put into different paddocks.

The Minister must remember that at present in the rural industry the beef trade is the high point. It has to be protected to a certain degree. The Minister can probably remember the 1971-I think it was-famous Midland abattoir strike. He would have been around the industrial relations sector at the time. The Midland abattoir was shut down for eight or nine months and farmers have certainly never forgotten that. I can remember that a lot of good beef cattle had to be put in the backblocks and was virtually useless the year after; not only had it become too old to make the grade but the price had dropped right back.

I believe that the meat trade, or the killing of meat, almost gets into the essential services situation; the whole industrial system in the meatworks and the abattoirs has to be looked at to sort out the problems. These problems in abattoirs have been going on as long as I have been around, so there must be something radically wrong. There have been numerous inquiries. The Government obviously knows that a problem exists; it has to be sorted out. There used to be longstanding arguments in other places-in the shearing industry and on the waterfront, to a certain extent, although the waterfront has a long way to go. I believe the meat industry has been let go long enough.

The situation we can all remember at Mudginberri-and Senator Crane and Ian McLachlan were involved-where after a long stand-off a good system was arrived at. I believe it is time that the Minister and the Government looked at the rural industry on that basis for the good of not only the meat trade but also those who actually work in the abattoirs. They will finish up just like at Mudginberri: better off than they were before.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

SPEECH.PARA: Our Government is committed to the best conservation outcomes that can be achieved consistent with maintaining a balance with the best industry outcomes. TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Short has pointed out, a large amount was spent on consultancies in the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce in the period covered by the Estimates. A number of those, as he has also pointed out, were one-off consultancies of a particular kind in respect of which no apology or criticism can properly be made. As for the general use of consultancies by the Department, I have asked for a review of that question and that will no doubt come up on subsequent occasions.
—Have you already done that?
—Yes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that answer because again it is a matter of concern. He will recall from the discussions what Dr Hawkins from the Department said in relation to my question as to whether a budget for consultancies is determined beforehand. The answer was:

SPEECH.PARA: No. Each committee has a budget and it determines how it will use it.
Then I asked:
So far as the committees are concerned, is there no ceiling placed on their expenditure on consultancies?
The answer was:
Not per se. They have a total budget--

And they can decide how they use it. I understand that point-it is a management issue-but, nevertheless, the report that Senator Button has called for on guidelines in relation to those consultancies will be an important addition to our knowledge because it is an issue where money can quite obviously run away while important expert resources within the Department are sitting there waiting to be used.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —While we are discussing the matter of consultants, I would like to put on record my reservations about one particular area where the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce (DITAC) has used consultants. That matter was raised in the hearings on 18 September, as recorded at pages 136 and 137. It relates to the $38,635 paid by DITAC to Messrs Ernst and Whinney to prepare a fraud control plan for the Department. I was very pleased to hear from the Minister and the departmental officers at the time that there had been no fraud perpetrated on DITAC to their knowledge and that they were doing this to prevent fraud occurring. What I was not so pleased about was the response I received to some of the questions I put a little later as we examined that matter. I asked Mr Palfreyman:

SPEECH.PARA: What specific procedural changes will result from the recommendations of the consultants?
The answer was classic Yes, Minister. Mr Palfreyman replied:

I think it will raise the question of fraud and fraud awareness within the Department. We now have a regular mechanism, if you like, to talk about fraud and fraud control measures. That is something which is quite different from the situation that existed 18 months ago.

Great! The Department is now going to talk about fraud control measures. But that is not really satisfactory; that is not why we pay $38,000 to consultants to prepare a fraud control program. I asked Mr Palfreyman again:

I want to know what specific procedural mechanisms had been put in place as a result of the consultants' recommendations. I am not interested in awareness campaigns. I am interested in how you have changed your operational procedures.
Mr Palfreyman replied:
We do not actually have any changed procedures yet in place.
I asked him:
Are you going to change any procedures as a result of this?
He said:
We are currently looking at that. There could well be some changes, but none have been implemented as yet.
I suppose that the looking at the changed procedures is part of the talking process.

TALK.START.PARA: —Maybe it is different from the talking about it.

—As Senator Bell has interjected, maybe it is different from the talking about it. My concern is that we seem to be spending a lot of money on consultants in this Department for absolutely no reward. I would have no problems if money were spent on consultants to prepare fraud prevention programs and the programs were put in place. When they just gather dust on the shelf, I think it is a great waste of taxpayers' money.

—There being no further matters for examination in the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, and there being no questions concerning the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Committee will proceed to the Department of the Treasury.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a perhaps fairly sensitive issue by repeating an observation made not by me but by others who actually read the transcript of the report. The discussion about the Australian Taxation Office commenced at approximately 10 p.m. and continued until about three in the morning, and the late hour may in part have contributed to what has been regarded as a matter of attitude towards senators.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to not all, but perhaps to one or two officers, in relation to the respect they had, through their answers, for the senators in the manner in which their replies were given. A number of questions were quite searching. They raised fundamental issues of tax administration but in no way and at no time did I suggest any impropriety. However, I believe that consideration should be given in future to ensuring that there is a proper relationship respecting the integrity of both the questioner and the person to whom the question is directed, and the appropriate response.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are there any further matters for examination in the Department of the Treasury?
—No answer?

—I am not quite sure, Senator Watson, whether the question was in order for a start. You did not identify any particular reservation that you were speaking to and I could not find one. If you would like to identify the particular reservation--

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think that is necessary. I have noted the honourable senator's views. I will take them into account and advise the appropriate officials about them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report dealt with our discussions in the Estimates Committee concerning Treasury economic forecasts. The Minister may recall that we had a very interesting discussion in terms of the impact on the Budget forecasts and Budget figures of the oil price increase-which of course had not occurred at the time the Budget was framed. The Budget was framed on the basis of a $US23 forecast for oil per barrel. We discussed that at some length and, in the end, the Deputy Secretary, Mr John Fraser, pointed out that one gets an impact on both the revenue and the expenditure side and that at that stage he was unable to give a sensible answer on the extent to which the impact on the expenditure side was offset over time by the impact on the revenue side because it was a highly complex calculation. I would certainly agree with that.

SPEECH.PARA: I noted, therefore, with interest the statement subsequently-two or three weeks later-by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) when he said at a press conference on 20 November 1990 that the cost to the revenue of the tax cuts that were to be made from 1 January would `roughly cancel out' the boost to the Budget from higher oil revenues. Obviously, there must have been some additional work done or information available to the Treasury between the time of the Estimates hearing and two or three weeks later when the Treasurer made that statement to enable him to say that, given that the Treasury was unable to give such an answer at the time of the hearings. I wonder whether the Minister wishes to comment on that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not a matter appropriate for this Committee. It is clearly a matter which has occurred since the conclusion of the Estimates Committee. But I will try to get an answer from the Treasurer (Mr Keating). Perhaps on some occasion I can give the honourable senator an answer in Question Time, which is the appropriate forum for such a question. I will undertake to get an answer now which I can give to Senator Short at the end of Question Time on some occasion in the near future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was a discussion, again in the Estimates Committee, on the question of the role of the Treasury in setting or monitoring prudential controls in the financial sector. I want to comment on that because I was very disappointed with the response of the Treasury to the, I thought, quite legitimate questions that were asked in the Estimates hearings. The Treasury officers played such a straight bat that it was about four cricket pitches wide and, as a result, we did not get any sensible or meaningful answers. I make the point that the whole purpose-and this was despite the fact, I must say, that we had placed questions--
—You are looking at Senator McMullan now.

—That is a delight! That does not mean that you are abdicating for greener fields, I assume, Minister. I had put questions on notice about this matter. Of course, the whole purpose of putting questions on notice beforehand is to give officers an opportunity to provide more details on areas to which they feel unable to reply without further information or details at the hearing. But I would have to say that the lack of response by the Treasury officers in this instance-the honourable senator might recall that it concerned the general question of prudential arrangements and supervisory arrangements-related also to some important issues that have been very much in the public domain in recent times. The whole question of the Commonwealth Bank's purchase of the State Bank of Victoria and the Commonwealth's involvement or otherwise with the events surrounding the Pyramid Building Society collapse were the two main ones, but there were some other specific cases as well.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that Treasury's failure to provide meaningful answers, not only in response to questions that were put on notice but also in response to the questions that were raised in the Committee-although it might have been a wonderful job of obfuscation and Treasury bureaucratic stonewalling-very seriously obstructed the important democratic process of parliamentary scrutiny. The answers I received were gratuitous, they failed to produce any real information, and they were totally unhelpful.

I hope that on future occasions those who sit at the table as Ministers or Parliamentary Secretaries guiding the questions in Estimates committees will look at this matter. If they do not, we will be spending a lot of time in committees which are supposed to be ascertaining material of interest and importance to the Parliament and not doing so. I hope that we do not see a repeat in future of what happened at least in that part of the hearings. I say that, in the overall context of what were very good examinations of the departments of Finance and Treasury, there were some black spots-particularly the one I have referred to. I hope that I will not have to make a similar criticism in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to Senator Short. I indicated I was retiring-from the chamber-and I add the three further words in case there is any confusion engendered in his mind. Before I leave the chamber, I indicate that Senator Short has made a point about the answers which were given at the Estimates Committee hearing. It is a point for which I am not without sympathy. I think it is intended as a constructive point in respect of the next sittings of the Estimates Committee. I am sure that we can seek some improved performance on those issues.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the estimates for the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, in respect of which Senator Short asked me a question and for which I undertook to obtain an answer. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that. I assume from what he said that the $360,000 or thereabouts was therefore the only figure involved; that the discrepancy between $360,000 and $800,000 was simply between what was asked and what was received; and that there are no additional cost items associated with the matter.
—That is my understanding.

—I would like to thank Senator Button, who is leaving the chamber, for his response to the point I have just raised about the nature of answers by certain Treasury officers. I ask Senator McMullan whether he is in a position to be any more forthcoming on the questions that I asked during the Estimates Committee hearing for which I did not receive an answer. In particular I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: What information would you-
the Treasury-
or the Reserve Bank have received concerning Pyramid prior to its collapse?
The answer I received was:
. . . the Treasurer has dealt with the information that he was given. I do not think I can add to that.

That was because the officer concerned was an officer rather than a Minister or a Secretary. I would welcome any additional information that Senator McMullan is able to give the Committee on this matter, because it does help the Parliament to understand the relationship between the Treasury, the Reserve Bank of Australia-and each of those individually-and the financial sector. It was unfortunate that it was not answered adequately in Estimates, but perhaps we can correct that deficiency now.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry to break the happy circle between Senator Short and Senator Button, but I do not think there is anything I can add, certainly at this stage. I will check whether some extra information can be provided, but if my recollection of the Estimates Committee discussion is correct-I have not checked that particular part in Hansard recently-to some extent the problem was one of how far we were straying into the area of departmental advice to the Minister. I will check whether anything further arises from today and if I can provide anything I will do so. But I do not have anything available to me today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As part of the deal with respect to the sale of the State Bank of Victoria to the Commonwealth Bank there is a tax involvement. I am just trying to refresh my mind on it, but I think the Commonwealth will reimburse the State of Victoria for, in effect, the amount of revenue that Victoria will lose by not getting its dividend from the State Bank. I ask whether the Government has looked at the implications of that decision for the wider range of `privatisations', for want of a better word, or sales of public assets, that it is engaging in.

SPEECH.PARA: The two examples that immediately come to mind are the sale of Australian Airlines and 49 per cent of the Commonwealth Bank. But it seems to me that the implications of the Commonwealth Bank-State Bank purchase decision are wider than just the tax implications and I would be interested to hear your comments on how much consideration has been given to the wider implications and what those implications may be, particularly in financial terms and so far as the question of Federal-State financial relations is concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not exactly clear on the honourable senator's reference to Commonwealth sales of assets and the implications of the State Bank of Victoria precedent, but the Commonwealth has looked at it. I am advised that it was made clear at the time-on 28 August the Treasurer (Mr Keating) spoke of this-that where State privatisations take place the framework that has been applied to the State Bank of Victoria situation is a framework of general application, and that information has been made available to at least Premier Greiner and perhaps to others who applied. Without being able to talk about the detail, the framework, the general approach, will be considered to be one of general application in the case of State privatisations, but I do not think it is so directly relevant to our own asset sales.

—I agree with the Parliamentary Secretary that basically I meant to refer to State privatisation. Do I take it that the pattern laid down in the Commonwealth-State Bank of Victoria deal is being regarded by the Commonwealth as the pattern that will apply in any future State privatisations? Has that definitely been accepted as the pattern for the future?
—Of course, when we get down to the detail that would depend on each case, but broadly the principles would be the same.

—Has the Treasury been able to make any calculations as to the revenue implications of that over the next few years, given the admittedly scanty knowledge of possible State privatisations. In the case of New South Wales, Premier Greiner has made various statements about privatisation proposals. Has Treasury made any calculations at all?
—No. We have not been looking at it on a speculative basis. We have no detail on that. The only one we have looked at in detail is the State Bank of Victoria.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a different subject, I asked in the Estimates Committee hearing on 3 October whether the Treasury had received any representations seeking exemption from the resource rent tax for petroleum feed stocks. The answer at that time was that the Treasury had received a copy of one representation to the Minister for Resources requesting an exemption for gas and ethane. I then mentioned to the Estimates Committee that the resource rent tax proposal would have some important implications for user industries, particularly industries using Bass Strait gas. It will have the effect of a significant increase in the price of gas in Victoria because gas, in effect, has not been subject to tax. Bass Strait gas had not been subject to it because the royalty arrangements applied only to Bass Strait oil. Gas users in Victoria will be hit by the resource rent tax decision to apply to Bass Strait. Hit even more will be those industries which use Bass Strait gas as a feed stock.

SPEECH.PARA: In that context, the petrochemical complex at Altona, a major complex which has had severe difficulties recently over the Hoechst dispute, will be very considerably hit and it will have quite a detrimental effect in relation to its ability to compete with imports. It will affect its export potential and it is having a very inhibiting effect on its views towards future capital investment. Since 3 October when this matter was raised in the Estimates Committee has the Treasury received any further representations and has the matter been looked at in any detail as a result of my questions or any other representations coming its way?

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not have any information of further approaches. On the point that Senator Button raised, it is not essentially an Estimates Committee matter but I am happy to take on notice that question and get Senator Short an answer as soon as possible, in that it has arisen in our considerations. I am happy to take it on notice from here to save duplication and get the honourable senator an answer as soon as I can.

—I thank Senator McMullan for his cooperation. With a similar dash of generosity, could he also let me know whether-this has arrived also I think since the Estimates hearings-the Treasury has been engaged in the representations that have been made by the Kirner Government to the Federal Government about the impact on Victoria of this resource rent tax proposal.
—I will include an answer to that matter in the answer to the previous question which I took on notice.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Chairman do now leave the Chair and report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Pursuant to sessional order, I call on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the privileges that we as parliamentarians have is that we have an opportunity to become familiar with some of Australia's greatest treasures. In the last week, in the company of the Hon. Fred Chaney, the shadow Minister for the environment, I had the privilege of inspecting some of the rainforests and other natural wonders of far north Queensland. One of the things that became abundantly clear to me was that, whilst many of our rainforests and other natural treasures must be preserved, they must never be preserved in such a way as to lock them away from the ordinary Australian family. At times during the last week I was disturbed by some of the more radical proposals for preservation of our rainforests and our other geographical heritages, in that they might be locked away from the ordinary Australian and become accessible only to those who fortuitously do not have to work for a living and who can take the many weeks off that are necessary to trudge through the beautiful nature spots that are our rainforests.

SPEECH.PARA: During the four days I spent with Fred Chaney touring north Queensland we had the opportunity of having discussions with many Australians from many very differing outlooks and backgrounds. The divergence of views about what should be done in the future was quite remarkable-and I might say a little perplexing for a politician; but all with whom we spoke had the interests of Australia at heart. But each person came from a position which he or she perceived to be in Australia's best interest.

We were privileged to have had discussions with councillors of the Douglas Shire Council, who kindly provided transport for us along the road from Mossman and the Daintree area through to Cape Tribulation and on to the Bloomfield River. We traversed the track that excited so much media attention in the past. However, a sensible debate has now developed between the many parties, all attempting to find out just what is the best way to handle the situation of that road from Cape Tribulation to the Bloomfield River that was the subject of so much media attention some years ago.

We were able to talk to groups of environmentalists, who had very definite and reasoned views on why the road should be closed, and also with other people who live in the area and care about the environment and who consider that the road is there and that what should be done is to make sure that it is used and maintained. If the road were maintained there would be less run-off and fewer side effects that may damage the fragile environment in the area. We spoke with many businessmen who considered that the road should be shut-and many ordinary Australians who considered that it should be open.

Mr Chaney, our shadow environment spokesman, will formulate a position for consideration by the coalition at a later time. But my impression-and I say this not wanting to reopen any of the wounds which may have been cut at the time the road was first opened-is that, as it would seem that the road is in place, what we have to do is make sure that it is maintained in such a way as not to cause any damage to the environment but so that it will provide a ready access to our rainforest treasures for ordinary Australians who want to travel up to those more spectacular parts of far north Queensland. I am conscious that the road does give the opportunity to ordinary Australians to visit these areas-an opportunity which would be denied if the road were not there.

During our visit north of Cairns, I was also pleased to find that, against the gloom and doom that besets other parts of Australia, the Sheraton Mirage Resort at Port Douglas was exhibiting an 80 per cent occupancy in November-a truly remarkable feat and one that has obviously been achieved by some very intense and skilful marketing overseas by that organisation. So it does show that, when times are tough, if the tough get going they can succeed. I can only congratulate the management of that resort for getting out and getting their customers in.

There is an enormous diversity of tourist destinations in far north Queensland, and I should mention one in particular that gave me a great deal of pleasure. It was a man-made rainforest habitat operated by some very enterprising people in the Port Douglas area. They have built acres of shade cloth under which they have planted and grown a real-life rainforest complete with running water. They have within this enclosure a myriad of different species of butterflies and bird life. But I might add that none of those have been captured wild; they all are home bred. It gives tourists a first-hand experience of just some of the many hundreds of brilliant and interesting creatures, birds and butterflies that our nation can be so proud of and is so lucky to have.

I will take a couple of minutes of the Senate's time to tell of a very moving experience that I had in this rainforest habitat-an experience that will be one of the most memorable in my life. We were followed within this rainforest enclosure by a little flying bat, who loved people and almost-I stress almost-made a nuisance of himself by wanting to be with the action and to follow people around as they walked through this area. The bat was so friendly and made a point of landing on visitors and showing his affection when he was pampered in the right way.

Although I have lived in north Queensland all my life and been very familiar with the bats flying out of mango trees as a flitting shape across the darkened sky, I had never had the opportunity of getting close to them. I was quite surprised to find that they are really very friendly and intelligent little creatures with quite a remarkable make-up, a remarkable build. Really, if one were inclined that way-I suggest that many would not be, and I also suggest that it would be improper-they would make great companions for mankind.

While we were in the Cairns area with Mr Chaney, we took the opportunity of discussing environmental matters with the Cairns Environment Centre officials and the rainforest management unit which is being funded by the Commonwealth Government to the extent of about $10m in this year's Budget. This unit is in a transition stage, in the course of being handed over to the Wet Tropics Management Authority-also a government authority being set up jointly by the Queensland Government and the Federal Government. The officials working in the rainforest management unit are very dedicated to their task. They are very knowledgeable, but they have some problems in that they are lacking in any direction from above and there is an uncertainty hanging over the future of those people. I do think that the Wet Tropics Management Authority, the Commonwealth and State governments should bring some finality to that, should appoint a director to the Wet Tropics Management Authority and coordinate those groups as quickly as possible. As things are running now, there is a problem with the direction of that organisation and it should be solved at an early date by the governments involved.

During my time in the Senate, I have taken a particular interest in the north Queensland space base. It was interesting for me, with Mr Chaney, to extend this knowledge by meeting with the Cairns based Cape York space base working party which is an offshoot group of the Cairns Chamber of Commerce. The establishment of the space base would propel Australia into the forefront of science and technology into the next century and would also create much needed jobs and impetus to development in far north Queensland. There are many people working hard on expanding their knowledge and awareness of the space base and also considering environmental matters and questions of traditional land ownership. I can only urge the Commonwealth Government and the Queensland State Government to set more realistic timetables as time is running out for the space base project to become a reality. Unless the current Cape York land use survey is quickly finished, and the environmental impact studies hurried up and finished at an early time, it would seem that Australia may miss out on this project-one which could be of worldwide significance.

One of the greatest problems facing those trying to grasp the issues of the space base is to determine the question of traditional land ownership. This, of course, needs some investigation, some clarification and some ground rules to be set with the groups with which the proponents of the space base are to deal. I understand that that is one of the problems at present; that the people wanting to proceed further, wanting to do environmental studies, wanting to talk with the traditional land owners, cannot find a traditional land owner with whom they can speak. There are some groups that have been approached that have refused to talk, to discuss it. Even if someone could be found to discuss it with the proponents of the space base, there is no certainty that one would be talking with the right person. I think it is very important for the Queensland Government and the Commonwealth Government, if it has some input into it, to set the guidelines more clearly so that those wishing to establish the space base will know with whom they can speak and that, when they have made agreements with those parties, those agreements will be binding.

I finally mention in relation to the space base that I saw in press reports in yesterday's and today's papers that, following the withdrawal of the Essington Corporation from the project, many new different groups are interested in tendering for the Cape York space base project. I also note with some interest that one of the tenderers, a group in which the former Queensland Premier, Mr Ahern, is involved, has indicated a great interest in it. But he has also said that the base may not necessarily proceed at the Temple Bay site, which had been identified by the Cape York Space Agency Pty Ltd, which has been doing the work so far and which was a creation of Essington. So, although a lot of work has been done on the Temple Bay site, it is clear from the press reports and from what Mr Ahern is reported as saying that the Temple Bay site may not necessarily be the site.

There were a certain number of reasons why that site was chosen. One of them was so that the rockets would go off over the sea rather than over land and so that no-one would be inconvenienced. The Temple Bay site has sea access that would be suitable and also comprises land which is of fairly poor quality. It is not a rainforest, as many people might think it is because it is up in Cape York. It is not as was portrayed on a disgraceful 60 Minutes program on that particular matter, with lots of natural wonderments and heritages there. It is really very low saltbush, scrubby sort of country which barely carries one beast to 20 hectares. It is very poor country indeed. That was one of the reasons why the Cape York Space Agency Pty Ltd originally chose that site. But it is interesting to see that other sites may well be looked at now, and there may not be as many problems with the traditional land owners in other sites being looked at.

Those are some of the things that were of interest in an environmental way and a development way in far north Queensland that I was pleased to show to Mr Fred Chaney. There were a number of other things that we looked at while there, one particularly dealing with the Tully Falls-Millstream Falls hydro-electric project, and I will be saying something about that a later stage. I thought, as a matter of public interest, that those things-the natural treasures, the great wonderment of the rainforests and other tourist destinations in far north Queensland, and the work that is being done on the space base in that part of the world-would also be of interest to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, in my contribution this afternoon I intend to outline the danger that new electoral boundaries in Queensland, the State I represent, will not shed the cloak of malapportionment that has for so long blighted Queensland's electoral system. If this possibility is not thwarted it will be a massive disappointment for those who have fought hard and long, sometimes against almost insurmountable odds, to rid Queensland of a rotten electoral system, a system which was deliberately designed to boost the opportunity for a particular party to remain in power. That party, of course, was the now discredited National Party in Queensland, and the electoral system was commonly referred to as a gerrymander. Even though that term is not strictly technically correct in the context of Queensland's electoral boundaries, its use was a clear indication of the deep lack of confidence Queensland residents had in their system of electing parliamentary representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: At the time of Queensland's 1989 election there was a groundswell of opinion for the introduction of an electoral system based on the principle of one vote one value. It is generally accepted that in a system of single member constituencies for enrolments in individual electorates, a tolerance of plus or minus 10 per cent may be regarded as a one vote one value electoral system. This is a fairly liberal tolerance and some observers believe that a 5 per cent tolerance may be more appropriate. After all, with a 10 per cent tolerance either way-that is, from 90 per cent to 110 per cent-it is possible for one electorate to have an enrolment 22 per cent higher than another. It is now history that in the 1989 State election Labor secured 50.3 per cent of the primary vote and about 54.3 per cent of the two-party preferred vote and, in doing so, overcame the State's malapportioned electoral system.

On assuming government, Labor, under the leadership of Premier Wayne Goss, established the Electoral and Administrative Review Commission, usually referred to as the EARC. The EARC's duties included a review of the State's malapportioned electoral system. Before discussing the EARC's findings, I shall outline Labor's policy in regard to electoral justice in Queensland. The policy is quite specific. It states:

Labor believes that the essence of representative democracy is an electoral system based on the principle of one vote one value. To this end Labor will institute an independent electoral commission which will establish fair electoral boundaries based on geographical community and population factors, with an optional preferential system of voting with a 10 per cent tolerance. There will be no electoral zones.

Like all the major parties, Labor made a submission to the Commission. The EARC, however, was not obliged to bring down a report based on Labor policy, even though Labor is in government in Queensland. Nevertheless, although some parts of Labor's submission were not accepted by the Commission, Labor Party members in Queensland are able to accept comfortably almost all of the key points of the EARC's recommendations.

The key recommendations are continuation of single member electorates; compulsory enrolment and compulsory voting; optional preferential voting; an average of about 20,000 voters per electorate with a 10 per cent tolerance amongst electorates; an electoral weighting for electorates more than 100,000 square kilometres in area; the number of members of State Parliament to remain at the current level of 89; an independent redistribution commission to determine electoral boundaries; the early appointment of a Queensland electoral commissioner who will be the chief executive of a Queensland electoral commission; and the State Education Department to give priority to electoral and citizenship education for primary and secondary schools.

Most of these recommendations go a long way towards meeting the urgent public demand for a fair electoral system in Queensland, one based on the principle of one vote one value. But the Commission's recommendation to weight electorates more than 100,000 square kilometres in area is a serious flaw. What the EARC's proposal would do, if adopted, would be to create a two-zone electoral system. It is simply not possible to have a one vote one value electoral system with two zones having different quotas in the different zones. It would not be correct for the Queensland Parliament to accept this part of the Commission's recommendations.

The EARC's basic proposal in relation to weighting is to add what have been termed phantom voters to the enrolment in electorates with an area of 100,000 square kilometres or more. The number of phantom voters may be up to 2 per cent of the electorate's area. Thus, for example, an electorate of 150,000 square kilometres may have 3,000 phantom voters added to its enrolment.

I find it incredible that this idea had its genesis in a proposal made by a well-known member of the Australian Labor Party in Queensland, Councillor Noel Robertson. According to the EARC's report, Councillor Robertson proposed his own hybrid suggestion to the EARC. His method absolves certain electorates from adhering to an electoral system based on the principle of one vote one value.

I have always enjoyed good relations with Councillor Robertson, who is Chairman of the Cloncurry Shire Council, but on this occasion I must totally disagree with him. I cannot accept that he was unaware of Labor policy. He was Labor's candidate for the seat of Flinders at the 1989 election, so he should have had more than a passing knowledge of Labor policy. When I have the opportunity, I shall determine whether he sought permission from his own Party to propose his harebrained scheme.

I also find it incredible that the distinguished commissioners of the EARC would consider this proposal worthy of comment, let alone suggest that their two-zone recommendation should be passed into law. Surely they knew the strength of feeling against zonal systems in Queensland, with the votes of some citizens being of greater value than others simply because of their geographical location. The EARC protests that it has not recommended a two-zonal system, but it has.

It is worth while looking at what the EARC's proposal would mean in concrete terms. The figures I am about to outline are based on data and analyses of those data provided to me by the statistics group of the Parliamentary Library. I am indebted to that group for its assistance.

Under the existing boundaries, four Queensland State electorates are over 100,000 square kilometres in area. These are Flinders, 199,000 square kilometres; Warrego, 225,500 square kilometres; Cook, 350,750 square kilometres; and Gregory, 443,250 square kilometres.

The EARC's proposals would result in a quota per electorate of about 20,000 voters. Assuming this figure of 20,000 with a 10 per cent variation, enrolments could vary from 18,000 to 22,000 voters. I seek leave, Madam Acting Deputy President, to incorporate in Hansard a table which illustrates how the proposals would affect these four electorates. I have in fact cleared this table with the Whips from both sides of the chamber.
Leave granted.
The table read as follows-
