TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. This table reveals that the number of phantom voters in those four electorates are 3,950 for Flinders; 4,450 for Warrego; 7,015 for Cook; and 8,865 for Gregory. If these phantom voters are deducted from 18,000, the lowest allowable enrolment for electorates, it may be seen that the number of real voters required for each electorate is 14,020 for Flinders; 13,550 for Warrego; 10,985 for Cook and 9,135 for Gregory. Taking into account these electorates' existing enrolments, Flinders and Warrego would need additional real voters to make up the least possible quota of 18,000 voters. Cook would be able to shed over 2,000 of its existing enrolment and Gregory would give about 1,000 of its real voters to another electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: With other electorates, the possible enrolment may vary from 18,000 to 22,000. The ratio of the lowest to the highest possible enrolment is 1 : 1.22. Put another way, a vote in the electorate with the lower enrolment is worth 1.22 times the worth of a vote in the electorate with the higher enrolment. As I mentioned earlier, this type of variation in a one vote one value system of electorates is usually regarded as acceptable.

The ratios of real voters in the four electorates being discussed to the highest possible number of electors in other State electorates are not acceptable. They are 1.57 for Flinders, 1.62 for Warrego, 2.00 for Cook and 2.41 for Gregory. Should the EARC's suggestion for remote areas be given any credence when it allows for possibilities of votes in one area being worth two and more times the value of votes in other areas? My response is that it should not. This is the very defect in the current zonal system that Queensland electors want to see removed. I have discussed the probable consequences of the EARC's proposals on those four State electorates, which currently have an area of 100,000 square kilometres or more. Nevertheless, under the proposals more than four electorates could be over 100,000 square kilometres in area.

It is also worth noting that three Federal electorates in Queensland exceed 100,000 square kilometres in area: Leichhardt, 141,300 square kilometres; Maranoa, 625,200 square kilometres; and Kennedy, 772,000 square kilometres. None is weighted with phantom voters and there is rarely, if ever, any clamour that the Federal representatives in those electorates have areas too large to cover adequately. To suggest, as the EARC does, that these representatives have 12 senators to assist them is also totally misleading. If the EARC believes that this is so, it does not understand the reality of Federal politics.

It is my understanding that the EARC report is to be examined by the Parliamentary Electoral and Administrative Review Committee. It will then be considered by the Government. I would urge the parliamentary committee to consider the adverse consequences of the weighting proposal. Just because the EARC has made a recommendation to have two classes of electorates does not mean that the idea is sound. My assessment is that the weighting proposal should be rejected and the State Government should take this opportunity to reject this aspect of the EARC's advice. If it does not, an unacceptable zonal component will remain an unpalatable feature of the Queensland electoral system.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Electoral Boundaries-Australian Audit Office-Registration of Business Names

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: -Before commenting on the two subjects I wish to raise in this discussion of matters of public interest, could I just say that the hypocrisy of the Australian Labor Party knows no bounds when it comes to electoral boundaries and redistribution. Members of the Labor Party claim to be whiter than white but they ignore reality. The reality in South Australia is that although at the last State election the Liberal Party obtained 52.5 per cent of the vote and the Labor Party 47.5 per cent, unfortunately the Liberal Party was unable to form government. So Labor members cannot stand up in this House or any other House in Australia and claim to be the advocates of one vote one value and fair electoral systems. The fact is that they do not practise what they preach.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to refer to two important issues related to, firstly, the Australian economy and, secondly, a business in South Australia. On many occasions during the past few months we have asked the Government to release a report entitled the Sheridan report. It is now well past the stage where the non-appearance of that report can be treated as being above suspicion. It is a matter of great public interest that a report commissioned by the Government which then tells the Government facts it does not want to hear can be hidden, as this one has been.

The Sheridan report is an independent review of the Australian Audit Office. The Government is deliberately keeping this report under wraps. It was delivered to the Government by the due date- 31 March 1990. We have now been waiting eight months for its release. Media speculation about the report grows daily.

We have had the ridiculous situation of having two government reports released recently which actually comment on the findings of the Sheridan report. The annual report of the Australian National Audit Office makes mention of the Sheridan report. The report of the independent auditor, Mr Michael Sharpe, also makes mention of the Sheridan report. I am delighted that this means that at least someone has seen the report. But the fact is that those who should see the report have not. This Parliament and the public have not seen it. That is what counts. That is what is called accountability.

So what is in the report that is so difficult for the Government to accept? What is in this report that needs to be hidden? The history of the man who prepared the report, and the reasons he was commissioned to produce it, give us some of the clues to that. Tom Sheridan is the retired Auditor-General of my home State, South Australia, and a man respected by all sides of the Parliament. He is a man who knew how to achieve results in South Australia and who, when Auditor-General, managed to increase efficiency auditing of government agencies and bodies while the staff numbers within his department actually decreased. So there we have it-a man who knows and understands the word `productivity' and how to achieve it.

Is productivity and what it means what this Government is hiding from? I am told that the Sheridan report contradicts a Commonwealth Joint Committee of Public Accounts recommendation for additional funding of $15.7m for the Audit Office. This funding was recommended by the Public Accounts Committee to enable the Audit Office to conduct efficiency audits of government bodies and agencies. However, the Sheridan report not only says that the Audit Office does not need the money to carry out that additional work; it actually states that about 60 full time staff-the equivalent of about $3m a year-from within existing resources of the Audit Office could successfully be redirected to efficiency audits. In other words, not only does the Audit Office not need more money to carry out efficiency auditing; the Sheridan report findings are that, if the Audit Office did not need to take on the extra workload of efficiency audits, it could save $3m and 60 staff. That is the meaning of increased productivity methods. That is the meaning of increased management and control of resources, of better planning of audits. I am also informed that the Sheridan report recommends allowing the Audit Office to charge all government bodies for audits.

The underhanded treatment of the Sheridan report by the Government suggests that, despite wasting many trees extolling to the nation the values of increased productivity, the Government runs scared as soon as it is confronted with the hard facts of productivity within the Public Service.

Let us look at it this way: the Australian National Audit Office is a relatively small and a supposedly efficient office. Yet, as soon as a man who understands how to achieve productivity gains access to the running of that office, he identifies quite enormous savings to be made. What gains could be achieved from similar reviews of major government agencies such as the departments of Defence, Social Security, Finance and so on? As far as the Government is concerned, it does not bear thinking about; that is why the Sheridan report has not been tabled and presented to this Parliament. It has been kept under wraps, not so much for what it says about the Audit Office but for what it indicates about the Public Service generally. Clearly, vast savings could be made if similar reviews of other government bodies and agencies were carried out to indicate productivity gains. But as far as the Government is concerned, its productivity message to the private sector is, `Do as I say; don't do as I do'. Meanwhile, the Commonwealth Auditor-General, John Taylor, has been reported as follows in the Business Review Weekly:

``The Sheridan report is positive as far as we're concerned,'' he says. ``It is a good report and it is fair. It has put the acid on us in non-audit areas, where it is harder to get further productivity gains.''
So we have John Taylor praising the report. No doubt he, too, would be pleased to see a report of which he approves made public.

How much longer will the Government hide the report from us? Not once in the eight months since the Sheridan report was delivered has a reason been put forward for the delay in its release. It has gone far beyond bearing a report which shows changes that need to be made, need to implemented and need to be put in place. It is at the stage where Parliament is being treated with contempt. It is a matter of public interest that ought to be resolved immediately. Governments are accountable for the spending of taxpayers' money. The Sheridan report has identified where some of that money can be saved; this Parliament has a right to know. That the Sheridan report has identified the tip of the iceberg is all the more the reason for its release-and its release urgently.

There is another matter of concern to me as it relates to a business operation in South Australia, a private company, free enterprise company, that has launched into the tourism market to service the Kangaroo Island tourism industry in the State of South Australia. Having got the business up and running, very successfully, very professionally and very efficiently, its operators have now run into a brick wall through administrative blunder. The position is that they used to operate ferries known as the Philanderer Ferries. The new name is Kangaroo Island Searoad. They operate two 40-metre ferries with 16 crew between Kangaroo Island and the mainland, and it is a vital link between the mainland and Kangaroo Island-an island that has enormous tourism potential for South Australia and is exceptionally important to our State's tourism.

In April this year they were granted by the South Australian Corporate Affairs Commission registration of the business name Kangaroo Island Searoad. They went ahead and put in place this particular enterprise, this facility. They undertook an extensive launch of Kangaroo Island Searoad, put in place its vessels, equipped its crew with uniforms, printed brochures and undertook advertising of its service in the tourism sector. Then, after being in operation for several months, they received correspondence from the Australian Government Solicitor threatening to sue the company for using the name `Searoad', saying that by a 1956 Act the Australian National Line (ANL) has exclusive right to that name. When the 1956 Act was converted in 1988 for public company status of this government quango, that was maintained.

So we have a situation that a business, in good faith, applied for and obtained registration of a business and trading name, operated for several months and incurred costs of hundreds of thousands of dollars in marketing potential. Two months later, the operators were told that within days they had to take the name off the side of the ferries, to burn all their tickets, all their literature, all their publications, all their brochures and to take the uniforms off the crews servicing the two ships because they have the name `Searoad'.

But the story gets even more curious. There are other companies trading in Australia already who are using that name. One of them is Searoad Props Pty Ltd. Why has the Australian Government Solicitor written to this one company in South Australia when there are other companies in Australia that have the word `Searoad' in their business name or their trading name? Why has this one company been singled out?

The South Australian Corporate Affairs Commission had no knowledge that that name was protected. I understand, and the South Australian Attorney-General has indicated in that Parliament, that it is the norm that, where there is a name protected by Act-as is the case with `Searoad' with ANL-that formal advice is given through ministerial council meetings to the relative State authorities so that they are aware of that set of circumstances.

In this instance, there was no notification from the Federal authorities to the State authorities that the word `Searoad' was in fact a generic word protected under the Act. Therefore, the Corporate Affairs Commission within South Australia acted in good faith in registering the name-giving the green light for this company to go ahead. Talk about the classic Yes, Minister syndrome: it seems to me to be well and truly to the fore in this circumstance.

Senator Collins, the Minister responsible in the area, has become extremely difficult to contact in the last few weeks to try to clarify this matter for this company. I understand that the matter is currently before the Federal Attorney-General (Mr Duffy). But it happens to fall within the jurisdiction of the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, Senator Collins. I ask the Minister, as a matter of urgency, to give consideration to the plight of this South Australian company.

If it were not for the ANL Act, the company would be quite entitled to proceed with the name `Kangaroo Island Searoad'. It would be able to continue to provide the service which it put in place in good faith with the support of government instrumentalities. The fact that it now cannot proceed, that there is a stumbling block and that it is being singled out from other Australian companies that use the word `Searoad', is something that needs to be addressed as a matter of urgency-particularly when ANL does not use that generic word in any of its advertising or marketing in South Australia. It is not even in the phone book in South Australia. Yet, ANL is objecting to this word being used by a company that operates a short transport link between the mainland and Kangaroo Island in South Australia.

What has happened raises this question: with the privatisation of Australian Airlines Ltd in due course, will the generic word `airline' be used in legislation and, if it is, what problems will flow from that? So the problem that has been highlighted indicates an area that needs to be addressed quite seriously.

Madam Acting Deputy President, this company has acted in good faith. It deserves more than the scant regard it is getting at the moment from the Federal ministry. It has a problem on its plate not of its own doing. I think it behoves the Minister, Senator Collins, to address the matter and give a clear indication of what action the Government intends to take either to uphold the Act, amend the Act, or ask ANL to show some commonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak briefly about the matter that Senator Olsen has raised. It is something that has come to my attention in the last couple of days. We believe that the new Australian Securities Commission legislation will come into effect on 1 January. This whole matter of business names and the particular case of the `Searoad' name in South Australia illustrates one of the major problems that the business community in Australia could suffer from under the new national scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: As most honourable senators would know, currently business names are registered in each of the States and Territories under business registration regulations. I would presume that they would probably differ from State to State. I know that in Western Australia the test that the Corporate Affairs Commission would apply to one wanting to register a name is whether or not that name is likely to cause confusion with some other name. Because under the new national scheme we are going to register all business names and company names, particularly company names, in the one data base in Morwell in Victoria, we will have a situation where there will be 800,000 names.

The Government has come to the conclusion, and quite properly, I guess, that we cannot apply a test such as the one I have described-that is, the test of whether a name is likely to cause confusion-with 800,000 companies because it would just be a bureaucratic nightmare to have to review all of these cases.

So what is likely to happen after 1 January is that across Australia there will be a number of companies-for example, Smith Corporation, Smith Company or Joe's Delicatessen-with similar names registered. This has caused the need to have what we now know as the Australian companies number-that is, a nine-digit number which all companies around Australia are required to have printed on all of their public documents, cheques, letterheads, envelopes, seals and so forth.

This will potentially cause the sorts of problems for business around Australia that my colleague Senator Olsen has mentioned today. The test that will apply from 1 January is that the Australian Securities Commission will not register a name only if that name is identical to an existing name. So if one were, for example, to have the name `Joe's Cake Shop Pty Ltd' no-one else could go along and register the same name. But if there were a successful cake shop operating somewhere in Australia and someone like Coles or Woolworths, or some other large transnational company, wanted to use, I guess, the goodwill associated with that name, all they would need to do is register a company with some small alteration to the name. They may decide to register `Joe's Cakes Shop' instead of `Joe's Cake Shop'. If they did, they would meet the test which will be applied by the Australian Securities Commission.

Another good example is a successful small business or partnership that has a business name registered. Take, for instance, Burley, a very famous manufacturer of footballs from Western Australia, which I understand is just a small family company. If some national, or even international, company wanted to come along and use the goodwill associated with that name, all it would have to do is register a name similar, but not identical, to Burley. This could be done with impunity in relation to the Australian Securities Commission test which is that one cannot register an identical name. One can, however, register a name which is likely to cause confusion.

Someone like Burley could then enter into a passing-off action and I guess try to sue the international or national company that was trying to use a similar name and steal the goodwill of that company name. However, some small businesses-one-man and two-man trading names, for example-might just not have the resources of the big national and international companies to fight a court battle to protect their goodwill and name.

The point that is important to make here-and Senator Olsen has made it already-is that under the new Australian Securities Commission regime, which will apply after 1 January, there seems to be one rule for the private sector and one rule for the public sector. The name `Searoad' is being protected by the Government. It is stopping, at great expense, this company in Adelaide from using the name. However, this could not be done in the private sector. I think that is wrong; it is a double standard. It is an area where I believe there will be great confusion.

There will be great cost to business across this nation when this new scheme comes in and 800,000 companies are all registered on the one register. It will be very expensive. There will be a lot more litigation in relation to passing-off actions. It is hard to estimate what the impact of this one aspect of the Australian Securities Commission legislation will be. But, on all estimations, it will add an enormous amount of bureaucracy. There will be an enormous amount of litigation in relation to company goodwill. The centralising of State corporations regulations is likely to considerably enhance the problems that small business will confront.

So all I do today is to draw this to the attention of the Senate. It is an issue that will raise its head during the first 12 months of the implementation of the Australian Securities Commission legislation. The Senate and the Australian Parliament and all of us who represent our various constituents need to be aware of it because it involves a sort of bureaucracy which is going to cause a lot more trouble. The problem that Senator Olsen has raised here today is but a small tip on the top of a very big iceberg.
Sitting suspended from 1.36 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I remind the Minister of his response to my question yesterday. If I might say so, he smugly urged the Opposition members to wait for today's national accounts figures for a more intelligent assessment of Australia's economic position. In light of the latest national account figures, I ask the Minister whether the Government will now confirm that Australia is in a recession.
—The answer to that question is yes.
—Your own backbenchers laugh. They are enjoying this.

—It does not please us at all. Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. Now that the Government finally acknowledges what has been evident for so long-that is what the Opposition senators' reaction was about-will the Government indicate what it intends to do in terms of policy changes for the benefit of those thousands of Australians who have lost or who are losing their jobs, for small businesses that are collapsing and others who are struggling as a result of government policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I resent Senator Hill's suggestion that I smugly answered a question yesterday. I said that the national account figures would be out today and the question which was asked then would be subsumed in the anticipated national accounts figures. That was the point I was making. In so far as the current economic situation is concerned, the Government has said for some time that it expects an improvement in output in the Australian economy next year. No response made instantly now is in any way capable of producing any immediate reaction in the economy.
—I have heard this before.

—Yes, Senator Parer has heard this before. That is the point. I am saying it again because Senator Hill obviously has not heard it before, nor has the shadow Treasurer, Mr Reith, who made some suggestions today about Government revenue and expenditure in terms of a mini-Budget. He made those suggestions in the clear knowledge that Opposition senators had rejected the assets test on the family allowance.
—Come on!
—He made that in the clear knowledge--
—What sort of money are you talking about-$20m?

—Mr Reith said, `We would adopt a bipartisan approach towards this issue'. Only two weeks ago the Opposition was not prepared to adopt a bipartisan approach to the present Budget which is still before the Senate. It is all very well for Opposition senators to come in here, yelling their heads off today, buoyant with gloom about the national accounts figures. They should be looking at their own track record in the last two weeks. Opposition members knocked off their leader on this issue. Their leader within the parliamentary party was defeated on this issue. He was prepared to honour the previous statements which he made about support for the Budget.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I have never seen the Opposition in the Senate so excited by a very bad situation revealed in the national accounts. Since the Budget, how many questions have we had on the Australian economy from the Opposition in the Senate?
—A lot-one hell of a lot.
—`A hell of a lot', says Senator Short. I would think two. This is the first question that has been asked by the Leader of the Opposition on the Australian economy.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—There is a lot of yelling --
—Where are you sending him, Gareth?

—Senator Evans is a much shrewder man than that. He would not want me to go to London with these national accounts figures-not for a moment. The point I was making before I was rudely interrupted by an interjection was that there is a lot of noise here today from an Opposition which has scarcely said anything about the economy in the last few months.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Can the Minister tell the Senate what the Government's attitude is to the imminent adoption in New York of a United Nations (UN) Security Council resolution on the use of force in the Gulf situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answers to questions earlier this week I have already made clear the Government's reaction to the general prospect of such a resolution, but let me repeat the points: we hope that the crisis can be peacefully resolved but accept that ultimate resort to force cannot be ruled out if UN objectives are unlikely otherwise to be achieved; if force is to be applied we would very much prefer it to be under cover of a specific UN Security Council resolution; we accept that it is time for further pressure to be applied to Iraq to make its leadership understand that it has no option but to withdraw from Kuwait and meet the other terms of the UN resolutions; and in this context we support the passage of a resolution of the kind that is now before the Security Council.

ANSWER.PARA: Depending on the final terms of that resolution, its passage will be an important new element in the international community's consideration of its response to the present crisis. The Government will be considering carefully over the next few days the implications of any resolution that may be passed. As far as our own involvement in the Gulf is concerned, it is presently anticipated that the Prime Minister will be making a parliamentary statement on the Gulf situation generally early next week-probably on Tuesday. Until then, I do not think there is anything useful I can further add.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Will security grounds permit the Minister to tell us where he has been for the last few days?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Contrary to rumours, I have not been to a slimmers' farm for the last five days.

ANSWER.PARA: Government senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The cruel people on my side of the chamber are asking where Senator Durack has been for the last five years, so we are one all. I have in the last few days visited the three ships we have deployed in the Gulf. When I first planned that trip six weeks ago I think there were security aspects which led us not to announce that trip, because of the unknown situation there. Probably as the weeks went by that became less imperative; nevertheless that is the way the position stayed.

ANSWER.PARA: I am sure Senator Durack will be interested to know how well the ships have done in the Gulf. They have interdicted a very high percentage of ships, and the situation now is that there is virtually not an Iraqi ship left that is not laid up. The morale of the crews is particularly high, and they very much appreciate the support their deployment there has received from this Parliament-this chamber and the other place. I think, overall, we can all be very pleased about the success of the deployment. In short, I have spent the last few days in the Gulf visiting the ships.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am pleased that the Minister has been able to tell us about the great significance of his visit and what he found, but I am still curious to know why the visit had to be kept so secret and what the security grounds could possibly have been when the President of the United States, the US Secretary of State and the British Minister for Defence have made highly public visits to their forces in the region.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Beahan has suggested that I am a bigger target. The reason had nothing to do with my security, incidentally. At the time this trip was planned five or six weeks ago, a visit by anyone to our ships put that person in a particular geographical region-that is, within a helicopter flight of the host country that is dealing with our logistical support. For that reason, and that reason alone, I did not want to pre-announce the visit when the decision to go was made five or six weeks ago.

ANSWER.PARA: As I have conceded here, given the way that international events were going at that particular time, by the time I went that reason was virtually inoperative. However, we saw no particular reason to announce the visit. There are one or two other sensitive matters concerning publicity in that region and I am happy to go into them. Our logistics base there has worked very effectively, but one of the conditions of its use is that there be no publicity. That was also in my mind in regard to this particular trip.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNION OF SOVIET SOCIALIST REPUBLICS: HUMAN RIGHTS

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Has the Government been monitoring the human rights position in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) and, if so, has there been an improvement in the situation recently? Has the Minister seen the October Australian newsletter from Amnesty International suggesting that prisoners of conscience in the Soviet Union are still being punished repeatedly? What is the Government's response to that report, if it has seen it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Government has been closely monitoring the human rights situation in the USSR on an ongoing basis. We recognise and very much welcome the significant progress that has been made there in recent years. The Soviet Union today is obviously a vastly different society from what it was only five years ago or, indeed, more recently. New laws in areas such as freedom of conscience and the media have been passed by the Supreme Soviet. Draft laws on immigration, citizenship and freedom of association are under consideration by the Supreme Soviet. Revision of the penal code has reduced the possibility of conviction for political offences and the system of psychiatric treatment is undergoing significant reform.

ANSWER.PARA: Notwithstanding these welcome improvements in the human rights situation in the Soviet Union, there remain areas where further progress needs to be made. Although the number of political prisoners recognised by Amnesty as `prisoners of conscience' was reduced from 600 in 1986 to just 90 in late 1989, there are currently concerns about 50 or so suspected political prisoners in the USSR, several of whom are believed still to be in psychiatric hospitals.

I am aware of Amnesty International's concerns over prisoners of conscience in the Soviet Union. The October 1990 Amnesty International newsletter referred to by Senator Maguire mentions the cases of Bohdan Klymchak and Aleksandr Goldovich. The Australian Embassy in Moscow has been monitoring the case of Bohdan Klymchak for some time. We have received information that he was released from prison in mid-November, and I have asked the Embassy to verify the allegations made by Amnesty about the other man, Aleksandr Goldovich.

The Soviet Union signed a human contacts agreement with Australia last February which commits both governments to facilitating a broad range of people-to-people contacts in a number of areas. Also, next January the Australian Government will for the first time engage in bilateral discussions with the Soviet Union on issues concerning human rights of interest to both countries. This is another encouraging and, I believe the Senate will acknowledge, very welcome development.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister representing the Treasurer relates to the fact that today's national accounts figures confirm that Australia is in a recession and that we have not experienced the soft landing that the Government has been promising us for the last 18 months. Given that imports rose during the September quarter by 8.4 per cent, does the Minister agree that, even though the economy has been deliberately shut down, the strategy of containing the foreign debt growth by high interest rates has not been successful? Will the Minister comment on the Australian Democrats' view that a more appropriate strategy would have involved more emphasis on strategic trade policies to attack Australia's current account problems without increasing unemployment? Given that recessions impact most heavily on low income earners and tend to increase poverty, what measures does the Government intend to take to lessen the burden on disadvantaged groups-especially the 2.6 million Australians who are already living in absolute poverty?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not prepared to accept several of the assumptions in Senator Powell's question. Having said that, I will answer as best I can. It is true that imports were strong in the September quarter. It is important to note that there were a number of important factors in that. Five per cent of the 8.4 per cent increase was due to transport equipment, which included aircraft and things of that kind. There was another large contributor from service transactions related to the acquisition by the Australian Government of the new chancellery building in Tokyo. There were some one-off things peculiar to the September quarter. But I do not regard that as an explanation. During the history of the Australian economy there have always been surges of imports of transport equipment and things of that kind.

ANSWER.PARA: However, we are dealing with one quarter's figures. The figures for the previous quarter show that imports were dramatically down. If one averages the imports over the six-month period, one sees that there is not such a spectacular result as has appeared in the September quarter import figures.

Senator Powell asked whether the Government, in responding to the current account figures, would adopt some policies enunciated by the Australian Democrats. As a general proposition, my answer to that question is no. As a general political, economic and social proposition, adopting policies which have been advanced by the Democrats is not a good way to go.

There are a number of definitions of strategic trade policy. My understanding of strategic trade policy may be something quite different from Senator Powell's understanding as expressed in her question. I am not prepared to answer that question at Question Time in the absence of some specifics of what it means. I think they are the main points in Senator Powell's question. If I have not covered anything, she will no doubt let me know.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Would the Minister include, in any considerations of strategic trade policies, for instance, accelerated depreciation? Indeed, I raise the question of the $2.134 billion worth of imports of primary products into this country and the need for strategic trade policies to attack that problem.

—Senator Powell and I are like two Peter Sellers characters. I am referring not to our appearance, but to the two Peter Sellers characters who argue from different premises, like Edinburgh housewives, as somebody once said. The point is that my understanding of strategic trade policy would not include the question of accelerated depreciation. It seems to me to have nothing to do with strategic trade policy as it is enunciated by the journals and the experts around the place. Perhaps that is a Democrats' view of strategic trade policy. I will have a look at the second part of Senator Powell's question, which related to rural imports, not as a matter of policy but to see whether it is a matter of fact and, if so, why.

—Is the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support aware of concern within the aviation industry that the Civil Aviation Authority's proposed airspace management changes will adversely affect the safety of our airways system? Is there any basis for this concern? Can the Minister confirm that our airways, which are currently the safest in the world, will continue to be so?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I can confirm that. The concerns have been raised in two consecutive programs now on A Current Affair, both of which I saw, and which were riddled with inaccurate statements presented as fact. A number of things have to be made clear about what is a major proposal to reorganise Australia's airspace management. The first point is that decisions have not been taken by the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) to implement any of the proposals and will not be taken for some time. Extensive consultations are currently under way with the industry. The only timetable that has been set, February next year, is merely a target to establish at that time an implementation timetable for the proposals that go ahead. In fact, I expect that the full implementation of the proposals that come out at the end of this process will take years, not months, to establish.

ANSWER.PARA: It is absolutely untrue, as suggested by the program, that air traffic control will be removed from 80 per cent of Australian airspace. That is absolute nonsense. Currently, the air traffic control provided in Australia consists of a service adjacent to busy airports and positive separation provided at high altitude, which is where most of our major jet services operate. The fundamental basis of the proposal that is being put forward is to lower by some 4,000 feet the altitude of the air traffic control currently provided, which will significantly increase the number of aircraft that get positive separation services provided by air traffic control.

On that program the assertion was made that special events, such as the races at Birdsville, which were specifically cited, and Bathurst, where a very large number of aircraft come into an airstrip that would normally not do so, will also be greatly affected. I saw the interview where a fellow said that aircraft would collide in the air and so on. That assertion is absolute nonsense. The Civil Aviation Authority has always provided the service of a mobile control tower at any of these special events, such as Birdsville and Bathurst, where large numbers of aircraft converge on an airstrip that normally do not do so. That service has always been provided, and will continue to be provided, by the CAA, and in fact is completely untouched by any of the proposals that are being put forward at the moment.

I conclude by saying that the basis on which all this is being done has as its primary consideration the question of safety. The consultation process has a very long way to go and significant changes will no doubt be made to the proposals that are currently being put forward. But that is all they are-proposals.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to the comments yesterday by the Governor of the Reserve Bank, Bernie Fraser, that there should not be any further easing of monetary policy this year. I ask: does the Minister agree with this view? If so, does he therefore rule out any further easing of interest rates this year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The adjustment to monetary policy is a matter of judgment to be exercised at the appropriate time. Sometimes governments exercise it at the appropriate time and perhaps sometimes they do not.
—Oh!

— Senator Durack would know; he was a member of the Fraser Government. He did not do much good in 1982. He would be the first person to interject. If he wants to have a look at the quality of his recession compared with this one, I will talk about it.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —It is extraordinary that an interjection about monetary policy should come from Senator Durack. As far as the comments of the Governor of the Reserve Bank are concerned, I think his prime concern is to bear down on inflation, as the Government has been successfully doing. His remarks about monetary policy are probably related to that and probably related to the international climate-about which I have answered questions from Senator Short in the Senate before-namely, that the Government has to be concerned in the exercise of monetary policy--
—A little while ago, you said you had not been asked any questions about this. You said we asked no questions. Make up your mind.

—Senator Baume can speak for himself. He has not asked me any questions; Senator Short has. I conceded that earlier. Senator Short has asked me about four questions since the Second World War! I expressed in the Senate only a week or so ago, in answer to a question from Senator Short, I think, the Government's view that the important thing is to manage how this country comes out of the recession. That will depend very much on the international environment.
—And a change of government.

—I am not making any predictions. As unsophisticated as Senator Short may be in some ways-and I would regard that as a compliment to him-he ought to have known better than to ask me a question in the terms in which he did.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. It certainly is the clearest indication that Senator Button will not be gracing the portals of this Senate chamber for much longer, if he gives such a non-answer to what is a serious question concerning the state of the recession.
— Order! Ask your supplementary question.
—My question is, again: does the Minister agree with the view of the Governor of the Reserve Bank that there should not be any further easing of monetary policy this year? Yes or no?

—I answered that question. I said that the control of monetary policy is a matter for judgment to be exercised at the appropriate time and in various circumstances. I said that the views of the Government were very clearly directed to two issues, which the Government would have to take into account. Senator Short knows better than to ask me when interest rates are coming down, if that is the burden of his question.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I asked him a question on Wednesday concerning the level of industrial disputation in Victoria. He gave me an answer which spoke of comparisons with other States. Can he now tell the Senate how the level of industrial disputes in Victoria since the Labor Government came into power there compares with that under the government which immediately preceded it? Will this additional information lead to a change in the industrial policy pursued by the Government of which he is a member?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it will not, because this Government is more successful in handling industrial relations than the Opposition was. The record of this Government is that industrial disputes in this country have run at 62 per cent below the level they did for the comparative period of the Fraser Government. Indeed, the greatest fall in industrial disputation in Australia, if one compares the Fraser-Hawke periods, was in Victoria where there has been a 76 per cent reduction in the level of industrial disputes.

ANSWER.PARA: However, Senator Cooney has asked me about comparisons with the Victorian governments. The Cain Labor Government came into power in Victoria on 3 April 1982. In the previous 10 years, from 1972 to 1981, under the Liberals, the average annual rate of industrial disputation in Victoria was 832 working days per 1,000 employees. This was the worst record of any State in Australia during that period. The average annual rate of industrial disputation in Australia over the same period was 675 working days per 1,000 employees. Therefore, under the Liberals, the rate of industrial disputation in Victoria was 23.3 per cent higher than the Australian average. From 1982 to July 1990, under the Cain and Kirner Labor governments, the average annual rate of industrial disputation in Victoria dropped by 76 per cent to 200 days lost per 1,000 employees. This figure is 16 per cent below the Australian average in the same period.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I wonder whether this answer relates to public administration of the Commonwealth. It seems to be a comparison of the records of the last two State governments in Victoria. I do not think the Minister is even making an attempt to bring it back to Commonwealth responsibility.

—The question was clearly within the Minister's portfolio of Industrial Relations, but I have sought advice on the last part of the question, which asked what policies the Federal Government would implement, and therefore I think it is in order.

—Before I was rudely interrupted by an irrelevant interjection I was making the point that this figure is 16 per cent below the Australian average for the same period of 238 working days lost per 1,000 employees- that is, under the Liberals in Victoria, 23.3 per cent above the average; under Labor in Victoria, 16 per cent below the average, with an improvement of 76 per cent under Labor.

ANSWER.PARA: I now turn to the last part of the question asked by Senator Cooney. There has been some commentary--
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

— Thank you, Mr President. There has been some commentary lately that a couple of high profile disputes in Victoria somehow presage an outbreak of industrial lawlessness. Having regard to the figures, that is clearly not true. For example, if Alan Brown, the Leader of the Opposition in Victoria, who is trotting out the old remedies, were to succeed in being in a position to implement his policies, Victoria would impose on itself a significant handicap by again embracing a very high level of industrial disputation. I think the figures show that when one has an accord, as we do, that works so successfully, one can lower the level of industrial disputation and remove that drain on productivity simply because, from an industrial relations point of view, Labor governments do it better.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I remind the Minister of his recent reply to a question I asked about a 30 per cent rise in youth unemployment so far this year, in which he said that the increase in the number of people on unemployment benefit, including the job search allowance (JSA) for 16-to 17-year-olds, had been trending down. Is this still the situation-if it ever was-in view of the page one lead story in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald which reported that the job outlook for the 54,000 school leavers in New South Wales is `grim'; that the official figures show the job slump is continuing, with the number of skilled vacancies dropping to a seven-year low after being halved in the latest 12 months; that next year's apprenticeship intake is being cut by up to 40 per cent; and that major employers, including the Commonwealth Bank, are slashing their intake of school leavers? What level of youth and total unemployment does the Government now expect for this financial year and by how much will the Budget forecast of unemployment benefit and JSA payments now need to be revised upwards?

—Clearly, during the course of the last six weeks in particular, the unemployment situation has worsened, and worsened considerably. I get a weekly report of the increase in the numbers of unemployed, which includes those on the benefits to which the honourable senator referred and everybody else, but I do not have a breakdown of those figures with me. Therefore, I will talk in general terms about those numbers. Unfortunately, they have been rocketing up in the last few weeks. We had 6,000 people in one week going onto unemployment benefit and 4,000 in another week. Those figures show that Victoria is contributing very substantially to the big increase and obviously that is where the worst part of the unemployment rise is.
—What about Western Australia?

—Western Australia is the second biggest contributor to the national figure in percentage terms. Other States are going up in lesser degrees. We must remember that the figure for Victoria is coming off a much lower base, having been by far the most successful State with regard to employment levels during the last six or seven years. It is now clear to me, especially from the figures for the last six weeks, that the figure in the Budget of 475,000 people will be somewhat under the final result. I am not yet able to put a definite figure on it, but certainly the 475,000 yearly average figure will not be enough. I hope to try to get a better gauge on that as we see what happens over Christmas and perhaps give Senator Michael Baume a better estimate when we resume in February.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer to the switching contract recently awarded by Telecom to Alcatel STC Australia. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the likely benefits to Australian industry of this contract and how this fits in with the Government's recently announced strategy for the telecommunications industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The letting of a major switching contract to Alcatel STC places this longstanding manufacturer in a strong position to take advantage of the market opportunities provided by the restructuring of the telecommunications industry announced by the Prime Minister on 8 November. The company is in the process of undertaking substantial investments in new facilities at Liverpool, New South Wales, to provide a modern manufacturing plant for a long term future in this country. It is also recruiting additional engineers, bringing its research and development strength up to about 250 people. Software development for the new exchanges to be built will be undertaken in Australia. Local content will be well in excess of 50 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: Alcatel STC has a proven record in the South East Asian market with annual exports of some $30m. It sees Australian production of switches of the type to be supplied to Telecom as providing the company with a much stronger base on which to build its export markets in the growing market of South East Asia. As I have previously advised the Senate, the restructuring of the telecommunications industry should be seen as a market opportunity. By winning the Telecom contract, Alcatel STC has positioned itself to take advantage of those opportunities which will remain for firms to build on both the Australian and South East Asian markets.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH SCIENTIFIC AND INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH ORGANISATION: KENAF

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I refer the Minister to the work by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) in developing a fibre crop, kenaf, as an alternative to depleting our forests for paper pulp. I also remind the Minister that this crop grows in five to seven months and can be used to produce a wide range of paper products. I ask the Minister: what assistance has the Government provided to the CSIRO to secure sufficient funds to continue its research and development work on the crop? Further, what action has the Government taken to stimulate interest in the commercial production of kenaf?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —For approximately 15 years from the early 1970s, the CSIRO had a very extensive program of research and development of that particular crop. Unfortunately, at the end of that 15 years-which I think ended in about 1984 or 1985-there was precious little interest shown in its commercial production. While I am very reluctant, as my colleagues know, ever to comment outside my portfolio, it would be the case, I think-Senator Button would agree-that when the CSIRO conducts a very long program of that kind, it does have to give serious thought to the commercial end result in that it cannot keep money going into a program if it is not attracting commercial interest.
—We look for them in a lot of places.
—Senator Button and I are in agreement. This is good!
—You are not suggesting it is surprising, are you?

—During the course of that very long research program, the CSIRO continued to promote the use of kenaf. With the Bureau of Rural Resources, it even held a workshop for two days in February this year to encourage its use. It was held in the capital of the honourable senator's home state. The results of the workshop have now been published so they are available on the public record. If the honourable senator does not have a copy of it I will certainly make one available to her.

ANSWER.PARA: In the meantime, the Bureau of Rural Resources in CSIRO will continue in field days and the like around Australia to advertise and promote the use of kenaf and to show off the results of that research. Considering the absence of commercial interest after all these years, I doubt very much whether the Government would have plans to put more money into the research. I think the research has been done, and it is now up to Australian producers to see whether they wish to use it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. Firstly, is the Minister aware of criticism directed at the behaviour of mobile review teams, particularly concerning their alleged failure to inform citizens of their right to refuse entry to their premises by those Department of Social Security (DSS) personnel? Secondly, what procedures should be followed by mobile review teams when visiting citizens at their property or homes? Thirdly, are sole parents particularly targeted by mobile review teams and, if so, is this not a case of targeting people who are amongst the most disadvantaged in Australian society?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —First off, there have been a number of complaints, as Senator Burns would be aware, about the behaviour of mobile review teams. It has to be understood that around the country there are now 60 of those teams in operation. When we have 60 teams going around, it will always be possible that one or two individuals might exceed their authority and be overzealous in the application of their duties. Clearly, this has occurred in only a couple of cases. The Department has taken all possible responsible action to make sure that those officers have been reminded of their responsibilities and do not exceed them.

ANSWER.PARA: It is the case that when a mobile review team approaches the door of any Australian home it is supposed to inform the householder that the interview does not have to take place at that particular moment; it can be held later on at a DSS office. Of course, the householder has the right to refuse entry. There have been complaints that an explanation of those and other rights has not been given, so I have undertaken to have a set of guidelines produced and made publicly available for mobile review teams. The guidelines will include the requirement for personnel to identify themselves to the householder and make sure that a sheet of paper is handed over which does outline all the rights of the householder. That will not completely eliminate the problem, but I hope it goes some way towards doing so.

On the question of concentration on the most disadvantaged group, I think that while some publicity may have attached to mobile review teams looking at sole parents, they are hardly the only ones being looked at. At the moment, of those 60 teams to which I referred, 20 are looking at unemployment benefits, 10 at long term unemployment benefits, eight at sole parent benefits, nine at public information, five at sickness benefits, five smaller teams are reviewing payments of all types, and three are follow-up teams. In fact, only a very small number of the teams are looking at sole parents, so it should not be suggested that the most disadvantaged group is in some way being singled out or picked on; rather, it is being reviewed in just the same way as we are reviewing all of our other kinds of benefits.

I hope that the percentage of cases being reviewed continues. These reviews have shown we can actually make very considerable savings. In 1989-90 nearly two million reviews were carried out, not just by mobile review teams but by other officers as well. In the course of those, there was a cancellation rate of 6.2 per cent-122,000 benefits were cancelled-and over 7 per cent were varied downwards. This continued targeting and making sure that in so far as possible fraud is minimised means that many millions of dollars are being recouped from those who are not entitled to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I remind him of the Prime Minister's refusal to release to the Australian Capital Territory Government funds held in trust by the Federal Government for the ACT Government to assist in restructuring the hospital system. I also remind the Minister that the restructuring of the hospital system arose from a report of Dr Brendan Kearney. The report was written for the Federal Government and accepted by it. What is the basis for the Prime Minister's refusal to accept that the proposed rationalisation of ACT hospital services will produce long term cost savings for the ACT and, therefore, comes within the criteria under which moneys from the transitional funding trust account are payable?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Reid was kind enough to give me notice of this question and I sought information on that basis. I am advised that this question misses the point because release of funds from the trust account is not only on the basis of whether the project will produce long term savings. Mr Kaine's request was rejected because it failed two criteria: firstly, the projects concerned were not of exceptional quality; and, secondly, alternative funding is available. The present Grants Commission inquiry into ACT finances is likely to confirm that the ACT is substantially overfunded relative to the other States. It is, therefore, vital that the funds in the trust account be available to assist in what is likely to be a difficult transition to State-like funding over the next two years. The trust fund should not be used for projects that are unlikely to assist significantly in that transition. In this crucial aspect, the projects nominated by Mr Kaine are not exceptional.

ANSWER.PARA: Another consideration in the decision was that it is clear from the 1990-91 ACT Budget Papers that alternative funding in the form of loan raising is available. The net borrowing estimates made allowance for the need to finance these projects within the ACT global borrowing limit, which makes a mockery of Mr Kaine's claim that he will need to raise taxes and charges as a result of the Government's decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to an interview on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio in Brisbane yesterday afternoon with the former Premier of Queensland, Mr Mike Ahern, on the subject of the proposed spaceport at Cape York. In that interview-which I was able to hear-Mr Ahern recounted the details of a conversation he had with the Minister in this way, `So I said to John Button, ``What-d'ya reckon, John, is it a goer? Is it viable?'' Whereupon John said: ``Yeah, I think so''.' On what evidence does the Minister base this speculation, considering it was at the same time that the National Aeronautical and Space Administration was concluding that the commercial future of satellite technology was in fact very shaky? Is this the way such important decisions are usually made or have they improved since Mr Wayne Goss came to power?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly had a phone conversation with Mr Ahern, but I would like to make it clear that he phoned me; I did not phone him. This is clearly one of these `Dear John' telephone conversations. I have no doubt that I said something like that. Mr Ahern, probably two months ago, approached me on the basis that he had been approached to chair a company, put together a consortium or something of that kind, to look at the spaceport proposal.

ANSWER.PARA: I was asked by him, in either the terms that Senator Kernot quotes or in other terms, whether I thought the spaceport was a viable possibility. My answer to that question, to Mr Ahern and publicly, was yes, subject-as I have said on a number of occasions-to an appropriate environmental impact statement and to addressing some concerns of Aboriginal communities over the nominated site.

During the course of the development of the spaceport concept there were a number of hurdles which had to be overcome. There was an economic hurdle about the potential viability of the spaceport, which I believe to have been overcome by agreement to use Soviet rockets. When it was agreed that Soviet rockets could be used, it then became a question with the Americans whether they would be happy with that course and for United Technologies, an American company, to participate in the management of the spaceport. That hurdle was overcome by discussions conducted by Senator Gareth Evans and others with the Americans.

Only two weeks ago people from United Technologies were here. They must be regarded as significant experts in world terms about these matters. They are enthusiastic about the spaceport proposal and regard it as a commercial oppor- tunity. Of course, there are numerous advantages associated with the Queensland site, particularly its closeness to the equator.

The deficiency at the moment in having a commercial spaceport proposal proceed in Queensland is the availability of reliable commercial consortia who might proceed with the spaceport proposal. I do not know whether Mr Ahern's consortium is in that position; certainly he sought reassurance from me in that phone conversation on the issues which the honourable senator referred to. It remains to be seen whether his consortium will find my advice palatable in terms of commercial realities.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, Senator Richardson. Senator Tate, I am sorry.
—So am I.

—I am sure that the Minister can cope. Is the Minister aware of a letter sent by an officer of the Department of Community Services and Health to the Chairman of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal which quoted a legal opinion designed to influence the Tribunal in the conduct of its duties? Is he also aware that the Chairman of the Tribunal considered the letter objectionable, lacking in courtesy and unsound in law? As the Tribunal is an independent body, can the Minister assure the Senate that no further pressure will be placed on the Tribunal and that it will be allowed to carry out its statutory duty? If the Minister is unaware of the letter, does he intend to take disciplinary action against the responsible officer of the Department of Community Services and Health?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of some allegation that there was an apparently discourteous letter sent from an officer to the Chairman of the Tribunal. I do not have a copy in the brief but I will undertake to table that at the end of Question Time. I am quite happy to make that public and available to the Senate because I do not believe it would do any more than convey what are the facts, that is, the Tribunal should undertake its statutory duty. But the question is: what duty has the Parliament conferred on it in this particular regard?

ANSWER.PARA: As I understand it, the legislation now provides that, where the Government and the Pharmacy Guild of Australia have reached an agreement on pharmacists' remuneration, the Tribunal must make a determination to give effect to the agreement. The agreement between the Commonwealth and the Guild was signed on 23 November 1990, and on the same day both parties sought a determination from the Tribunal. Senator Walters is quite right: the Tribunal ought to carry out its statutory functions and duties, but it is the contention of the parties to that agreement-the Government and the Pharmacy Guild of Australia-that its statutory duty is to implement that agreement.

It is in that way that the Government has sought that determination rather than the usual public inquiry route, for example, and I believe that that is what is probably sought to be conveyed in the letter to which I have referred and which, in any case, I will have tabled at the end of Question Time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. When the Minister tables the letter sent by the Department to the Tribunal, will he also table the letter that the Tribunal sent to the Department, because very obviously the objection was to the discourteous, unsound and objectionable tone, and the point that the Tribunal was making was that its statutory obligation is to still sit?
—If there was a reply from the Chairman of the Tribunal I will seek his permission as to whether it might be tabled in the Senate.

—Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade aware of the United States Senate's condemnation earlier this year in a motion by Senator Gordon Humphrey and Senator Edward Kennedy of the People's Republic of China's (PRC's) `coercive population policies, including the use of forced abortion and forced sterilisation'? Is the Minister aware of evidence from Tibet that these brutal policies are being inflicted by the PRC on women in that country? As this is the last day for debate on the Appropriation Bills, when can I expect from the Minister the promised written response to the questions that I asked at Estimates hearings both last year and this year concerning his Department's monitoring of, and actions concerning, human rights violations associated with population control programming?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that I was specifically aware of the Senate resolution to which he refers sponsored by Edward Kennedy or the specific matters relating to Tibet. I am, of course, generally aware of the nature of Senator Harradine's concerns about population policies and their implementation in China. That has been the subject of considerable discussion both in Estimates committees and more briefly in the Committee of the Whole.

ANSWER.PARA: I am concerned that Senator Harradine should have a properly considered reply to his concerns on these matters, with as much data as we can compile. That considered response is not yet on my desk so far as I am aware, so I am unable to make any commitment to have it available to him later today. All I can say again is that I will do so as soon as possible.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware that there were over 16,030 bankruptcies in the last financial year, an increase of 17.6 per cent? Those figures are made up of 7,394 public companies which went into receivership and 8,636 small businesses and personal bankruptcies. The Minister stated in an answer yesterday to Senator Hill:

QUESTION.PARA: In terms of small size business in this country, any environment policy induced by this Government has been compounded again and again by the behaviour of the banks . . .

Does the Minister still give the same answer today, or will he accept some of the responsibility on behalf of the Government for the destruction of many small businesses by the Government's crude singular economic tool of high interest rates and, in light of today's figures, the Government's hopeless management of the economy?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is one of those questions which are mixed with rhetoric--
—And fact-and truth.

—And a bit of fact and a bit of misrepresentation. The implication of Senator Boswell's question is that yesterday in the Senate I blamed the banks for the situation of small business in this country. I do not, in this sense: time and time again, as honourable senators opposite would know if they read their Hansards, Ministers have said that the high interest rate regime creates difficulties for small business.
—Boy, penetrating!

—It is penetrating, but it took a long time to penetrate Senator Crichton-Browne's head and, clearly, Senator Boswell's. I said that the adverse effects of that policy on small business had been compounded by the behaviour of the banks-not replaced by the behaviour of the banks but compounded, made worse, by it. I will have to go on for months and months if I have to get it through the thick head of Senator Boswell that that is a matter of reality. I get letter after letter day after day from small business people in this country complaining about the banks.
—Complaining about your Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 August 1990 Senator Watson asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question relating to alleged anomalies in the Australian Taxation Office. The answer to that question is very long. I table the answer and seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-
The matter to which the honourable senator refers relates to the treatment of bad debts under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936.

Under the income tax law bad debts may be claimed as deductions under either of two provisions of the Act. One is a specific provision dealing with bad debts, section 63, and the other is the general deductions provision, section 51.

Firstly, the specific provision itself sets out two bases for deducting bad debts. Pursuant to paragraph 63 (1) (a) a debt which has, during the income year, been written off as a bad debt, will be allowable as a deduction if it has already been brought to account as assessable income in any year. Pursuant to paragraph 63 (1) (b), a bad debt will also be deductible if it is incurred in respect of money lent in the ordinary course of a money lending business.

Alternatively, a deduction may be allowed under the general deductions provision, subsection 51 (1), where the bad debt is necessarily incurred in carrying on a business for the purpose of gaining or producing assessable income to the extent that it is not a capital loss or of a capital, domestic or private nature.

In the circumstances outlined by the Honourable Senator, two distinct debts may arise as bad debts. The first is the non-receipt of interest which may have accrued on a fixed interest security, and the second is the inability to recover the full amount invested in the security. To illustrate the operation of the provisions to the nonreceipt of both interest and the underlying investment, I will refer to three different categories of taxpayers-individuals, organisations carrying on the business of money lending, and other businesses bringing income to account under the accruals method of tax accounting.

Firstly, an individual who deposits funds in a fixed interest security clearly makes a capital investment. In general, unless the accruals method applies under division 16E of the Act, it is only when interest is actually paid or credited on the security that it will form part of the assessable income of that person. Accordingly, where a debtor institution is unable to meet its liability to pay interest on the security no amount will generally have been assessed to the individual investor. Consequently, there is neither an amount which has been brought to account as assessable income by the individual taxpayer in terms of paragraph 63 (1) (a) nor a loss or outgoing incurred in gaining assessable income in terms of subsection 51 (1). Therefore, no deduction is allowable in respect of the nonreceipt of interest income.

The return of an individual's capital outlay for an investment can never be assessed as income. As no amount will be brought to account as income the operation of paragraph 63 (1) (a) is quite irrelevant. As to subsection 51 (1), failure by the debtor institution to ultimately repay an individual's capital investment would amount to a loss but such a loss is one of capital and not deductible. However, that loss will be one which may be offset against any capital gains derived by the taxpayer in terms of the capital gains and losses provisions of the Act.

Secondly, where an organisation carrying on a business of money lending invests in a fixed interest security in the ordinary course of its business, the failure of the debtor institution to repay both the amount invested and the interest on the security will give rise to both amounts being deductible under paragraph 63 (1) (b). That is how the full Federal Court determined the provision applied in F.C. of T. v. National Commercial Banking Corporation of Australia Ltd in 1983. The same amounts are also likely to be deductible under subsection 51 (1).

Finally, any investment by an accruals taxpayer (other than a money lender) in a fixed interest security will usually be on capital account. Any failure by the debtor institution to pay interest on the security will be deductible under paragraph 63 (1) (a) where the taxpayer has already brought that amount to account. So far as the failure to repay the amount invested is concerned, that amount will be treated in the same way as for individuals and be regarded as a capital loss which may be used to offset capital gains for the purposes of the capital gains and losses provisions of the Act.

In addition, drivers over the age of 45 years with more than 10 years service were offered, in the calculation of their severance pay--
—Mr President, either there is something wrong with the amplification or the Minister is mumbling; it is impossible to hear him from this side of the chamber.

—Mr President, I will start the answer again. Comcar drivers have been offered the standard APS redundancy payment of two weeks severance pay for every year of service to a maximum of 48 weeks pay, plus 3 1/2 times their superannuation contribution. In addition, drivers over the age of 45 years with more than 10 years service were offered, in the calculation of their severance pay, their average overtime for the past two years, provided that the overtime average was more than 40 per cent of their base wages in each of those two years. ANSWER.PARA: The second question was whether the retirement offer must be made to all Comcar drivers. The retirement offer was made to all drivers in conformity with the policy of the Department of Administrative Services in relation to redundancies deriving from downsizing. It must be recognised that the retirement offers are part of the restructuring process for Comcar, which is designed to enable those staff who are--

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you downsize by replacing people?
—No one can downsize Senator Baume. He was downsized when he was found at the bottom of the harbour. It is designed to enable those staff who are unable to cope--
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I require that that offensive and untrue remark be withdrawn. It is typical of the Minister.
—Order! I did not hear any remark. If, however, Senator Bolkus made an unparliamentary remark, I will ask him to withdraw it.

—Mr President, all I said was that he was downsized when he was found at the bottom of the harbour. I do not know what is offensive about that. If you want me to say that he was not downsized at the bottom of the harbour--

—Mr President, I raise a further point of order. The Minister's deliberate repetition of the offensive remark is in fact a deliberate attempt to get around the thrust and purpose of the Standing Orders and is a typical smart alec, offensive remark from this offensive Minister.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

But due to a delay in the Hansard becoming available, several honourable senators wished to have access to a tape of the hearing. SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, I ask you under what authority can the chairman of a committee attempt to deprive other honourable senators and members and, for that matter, the deputy chairman of access to Hansard tapes. Why are honourable senators prevented from listening to a tape of evidence given to the world at large at a public meeting?
