DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Short proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government to acknowledge that Australia is in recession and to take the actions necessary to address this situation and the hardship it is causing all Australians.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In Question Time today in response to Senator Hill's question, `Is Australia in a recession?', the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, gave the first honest and clear answer from the Government on the economy in a long time-but only because he had no alternative. His answer was yes. What staggers me is that, on a day when the most serious economic statistics to greet this nation for many, many years are released, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, the third most senior Minister in the Government, has refused to participate in this debate. Indeed, the debate is being carried on the Government's side not by a Minister, not by a spokesman of the Executive Government, but by Senator Walsh.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walsh was an eminent member of the Hawke Government last time around, but Senator Walsh chose for reasons very understandable to resign. Those reasons were essentially because he violently disagreed with the Government's economic policies and he could not get his way in Cabinet to exercise responsible economic policies. That is the person today-he is no spokesman for the Government-who is carrying the candle for the Government in this debate. I find that incredible. I really cannot believe it, other than to say it is yet another example of the continuing and increasing arrogance of this Government towards the Parliament of Australia and, therefore, towards every Australian.

That is the reason why the Government has lied to the Australian people for months and months over the state of the economy. This economy is in recession. Statistical evidence and anecdotal evidence-every sort of evidence which has been coming to the Government and to the Australian people for months-has made it patently obvious that the economy is in recession. Indeed, today's national accounts figures, showing a fall in gross domestic product in this nation of 1.6 per cent for the September quarter, confirm what everyone except the Government seemingly already knew; that is, that we have been in recession for a year. The first paragraph of the official publication today says, in the explanation:

Gross domestic product (GDP) declined in September quarter 1990 by 1.6 per cent in constant price seasonally adjusted terms, to be 0.7 per cent lower than in September quarter 1989. This is the first occasion since June quarter 1983 that seasonally adjusted constant price GDP has been lower than in the corresponding quarter of the previous year.

So if ever confirmation were needed that this economy has been in recession for a year, there it is from the Government's official statistical spokesman, the Australian Statistician. Indeed, the national accounts figures show that for three of the last four quarters there has been negative growth in the economy. It was only in the March quarter that we got some positive growth. The decline in gross domestic product (GDP) in the statistics today would have been even worse-and it is bad enough as it is-if the Government had not been out there pump-priming the economy in various old-fashioned, past generation, Keynesian ways.

If one looks at the statistics, the impact on the private sector of the Government's policies is staggering. Private consumption expenditure rose in the last two quarters by only one-half of one per cent. In the September quarter alone, government consumption spending increased by no less than 3.2 per cent in real terms. Look at capital expenditure. Total private capital expenditure was flat in the September quarter after falls of 5 per cent, 2 per cent and 5 per cent again in the three preceding quarters. Indeed, private capital expenditure in the September quarter was down 10.9 per cent on the September quarter of a year earlier. What has happened to public expenditure? Public expenditure by government is up by a massive 10.8 per cent. Total public expenditure was up in the September quarter by 5 1/2 per cent, and over the year to the September quarter of last year it rose even more, by 5.7 per cent.

What has been happening in this recessed economy is that the Government has been taking action which has made the private sector even more recessed, and it has disguised the true magnitude of the recession that is in the private sector. We talk about a technical recession today. A technical recession is said to be a recession where there have been two consecutive quarter falls in GDP. That is just a technical definition. We all know that the recession has been with us for a long time. We did not need to look at technical statistics.

One has to ask the question whether recession is the right word, given the state of the economy and looking at the statistics over the last 12 months. We are getting to the stage where the more appropriate word is probably depression, and the statistics we have seen confirm that. Why did the Government not know we were in recession? Of course it knew. It has known it for months and months, and for purely political purposes it has consistently refused to acknowledge it.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and other Government Ministers have said repeatedly that we are not in a recession. On 22 March 1990 in Adelaide, during the recent election, the Treasurer said:
We won't let there be a recession.
On the same day in Brisbane the Prime Minister said:
There is no need to fear a recession in any sense.

What is significant about 22 March 1990? It was the Thursday before the general election of 24 March. The Prime Minister and the Treasurer made those statements on that day, in the face of mounting concern from the electorate, for one reason only: to mislead and deliberately lie to the Australian public in advance of the election that was to take place.

Businesses have closed, tens of thousands of people have gone bankrupt-16,000 bankruptcies in the last 12 months-and hundreds of thousands of people have lost their jobs because the Government has refused to change its policy direction, has refused to acknowledge the facts, has not been able to see for itself what the real world is like and has not been out there to see what the real world is like. The cost of this arrogant, blinkered approach has been tragic in economic terms but even more tragic in human terms. The human cost of this engineered recession-engineered because the Government has been playing politics with this economy for at least the last three years-is immense. I believe that the Australian voting public will never forget and forgive what has been done to them during that period.

It could all have been averted if the Government had acted sooner. The situation in Australia is made even more tragic by the fact that we have been in a recession over the last 12 months-it was building before that-at a time when world economic trade has been experiencing the longest ever growth period in history. The difficulties we face are compounded by our recession coming at a time when growth has been on the up in the world economy, although we are now seeing a world economy which is starting to slow down very dramatically. That has extremely grave implications for our external trading position and our economic situation generally.

TALK.START.PARA: —Commodity prices.

—As Senator Crichton- Browne said, commodity prices are under great pressure. The present position with our balance of payments is such that, even were there to be a dramatic improvement in our trading position, as a result of the policies of this Government we have built up a foreign debt of $154 billion, on which the interest payments are between $18 billion and $20 billion a year. So we have an enormous in-built problem-the greatest problem we have ever had on our external accounts-which is virtually intractable. If we do not make a start on correcting that today, that debt situation shows every prospect of causing a fall in our living standards, the like of which we have never seen.

SPEECH.PARA: While all that is going on, the Treasurer is running around painting the economic statistics of recent months as a beautiful set of figures. I will bet that he did not go running out to where my office is located at Brunswick in Melbourne, or even to his own office-if he knows where it is-in the western suburbs of Sydney saying that he had a beautiful set of figures, because the people being thrown out of work hour by hour as a result of the Treasurer's policies, the people closing their businesses day by day as a result of his policies and the youth forced on to the streets as a result of his policies would have lynched him; and so they should have. As late as last month, the Treasurer said:
The economy is slowing but not precipitously.

The Treasurer's scorched earth policy had arrived long before that. It was the policy of a Treasurer who had been unable to see that quite clearly, even on his own definition of a recession, we were in a recession. In May of this year, at a press conference on the March quarterly consumer price index figures, the Treasurer said:
Rapidly mounting unemployment, business failures and people trying to sell assets when they can't. This sort of thing. All the classic conditions of recession which we've not seen yet, not seen now.

I do not know where the Treasurer was looking. Over the last 12 months we have seen an increase of 160,000 in the number of people thrown out of work through the policies of this Government. At the end of October 1990, 650,000 were unemployed in this country. At the end of October 1989, 490,000 people were unemployed. That is an increase of 160,000 people.

Employment has been falling and bankruptcies have been rising. Senator Richardson admitted today in the Senate that employment will get a lot worse. We do not need Senator Richardson to tell us that. We just have to talk to anyone in the private sector. If we talk to the car manufacturers, if we could get through the acres and acres of cars in their yards that they cannot sell, the metal manufacturers, the retailers or anyone who is engaged in productive employment and productive retailing-anything to do with the work side of industry-they will tell us that this country will go down a lot more before it starts to go up.

Although the Government cannot tell us what is around the corner, the Prime Minister has tried to tell us in the last few days that the indications are that production and employment will certainly rise in 1991. Who on earth will believe this Prime Minister and his Treasurer, who have got it absolutely wrong every year for the last eight years in calling the economic shots as to what would happen in the future?

At least in this chamber Senator Button has had a little more honesty than have the Prime Minister and the Treasurer. He said some time ago that the high interest rate policy of this Government-and it is a high interest rate policy because of the inability of the Government to adopt a mixture of policies that are appropriate to the needs of our economy-was forcing `a reduction in manufacturing capacity in Australia'. He went on:
I hope profoundly that we are hanging on to the best but there will be some good ones which disappear. There is no doubt about that and that concerns me.

Yesterday, Senator Button admitted that the Government had made things difficult for business as a `result of earlier policy decisions'. Senator Button either lacked the courage to come in here to debate this issue or, I rather suspect, knew that the recession was coming, has given up on his Prime Minister and his Treasurer, and has taken the decision not to come and defend these figures-because they are indefensible. That is why today the Leader of the Government in the Senate is not in this chamber, although in Canberra, for this very important debate.

We did not need today's national accounts figures, dramatic though they are, to tell us that we are in recession. A whole host of other statistical indicators over recent months have shown this. Bankruptcies are up 32 per cent over the past year; unemployment has been rising for a year to a figure now of 650,000 people. As Senator Michael Baume pointed out in Question Time today, as he has been doing so diligently for months, the situation in youth unemployment is even worse.

The ANZ job vacancies have fallen dramatically over the course of this financial year. The Australian Bureau of Statistics job vacancies fell last year by 15 per cent. In August of this year-the latest available figure-the number of vacancies was 25 per cent less than a year earlier. We have seen, with the balance of payments figures yesterday, no improvement of any consequence at all. Indeed, if one looks at the underlying figures in the balance of payments, one sees that things have got worse: absolutely flat exports; imports-at a time when the Treasurer's restrictive engineered recession effects should be slowing imports-up by 8 per cent; and in the September quarter a negative turnaround in our trade position of $1 billion.

The debt figure has continued to escalate. The debt figures for the end of September released yesterday were $156.3 billion gross, $124.5 billion net. They are the second highest figures ever recorded. They would have been $1 billion higher, except for the favourable exchange rate effects on the way in which the figures are calculated.

Building approvals have been falling dramatically. Manufacturing production and investment are down. Dwelling commencements are down. Revenues from the prescribed payments system, as we saw in recent days, are down dramatically because of a decline in the construction industry.

One would have known all these things simply by looking at the national press. I do not normally quote the national press in support of argumentation, but for the last six months it has been telling us what has been happening to the economy. On 20 June 1990, in the Age: `Consumer confidence falls to new low'; 1 October: `Commercial, industrial property at 35-year low'; and 2 October: `No doubts about rural recession'.

The Government should have listened to the person who should be the next leader of the Australian Labor Party in this country, that is, John Kerin, because on 8 October this was reported: `Worse than '82: Kerin's grim news'. On 10 October leading businessman Arvi Parbo was reported as saying, `Pick-up in economy not likely'. Only yesterday the Chairman of the ANZ bank and one of the leading businessmen in Australia, Milton Bridgland, said that this last year was probably the harshest economic environment for medium and small businesses in Australia since World War II.

The situation facing Australia today is one of deep recession. The great tragedy is that the Government has consistently refused to acknowledge that. It has, therefore, delayed taking the policy measures that are required to even start getting this country on the right track again. I urge the Government-and perhaps today's dramatic figures will force the Government-to adopt the mini-Budget that it should have adopted months ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps if the Government were to accept Senator Short's exhortation to bring in a mini-Budget and we brought in a mini-Budget with a savings measure by asset testing, at a very generous level, certain education and social security allowances, the Opposition might allow that part of the mini-Budget to pass, instead of throwing it out, as it will do in the next week or two. Of course, that is typical of this Opposition-humbug, hypocrisy and double standards.

SPEECH.PARA: The motion that has been put up today falls into two parts. Technically, it is not a motion: the matter for discussion falls into two parts. Firstly--(Quorum formed) Senator Short, on behalf of the Opposition, was advocating a mini-Budget, which is Opposition shorthand for a list of expenditure cuts. There will be a list of expenditure cuts presented to the Senate within the next week or two. One of those expenditure cuts-or savings, as the Department of Finance normally calls them-is to apply a very generous asset test to education and some social security allowances. What is Senator Short going to do when that mini-mini-Budget comes into the Senate? He is going to move a motion on behalf of the Opposition to amend the Government's proposition and throw $57m a year worth of savings right out of the window. That gives us some indication of just how serious this Opposition is about pursuing a mini-Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the pipeline?

—And $700m for the pipeline. Seven hundred million dollars in asset sales-or what, in the jargon of the Department of Finance, is referred to as negative outlays-will also be thrown out of the window by the Opposition, in collaboration of course with the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter which has been submitted for discussion falls into two parts. Firstly, it states:
The failure of the Government to acknowledge that Australia is in recession . . .
The second part states:
. . . to take the actions necessary to address this situation . . .

Of course, in the first part the assertion is unambiguously wrong. I am not just talking about Senator Button having said at Question Time earlier today that the economy is in recession. Mr Willis-I do not remember the exact date, but it was about three months ago-on one of the Sunday morning television programs said, `We are probably right now, technically, in a recession'. The figures that were released today verified Mr Willis's judgment, a technical recession being two consecutive quarters when estimated gross domestic product (GDP) was negative.

The Opposition got that wrong. It got the most simple statement of fact in its matter for discussion wrong. It is more a question of opinion as to whether any actions are being taken or what actions should be taken. One thing which is not a matter of opinion is that no positive suggestions were put up by the Opposition about what the policy response to this technical recession or recession or whatever anybody wants to call it should be, other than to bring in a mini-Budget with a list of expenditure cuts when the expenditure cuts already being proposed by the Government are going to be thrown out of the Senate by the Opposition, in collaboration with the Democrats.

The Opposition even rolled its own new leader on this issue. Nothing has really changed in the Opposition. It might have a more presentable leader-in my opinion, it certainly does have a more presentable leader than it has had within my lifetime, probably, and certainly within my memory-but nothing has really changed. When it comes to the crunch, the shots are still called by the National Party. This present Liberal Party is as craven a lackey and puppet of the National Party as was the Liberal Party of Menzies, of Gorton, of Holt, of McMahon and of Fraser. Underneath, nothing has changed.

Senator Short was having another whinge because I am speaking in this debate. Naturally, I do not apologise for speaking in this debate, and I observe in passing that I have more spare time these days than I used to and I know how little spare time Senator Button would have. I want publicly to endorse Senator Button's judgment that his time can be more productively occupied doing his ministerial duties in his office or wherever else he is doing them than it is listening to humbug and cant from the Opposition and exhortations to the Government to produce a mini-Budget when the Opposition is going to throw out the mini-Budget that has already been produced.

The Opposition's delight at the figures which have been released today-it believes that it has finally been given a feather to fly with, and it has not had too many-is ill-concealed. But I think a few aberrations about the figures should be noted. Some of them could be classified as providing some grounds for optimism and some are probably not as clear. The first point is that there has been a run-down of stocks by almost $1 billion. When an economy is moving into recession it is usual for there to be an accumulation of stocks rather than a run-down of stocks. If stocks are accumulating at the same time that demand is falling off and an economy is moving into recession, that constitutes an overhang which will make it more difficult to come out of recession. The position that we are in now, according to the figures released today, is that stocks are running down quite significantly, so in the context of the prospects of recovery from recession that is a good sign.

The statistics on imports, when the June quarter is juxtaposed with the September quarter, have to be suspect. These statistics show that there was a 9 per cent decline in imports during the June quarter and an 8 per cent increase in imports during the September quarter. There are some one-off factors that boosted the September quarter imports-principally the import of aircraft-but it is improbable that two movements of that magnitude in opposite directions between one quarter and another are both correct. It is very likely that one or both of those figures will subsequently be revised. In other words, it is likely-as it is always likely-that there will be some revision to the bottom line on gross domestic product growth or negative growth in this quarter.

If one looks at changes over six-monthly periods or, better still, a 12-monthly period and disaggregates the figures which collectively produce the bottom line of 1.6 per cent negative real growth, again one can see some positive signs. Over the 12-month period gross domestic product-and gross national product, for that matter-has grown at a significantly better rate than gross national expenditure. That means that net exports are making a significant contribution to economic growth. Indeed, over the 12-month period the growth attributable to net exports was equivalent to almost 2 per cent of GDP-that is, for the September quarter compared with the September quarter last year. That sort of structural change must take place sooner or later in the Australian economy.

However, like Senator Button, like the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his press statement today and like Mr Willis, I am not pretending that the present economic situation will not cause problems for quite a number of people. In that sort of situation I think it is incumbent on anybody who purports to take a serious interest in it to try to analyse what has happened to produce this situation and to think about prospective changes that could be made which might ameliorate it. We did not get too much of that from the Opposition.

What has happened? To get to the starting point of the snapshot of the economy which was published today, one has to go back about two years-I have admitted this before as Minister for Finance and in the Senate-when there was a serious underestimate by the Government and by just about everybody else of the strength of demand. Therefore, imports and the current account deficit blew out in the 1988-89 financial year to a level that the Government had not anticipated.

In that situation, fuelled partly by an investment boom, the appropriate response, as the Government saw it, was to restrict total demand in order to reduce the alarmingly high current account deficit that was looming. That was done, and the mechanism which was chosen, for a variety of reasons, was to tighten monetary policy. Legitimate criticism could probably be made of that decision to hose down total demand by tightening monetary policy. An alternative is to tighten fiscal policy-in other words, increase the size of the surplus-which would also have the effect of dampening demand, although probably not in a one-to-one ratio.

We have already touched on that response, of course. Tightening fiscal policy means either increasing taxation or reducing expenditure. When the Government puts up propositions to do that, as likely as not, those propositions will be knocked off by the very people who have the effrontery to turn up here today and say, `The Government should have done something different from what we would have allowed it to do if it had tried to do it'.

Let us come to the effects of the tightening of monetary policy. Firstly, it took longer than anybody had anticipated for the effects of high interest rates to make a substantial impact on total demand, and the final effects of that tight monetary policy have been aggravated by some unbelievably imprudent and irresponsible lending by banks in the past. Senator Button very rightly touched on this yesterday. Until quite recently-indeed, until it became incontrovertible public fact-I would not have believed that Australian mainstream banks, leaving some of the spivvy fringe operators out of it, would have lent hundreds of millions of dollars on no mortgage security whatsoever, and in many cases without even asking the paper entrepreneurs who were borrowing the money how many hundreds of millions of dollars they owed to other financial institutions. I would not have believed, until it became a matter of public record, that that was possible.

In the five minutes that is left to me I want to make an observation about the Democrats. I will have to anticipate Senator Spindler's speech, but I anticipate that it will be full of pathos, empathy and sympathy for people who will be affected by the recession. That is fair enough; I think all of us would endorse those sentiments. But what makes it so inappropriate coming from the Democrats is that, when people have their incomes reduced or, at worst, lose their jobs, that will be a function of negative economic growth which occurred in the last quarter and the quarter before it. As I understand it, negative economic growth is one of the Democrats' objectives. The Democrats actually believe in negative economic growth. Indeed, if I have understood them correctly, they say that it is absolutely essential, if we are to survive on this planet, that there be negative economic growth.

So before we have too much humbug and hypocrisy from the people who sit at the end of the corridor about how terrible it is that people will suffer from this recession, let us remember that if Democrat policies were ever to be implemented that is only a little taste of what people can expect. It will not be just a limited section of the population which will be affected; it will be the whole lot-with the exception of those new class spongers who have managed somehow or other to fasten themselves onto the public tit. Everybody else will have their living standards reduced. I predict that the humbug and cant of the Democrats will be even more spectacular than the humbug and cant of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret that I will not be able to fulfil Senator Walsh's expectations. I do not suggest that negative economic growth at this time is what the community and the economy should be aiming for. We should be setting the scene for a sustainable economy in the years to come so that we do not sell our non-renewable resources simply to survive. Nor should we sell them, as Senator Walsh seems to imply, just so that we can run two or three cars and a boat and have two houses and use up all the resources which this country offers but which are not renewable and which we are exhausting at a fast rate.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter of public importance presented by Senator Short today relates to the Government's failure to acknowledge that Australia is in recession and also to its failure to take the actions necessary to address the situation and to consider the hardship it is causing all Australians. The first leg of that challenge was in fact met by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, when, earlier in Question Time, he acknowledged that indeed Australia, by that measure of two quarters of negative growth, is officially in recession. I regret that Senator Short did not address the second leg to any great extent. I found few, if any, suggestions as to the effective action which should be taken to address this situation.

I intend to address a good part of my speech to that question. In the situation in which we find ourselves, rather than criticising the Government for sending in a speaker who is not currently the Minister responsible for this portfolio, we should be addressing the measures that can and should be taken to redress the deplorable position that we are in when increasing numbers of people are without jobs.

The September quarter result was particularly bad for the Government and indeed for Australia since a drop of 1.6 per cent is fairly substantial. An interesting point is that the June quarter negative result was actually revised downwards from 0.9 to 0.5. So, in a sense, the Government was a little unlucky in its statistics. With an expenditure of an extra billion dollars on public works, it might have avoided the quarter negative growth that it experienced in June. But that, of course, is no comfort to those who have already lost their jobs or to those who are now facing losing them.

The employment figure certainly supports the fact that Australia is in recession. Since July the number of people employed in Australia has dropped by almost 65,000. Unemployment paints an even bleaker picture. In October 1989, 457,400 people were unemployed in Australia. That figure rose to 569,300 in July and to 607,700 in October. This is indeed a most disturbing trend. The Government should tell us its predictions for unemployment given that the Budget estimate has already been exceeded. There is no doubt that the Budget estimate of 2 per cent growth in gross domestic product for 1991 has been discredited by today's result.

Today the shadow Treasurer called for further cuts in public expenditure. That is a measure of the irresponsibility that the Opposition brings to this situation and to this debate. The reason the Great Depression deepened in 1930-31 was that the Scullin Government accepted the view from London and from the infamous Mr Gibson, the then Chairman of the Commonwealth Bank, to cut public outlays. We all know the result of that policy-massive hardship.

Now is the time to increase public spending to counter the social costs which arise because of the recession. But it is a not only a matter of increasing public outlays to alleviate some of the social disadvantage that is the result of the Government's monetary policy; it is also a matter of spending money strategically to achieve improvements in our economic performance.

From the position that we find ourselves in, it is clear that we are reaping the results of several years of deregulation and reliance on markets. Our governments, both State and Federal, have abdicated their responsibility to the market. In some ways, although fairly late, it is pleasing to see that certain sectors of the private enterprise part of our economy agree that maybe this was not the road to travel, despite the fact that the Opposition parties supported it, and in fact are still claiming that deregulation, privatisation and exposure to markets have not gone far enough. Mr Ian Campbell, Chief Economist of the AMP Society, in the economic notes for the September quarter 1990, states:

. . . deregulation and exposure to market competition, which have been confidently put forward as the answers to economic mismanagement, don't seem to be leading us to utopia either. Such a situation opens the way to widespread cynicism, and that prospect must be alarming to anyone with the wellbeing of the nation at heart.

The worst of it is that this strategy of high interest rates has not assisted us in reducing our overseas borrowing since our foreign debt is now climbing rapidly well above the $120 billion mark and going towards $130 billion. Unfortunately, that money was not borrowed for productive enterprises but for paper shuffling takeovers.

We see the Government standing by and not doing anything to increase our export and manufacturing capacity. Even in the current batch of legislation coming before us we see penny pinching in the export market development grants. A recent article in the Australian documented the failure to gear up our partnership for development program, which we are now prepared to let go in contrast to France, Germany, Japan and the United States of America, which are not afraid to support their industries and primary producers.

The Australian Democrats believe that the Government must take steps to intervene strategically. We believe that the suggestion put forward by the Australian Manufacturing Council to engage in accelerated depreciation allowances on large scale industrial projects destined for exports should be taken up. We believe that tariff reductions should be reviewed and that they certainly should be treated selectively. However, apart from these sorts of measures, we believe that we should also look very carefully at our own capacity and at how it can be increased.

Here I turn to our science and technology capacity. I refer to a question that Democrat senator John Coulter asked recently of Senator Button. It demonstrated very clearly that the sort of technology that enables solar powered cars to race across the continent will be produced and utilised in Spain, even though it was developed in Australia. Clearly we do not have the scientific infrastructure to enable us to utilise the fruits of our scientists; not that we treat our scientists with any deal of respect or give them the support that they deserve.

I turn to a recent publication of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) which showed that its 1988-89 budget totalled $503m, including $375m of government appropriations and $106m for research and development projects funded by industry. That is quite a respectable percentage, even for those people who feel that markets should rule the decisions we make in the development of our scientific and technological capacity. Yet it is clear that if we are going to achieve the sort of independence and push in our markets that we need to turn the ship around, we must support organisations such as the CSIRO to a much greater extent. The Australian Democrats certainly support the call for a doubling of its funding.

Unless we take such measures, we cannot expect to achieve the turnaround that the current situation requires. Rather than do that, the Government, however, actually cuts funding. I am referring here to the recently publicised research on a hydrogen or gas fuelled zirconia fuel cell which has recently been suspended; there is no more government funding. If we are going to proceed in this sort of manner, we have only ourselves to blame if we fall further and further behind. It is not only an economic question; it is also a question of what it does to our social fabric or, to put it more simply, what it does to women, men and children who suffer because our economy is not managed, because our Government is not accepting responsibility for managing our economy for people; rather, it is managing it for overseas financiers and for this nebulous concept of markets to which it abdicates all responsibility.

Just to give an indication of the fruits that we are beginning to harvest, I turn to an Age article of 27 June 1989 by Sally Loane which cites some statistics provided by the Catholic bishops inquiry into wealth. It shows the connection between poverty and other social dislocation criteria.

In the 1986 census data, we see that families with an annual income under $15,000 have children who are exposed to much greater risk than families which are well above that income level. In fact, they are 11 times more likely to suffer neglect, six times more likely to endure emotional abuse, five times more likely to suffer physical abuse, and four times more likely to be sexually abused. Those are the sorts of risks to which we expose our children if we believe that the economy that we now have, with the results we are facing, is all we can achieve.

But it goes further than that. For those people who believe that there must be a financial equation, if we are to spend money to turn the economy around, let me turn to some statistics from the Australian Institute of Criminology cited in the Age on 29 August 1990. The heading is, `Young People and Crime: Costs and Prevention'. A survey found that young offenders were responsible for at least $610m in direct costs. Spending on prevention, enforcement and justice-rather more enforcement and justice than prevention, I suggest-amounted to more than $800m. The characteristics of potential offenders included that one or both parents or a sibling had been convicted of a crime, had a discordant home, and a low income family. The indirect costs of this situation include $250m spent by the private security industry and a $350m police outlay on law and order relating to young offenders.

We, as a community, have a choice. We can spend our money and our resources on repression, bringing offenders to justice, making our gaols even more secure with barbed wire, or we can spend similar or larger amounts of money on gearing up our industries, training our people and providing jobs for young people as they leave school. The choice is ours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the time remaining to me, I just want to make three brief comments.
—I might call a quorum.
— Please do, Senator Tate.
—No, you would retaliate.

—Thank you, Senator Tate. I want to add a few comments to the comments made by Senator Spindler. As part of the policies that Senator Spindler supports, he believes that we should have over 40 new taxes, charges and tax rises. I invite the public-I do not invite the Australian Labor Party-to reflect on what that would do to the current state of the Australian economy. The fact of the matter is-this is the one point on which I agree with Senator Walsh-that the policies that Senator Spindler advocates would be even worse than the policies of this Government under Mr Hawke and Mr Keating.

SPEECH.PARA: The two other points I wish to make will reinforce the comments that Senator Short made. Australia is now facing the most serious recession since World War II. It is possible that the recession will deepen quite substantially. I believe that the signs that we received today from the national accounts are frightening, to say the least.

The Opposition has brought forward this matter of public importance so that we can debate the Government's policies which have propelled Australia into this recession. It is a tragic indictment of this Government and the contempt with which it treats Parliament that Senator Button, the person who should have been here to take part in this debate and been prepared to stand up and defend his Government's policies, walked out of the chamber. I repeat: when Senator Button was given the chance to stand here and defend his Government's policies, he walked out of the chamber.

Not one Minister was prepared to stand up and defend the Government's policies. Senator Tate, who is in the chamber now, certainly was not prepared to defend the Government's policies. So what did the Government do? It rolled up Senator Walsh in the hope that he would indulge in the usual abuse of his political opponents. We had a comparatively lacklustre performance from Senator Walsh. Even he could not give satisfactory reasons why the Government's policies-in which he took part, let us not forget-have had disastrous consequences.

The last point I wish to make is a very important point: those who were closely involved in the last election and who listened carefully to the debates in the last two or three weeks of that election heard Mr Keating and Mr Hawke being asked numerous times whether Australia was heading towards a recession. Time and time again Senator Tate's colleagues were asked that question, and time and time again they assured the Australian public that we were not going to have a recession.

What happened today? Senator Button came into the chamber and, in answer to a straightforward question, we at last got a straightforward answer. The answer is that the Australian economy is in a recession. The point I wish to make is that this Government has been typecast as a government of the big lie. We all remember the big lie on child poverty. That continues to haunt this Government.

Let me add another one to the extensive list of lies that this Government has made to the Australian public, the promises it has broken. It went to the election and sought the votes of the Australian people. It gave assurances that its policies, the settings, the famous accord of Senator Cook, who gets up here and defends this every day, would not produce a recession. That was wrong; it was a lie, and now Australians all over the country are facing the most serious recession since World War II.

TALK.START.PARA: —The time allowed for the matter of public importance has now expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

The employment of consultants by Ministers has become one of the few growth areas in the Australian economy. The report which the Government has tabled today shows that during the year to 30 June 1980 there were some 54 engagements of consultants by Ministers under the Act. I understand that there are currently some 25 to 28 government consultants on ministerial payrolls. The employment of consultants-and I stress that I make no reflections on the individual qualities of the individuals so employed-has been one of the key ways in which the Government has rapidly expanded ministerial staffing entitlements. This is just one of the ways, I believe, that the Government has breached a valuable convention. That convention is this: the government of the day, whoever it may be, should not exploit its access to taxpayers' funds to give itself undue advantage over its political opponents.

It is clear from what we learnt yesterday from Senator Bolkus that these positions of ministerial consultants are very well paid indeed. The typical payment of consultants stretches from $70,000 to over $117,000, excluding other entitlements such as access to cars and Commonwealth superannuation. These are very valuable consultancies.

As a result of the Government's behaviour in this area, it must naturally expect that the Opposition will take a keen interest in what is happening in the area of government consultancies. I would say that Senator Short has done some great work in this area to bring the community's attention to what has continued to be a matter of considerable concern.

In conclusion, I think that the report would be more helpful if it outlined, in addition to the information on the period of engagement and tasks of the ministerial consultants, information on the consultancy fees and other associated entitlements.

Madam Acting Deputy President, on none of these papers so far called in respect of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody has anybody spoken. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

This is the final report from the Australia Council under the Chairmanship of Professor Donald Horne. I think that certainly calls for some remark by the Senate. Professor Horne in his farewell letter to the Minister for Arts, Tourism and Territories, the Hon. David Simmons, which precedes this report, refers to the fact that this is his final report and he deals with his six years at the Australia Council.

It is no surprise to learn that Professor Horne and spokespeople for the arts on this side of the chamber have, if I may use the phrase loosely, locked horns at times. During the last election campaign, for example, Professor Horne thought it was proper and within his duties to put out what was clearly an unfortunate press release of a blatantly political nature attacking the Opposition's policies. As a result, there has been a tendency for this very important debate about the role of the arts in our community to be coloured by a touch of emotionalism and prejudice that will, one hopes, go in the near future.

That is not to say that Professor Horne's only mark upon the Australia Council has been to develop that controversy. He has contributed a great deal in terms of force, direction and controversial liveliness to the topic. Nonetheless, one cannot help feeling that every now and again there is a touch of pretentiousness in his style. I notice that in his chairman's letter, Professor Horne says:
. . . without a rigorous intellectual and artistic life a society lacks a market place of options in facing the puzzles of existence.

I commend his recognition of the fact that there is some kind of marketplace and I note that in the following sentence he talks about goods and services, as though trying to associate the arts in some way with the new trend to a market society. But we have to concentrate on what the Australia Council is all about. Frankly I do not think it is about pretentious statements about society. I think the Council is there to provide, as an instrument of government, assistance to the arts along the lines of its charter. That is pretty simple; it is to promote excellence in the arts, to provide and encourage the provision of opportunities for people to practise the arts, to promote appreciation, understanding and enjoyment of the arts and so on. However, I totally agree with Professor Horne when he says that the Council:
. . . is not there primarily to serve artists, but, by serving artists, to serve the people who use the things and the activities artists produce.

To that extent I think Professor Horne has contributed significantly to the recognition of the fact that the Council has a broader approach-as it should have-than simply to serve artists themselves. However, I am concerned that Professor Horne has seen it as a mark of success that Council has become:

. . . something of a leader in broad issues of cultural policy, as this report shows, and in its concern for community cultural development it has gone beyond the narrow concept of `community arts' to broader concepts that involve forming alliances with other organisations, from the universities to local governments.
Fortunately the report now reveals:
. . . these developments may now be threatened by a chronically debilitating position. I am afraid the Council's administrative expenses are being cut too fine.

Quite frankly, I think the Council has overstepped the mark in some areas. I am overjoyed to see that the management review says that Council is confident its high quality programs will be maintained, and it will continue to provide leadership in the arts in the years ahead, given the cuts that have taken place. I think the Council has tended to expand too far beyond its proper duties.

I draw the attention of the Senate to the tabulation in the report on page 56 and onwards in relation to Australia Council grants. I particularly want to draw the Senate's attention to the fact that in 1989-90 a total of $529,855 was given by the Australia Council to trade unions for arts grants. Of that figure, $339,000 went to trades and labour councils and $104,000 apparently went directly to the Australian Council of Trade Unions. There are some notable grants among those figures: for example, $99,526-say $100,000- went to the Victorian Trades Hall Council, courtesy of Mr Halfpenny; $29,487 went to the Building Workers Industrial Union (BWIU) for `performance projects'-heaven only knows what they were--
—Poetry on the sites. Excellent. Fantastic.

—Poetry on the sites, from the BWIU. A sum of $95,357 was allocated for trade union arts organisers, while $204,910 was allocated for trade union programs. I have spoken in the past on the subject of taxpayers' money being paid to trade unions for these purposes. I think my comments have been misrepresented, in that I have sometimes been criticised as saying I do not believe trade unions ought to be involved in the arts. That is not the point at all.

SPEECH.PARA: My point is that if trade unions see the arts as a priority for their activities and their members, that is fine, but such activities should not be paid for out of the public purse; they should be paid for from the general funds of the trade unions themselves. I am afraid the Australia Council provided only answers with details of grants for community development. In answers provided through the Estimates hearings, there were specific examples of purely community development grants which I believe highlight the need for concern in this area. I wish briefly to mention the retirement next month of Professor Donald Horne as Chairman of Australia Council. I wish him well in his retirement.
