TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few comments about the annual report of the Australia Council in the area of community cultural development. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Community Cultural Development Committee's main work is to encourage and assist communities from different cultures and backgrounds to have an input into Australia's cultural identity and to assist communities to obtain the resources they need to actively participate in the development of their own culture.

Under that particular program, and the performing arts program, I note in the report that some particular Australian circuses are mentioned, commonly known amongst the traditional circus owners as political circuses, such as Circus Oz, the Flying Fruit Fly Circus and the Rock and Roll Circus from Queensland. The report shows that an amount of $7,000 was given to Circus Chaos, a French circus I saw in Melbourne, which was quite horrific. I have no argument with the fact that the Australia Council has seen fit to sponsor our youth through the Flying Fruit Fly Circus, Circus Oz-which I believe is going to visit the Soviet Union-and the Rock and Roll Circus from Queensland, which received $30,000. They are in themselves quite a culture.

I am very pleased to report to the Senate that the Australia Council funded the first ever Circus Federation conference in Melbourne. I had the honour of opening that particular conference earlier this year. That gave the first opportunity in this country for traditional circuses and the so-called political circuses to get together. Before the conference, the traditional circuses felt that they had been ignored. Honourable senators may remember the demonstration, using traditional circus elephants, that took place last year outside this chamber complaining about the Moscow Circus coming to Australia and upsetting the circus program. As a result of that conference, the political and traditional circuses found they had so much in common that at the end of the day the feeling between the two types of circuses was much better than anybody expected.

Traditional circuses-such as Ashtons, Perry Brothers, Sole Brothers and Bullens-need to spread their wings to enable their artists to gain expertise overseas. I tried unsuccessfully on their behalf to get a small amount of funds to help some of the young artists travel overseas to a conference in, I think, East Germany to improve their expertise, but unfortunately funds were not available. Whilst the Australia Council sees fit to fund some circuses quite substantially-for instance, Circus Oz received $140,000 and the Flying Fruit Fly Circus $81,000-for a small amount of money the Council could have assisted the passage of some these young, traditional circus people, who are family people and finding the going tough in this economy, to improve their expertise. It would be good for the people of Australia to be able to see these artists with that extra expertise. Perhaps an interchange of artists between countries could be encouraged. I did see some magnificent artists in Moscow and Mongolia. I think we could try to arrange some interchange of circus artists between countries.

One of the members of the Australia Council, Mark St Leon, wrote a very interesting book on one of our old time circus people named Mervyn King. I had a lot of pleasure in launching that book and reading the accounts of what it was really like to grow up in a circus.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the President, I present in accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901 the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 13 of 1990-91-Australian International Development Assistance Bureau-aid to Papua New Guinea.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave- I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Eighty-seventh report of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances entitled Special Report on Subdelegation of Powers.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances recently became concerned at some aspects of subdelegation of powers in delegated legislation. It therefore asked its legal adviser, Emeritus Professor Whalan, to prepare a special report on the subject. After receiving the report, the Committee decided that it discusses matters of such importance that it should be tabled as a report of the Committee. The Committee always examines closely each power or discretion granted to a Minister or official by delegated legislation. It first scrutinises the legal validity of such discretions and then decides whether the particular power in question affects personal liberties or parliamentary proprieties. It also ensures that any discretions granted are subject to external review of the merits of any adverse exercise of those discretions.

However, many instruments of delegated legislation not only grant important discretions to Ministers or public officials, but also provide, usually elsewhere in the instrument, that such discretions may be delegated. Often the Committee finds that there are no limits at all on the persons to whom these powers may be given. In such cases it is theoretically possible for the Minister to delegate quite important powers to any person at all, no matter how unsuitable. Many of these powers are open-ended; that is, they are not restricted by criteria. The Committee has noted cases where such wide powers of delegation include the power to allocate Commonwealth money, to issue directives or directions which are partly legislative in nature, or to make decisions affecting the personal liberties or livelihoods of individuals.

In such cases the Committee requires a careful justification from the Minister for such provisions. In some cases they may be justified. Such cases may involve safety provisions. They may also involve situations where large numbers of decisions, suitably restricted by criteria, are to be made. The Committee is more likely to accept wide delegations where any effect on individuals is protected by right of review to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of the merits of a decision. On the other hand, decisions which are few in number but which affect whole classes of individuals or which have important economic consequences, should only be made at senior levels. As usual, where the Committee indicates that an amendment of the level of delegation may be appropriate, it has received a high level of cooperation from Ministers.

Professor Whalan's report-that is, the report that we are tabling today-includes a number of case studies of instances where the Committee has raised subdelegation with Ministers. The resolution of these concerns has, as Professor Whalan points out, influenced the development of this area of delegated legislation. It is hoped that there will not be similar instances to one chain of delegation described in the report. In that case, an Act was passed, regulations were made under the Act, orders were made under the regulations, the orders delegated certain powers to the Secretary, the Secretary could delegate to a senior officer, that officer could delegate the power to delegate to a delegate, and that delegate could delegate the power actually to make a decision. As Anna Russell would earnestly say, `I'm not joking, you know'.
This report, written in Professor Whalan's inimitable style, entertains as it instructs. I commend it strongly to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am also pleased to commend to honourable senators Professor Whalan's report on the subdelegation of powers in delegated legislation. I think the example Senator Giles has given should leave us in no doubt as to the need for such a paper and the need for this chamber to address the issue of subdelegation of powers.

SPEECH.PARA: Very significant aspects of Commonwealth administration are conducted through subdelegated legislation. For example, the various State grants Acts administered by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training expressly provide that the Minister may delegate his functions and powers under the Acts to an officer of the Department. The present Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) has done this. Different public servants in the Department approve projects and authorise payments of hundreds of millions of dollars in respect of those projects. All this is certainly legal and probably appropriate. Nevertheless, the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances closely scrutinises such instruments.

The Committee has recently written to the Minister suggesting that advice be sought from the Australian National Audit Office and the Attorney-General's Department on whether the format of this authorisation to spend Commonwealth money could be improved. Following correspondence from the Committee, the Minister has helpfully undertaken to upgrade the explanatory statements which accompany the authorisations.

In another similar case, the regulations empowered the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to guarantee borrowings of the Australian Wheat Board up to $100m. The regulations also provided that the Treasurer could delegate this power to any officer of the Department of the Treasury. The Committee considered that this power should be restricted to senior officers of the Department. The Minister then undertook to amend the regulations to restrict delegation of this power to the Secretary and Deputy Secretary (Financial) to the Department.

The Committee is equally vigilant where subdelegation of powers may affect personal liberties. In these cases, the Committee insists on closely drafted criteria to restrict and guide the exercise of power. It also insists on suitable review of any adverse decisions.

As Senator Giles said, in the report Professor Whalan, in his own individual style, covers all aspects of the Committee's scrutiny of subdelegation. Those who might find this topic somewhat boring or lacking in interest I am sure will find sprinkled through this report little gems that will make it much more interesting than they might have otherwise thought. I draw the attention of honourable senators to the subdelegation of powers as an important area of concern to the Committee and therefore to this chamber.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Beahan, I table additional information received by Estimates Committee F.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Cook)-by leave-agreed to:
That General Business be not proceeded with this day.
Consideration resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is considering Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1990-91. The question before the chair is that the report of Estimates Committee A, as it relates to Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1990-91, be adopted. I understand that the Committee has completed consideration of the proposed expenditure for the Department of the Treasury. The next department to be considered is the Department of Finance. Are there any matters for examination in relation to the Department of Finance?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of Estimates Committee A contains several reservations put by Senator Bronwyn Bishop, Senator O'Chee and me. One of those related to the Advance to the Minister for Finance. The reservation we put said:

SPEECH.PARA: Questions asked of Departmental officers within the Departments of Finance and Treasury failed to show that recent payments to three States had not been illegally approved by the Minister for Finance.

The reason why my colleagues and I made that reservation was that, in our view, the answers we received from the Department of Finance failed to allay our fears that the Department of Finance had improperly approved payments to South Australia, in particular, totalling more than $100m over a period of four years. The payments had been made in successive transfers.

Although we did have quite a lengthy discussion in the Estimates debate about this matter, I personally found the situation very unsatisfactory because the use of the Advance to the Minister for Finance is required to be only for urgent and unforeseen circumstances. I would have thought that the payments to South Australia quite clearly could not fall into that category because the payments in 1989-90 were made right at the end of the financial year, presumably to get approval before 30 June, despite the fact that there was no way that the money was going to be utilised by South Australia in 1989-90. To the extent that it was urgent, there was a question mark about that; to the extent that it was unforeseen, there was also a question mark because of the fact that it was part of a series of annual payments that had been made to South Australia for a similar purpose.

I would like Senator McMullan, who, I see, is handling this, to tell the Committee again or perhaps to enlighten it in a way that I do not think was done by officers at the Estimates hearings as to how such a payment could be regarded as a proper use of the Advance to the Minister for Finance. I raise it not just in relation to this particular case. Although I think this one is the most obvious and blatant misuse of the Advance that I have seen, it is by no means unique.

It is a serious issue because the use of the Advance to the Minister for Finance in this way means that the payments to which the advances relate are not able to be subject to the same parliamentary scrutiny as would occur with normal appropriations because the Parliament is advised of the payments only after they have actually occurred, or after the Advance to the Minister for Finance has been utilised. The recording of that, or the tabling of the relevant documents, is done in the Parliament only after the event. Also, the notification of them is included in the Budget Papers, but for the following year. Therefore, they are not subject to the normal consideration as are all other forms of appropriation.

It is an important matter. I think it is significant. I would like an explanation as to how the Minister really does interpret the legal requirements that he is bound to operate under of approving only payments which are unforeseen and urgent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is not much to add to the lengthy discussion that was had in the Committee. I understand that we concluded by agreeing to disagree about that matter. At some length Senator Short put his point of view, the officers provided the facts and I put my point of view with regard to them. The tests of urgent and unforeseen were delineated then as they are set down in the Act and the manner in which I believed then, and believe now, they were met.

SPEECH.PARA: The only thing I have to add is, I think, a bit of useful information. Senator Short will be aware of some of this because it is a matter of course, but he could not be aware of all of it, so I provide it for the Committee's information. The Advance to the Minister for Finance is, of course, audited by the Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) in the course of the year on each occasion. I understand that officers from the National Audit Office on this occasion were satisfied that the funds detailed in the statement to which we are referring were issued in accordance with the criteria, that the ANAO has verified the statement as correct, and that, accordingly, their written report will be tabled in the Parliament.

So, in saying that I do not think we ought to have in here again the debate that we had in the Committee, I am not saying that the matter is not important. I accept that it is important; I do not challenge that at all. I simply say that the position has been amply put and I provide that extra bit of information, which I hope is helpful.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it from the Minister's answer that he would not see the South Australian payment as other than urgent and unforseen. I am still not clear regarding that payment-which I think this year was $25m-as to the reasons for regarding it as urgent and unforeseen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was in fact $12m, but that does not change the point at all-I understand that. I will reiterate briefly the points that were made before. The Act requires things to be deemed unforeseen such that the amount of money that needs to be appropriated could not have been specified for inclusion in the previous Appropriation Bill or the supplementary Estimates. That clearly is the case on this occasion because the discussions had not concluded about the amount of money that might be paid.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know this because it is not really relevant to the point, but even if it were known beforehand by the relevant Ministers that a payment was going to be made-and I do not know whether that is the case or not, and it is not relevant to Senator Short's point, nor to mine-nobody could assess the amount of money required and nobody could put a figure in the previous Appropriation Bill. The urgency relates to the fact that there was a time limit specified by what the required procedure sets down, that is, competent authority-the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating)-such that it could not be in the next Appropriation Bill. The two things are quite straightforward. One is entitled to disagree with them, but the words `unforeseen' and `urgent' have a clear English language meaning. There is nothing very arcane about this interpretation of them. They were clearly met on this occasion.

One is entitled politically to say, `The Prime Minister and the Treasurer made a decision that I do not agree with'. That is a proper matter for parliamentary debate, but I do not think whether the legal requirements have been met and whether the officers have acted properly in the discharge of their obligations under the Act is a matter of any doubt. It is a question of whether one thinks the decisions made in and around the Premiers Conference by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer are correct, and that is a matter for political contention and legitimate agreement to disagree.

TALK.START.PARA: —I presume that an important reason for the Commonwealth being prepared to accept the payment as urgent and unforeseen relates to the requirements of the recipient-in this case, South Australia. I wonder whether Senator McMullan could provide the Committee with the relevant information-presumably he does not have it now, but whenever possible-from the South Australian authorities to enable us to understand why the decision by the Commonwealth was so urgent. For example, if the South Australian authorities did not require those funds until such time as our normal appropriation processes had been gone through, that would put a different view on the matter compared with if they did need it. Would the Minister have any information on that?

—The only thing I can add to that which we have already discussed is that there is no documentation from the South Australian Government which we are at liberty to release. Essentially, how the South Australian Government intended to use it is its business, which we also discussed to some extent in the Estimates Committee. But if there is documentation between the Premier, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer, it is the property of the South Australian Government, not the Commonwealth Government. I cannot release any of our documents which are relevant to the point the honourable senator raises. If he wants me to have more of an examination and see whether there are some documents, I am happy to do that, but I do not think it will be a very fruitful search.

—Presumably there are documents from the South Australian Government-it might be a letter from the Premier or the Under-Secretary; I would not know-to the Commonwealth Government making the request for funds. Without necessarily wanting to see copies of that documentation, I do not quite understand why there would be a confidentiality involved in the question of when the request was made, in what form and the details of when the funds would be required by South Australia. I wonder if in his further undertaking to look at the matter Senator McMullan would take that into account. Quite frankly, I cannot see the circumstances in a matter of this nature where there would be the degree of confidentiality that he is suggesting. Even if there is confidentiality involved in some of it, in light of the aspects that I would be particularly interested in and I think the Committee would be interested in, I fail to see the likelihood of a confidentiality problem there.

—The agreement was a product of the negotiations in and around the Premiers Conference. There may not be the documentation that would normally flow in an exchange of documents between governments in other circumstances because the parties were here and discussing related matters. So I am not aware of what documentation there is. I am happy to see whether there is something I can provide. I cannot give any guarantee there will be, but I am happy to look at what there is and provide Senator Short with such answer as I can.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator McMullan for that. I assume he did not mean to suggest that there could be any possibility that with an amount of money of this magnitude-$12m to $15m-an arrangement could be made between the Commonwealth and South Australia to pay that money over without very adequate documentation surrounding it.

SPEECH.PARA: The report of the Estimates Committee dealt with, among other things, the sale of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation (HLIC). I understand that since the Committee met, the sale has been consummated. Prior to the Committee meeting, I think the Minister for Finance, Mr Willis, announced in Parliament in September that the Government would keep liability for existing insurance policies for five years and the buyer would manage the policies on behalf of the Commonwealth. He said subsequently that the Commonwealth expected to receive some $80m in net present value terms. That $80m is considerably higher than the $50m which was talked about prior to the sale. Do we have a figure on the real value of the sale? Is $80m the relevant figure or is it some other figure?

TALK.START.PARA: —We consider the $80m figure a conservative estimate. An actual amount will be paid now against which have to be offset the possible claims over the next five years, which it is not possible to estimate precisely. On the best but conservative estimates we believe the net present value of $80m is the right figure.

—As Senator McMullan would no doubt be aware, because the letter was made public, one of his colleagues, Mr Langmore, wrote to the Minister for Finance, as I recall-I do not have the letter with me-asserting that the Commonwealth was paying out money, far from receiving money, on the sale. I assume from what Senator McMullan said that the Government believes Mr Langmore is wrong. Can he enlighten the Committee on where his misunderstanding has arisen?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Without going into too much detail, I did read the letter some time ago. I do not have it with me, but on the day I read it thought-and I confirmed it in discussion with the officers-that in that letter Mr Langmore operated on some incorrect assumptions about the basis of the sale. If his assumptions were right, his conclusions would have been right.

SPEECH.PARA: However, there were some flawed assumptions in the document. He has had some subsequent discussions with the Minister for Finance, and I understand he accepts that to be the case. I could go further, but I am not sure it is going to take us far today. The fundamental problem is that the nature of the sale had changed from the original idea to the final way it was sold, as Senator Short knows, and in that transition some of the points of significance had been missed in Mr Langmore's letter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the sale of HLIC was first canvassed there were reports, according to the media, that initial bidders had dropped out because of-to quote one of the press reports-the excessive price tag of at least $50m and the sale conditions, which included a requirement that any successful bidder indemnify the Government against the HLIC's continued government guarantee.

SPEECH.PARA: Can Senator McMullan comment on that, because if those reports are at all correct, particularly the one that potential buyers saw the $50m price tag as excessive, the $80m which the Government has achieved is an extraordinarily good effort. If that is so-I congratulate all concerned; the HLIC sale has been a long, tortuous process-the two figures, therefore, do not sit consistently together. I add to that the fact that there was a downgrading, or a reported possible downgrading, of HLIC's credit rating which, I would have assumed, again would have affected potential buyers. I do not know whether that was taken into account-I would like to know-in the sale price negotiated between the Commonwealth and CIC Insurance Ltd. What I am really getting at is that the $80m which the Government has achieved does sit somewhat oddly against the $50m. I would welcome any comment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the supplementary point first: nothing happened, as far as I am aware, to the credit rating of the HLIC prior to its sale. Its credit rating may change when it is no longer a Commonwealth-owned asset and does not have all those benefits. So I do not think that is a factor.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, although we never put a price tag on it as such, I think that early on some people were excessively pessimistic about the price that would be gained for the HLIC, and have been proved correct by events. Senator Short is correct: it seems, on the evidence I have, to have been a very successfully executed sale.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to return very briefly to Senator Short's discussion on the reservation about the Advance to the Minister for Finance and the concern that control over those funds may be inadequate. The question strikes at the heart of some of the Government's rhetoric in terms of restraint in government spending. In that context, today we saw evidence of considerable increases in government spending, not necessarily from the Federal Government alone, but from States as well. The concern relates to advances in relation to some State matters.

SPEECH.PARA: The national income figures show that there appears to have been some laxity in the general thrust of government spending. For example, in the latest 12 months, the September quarter 1990 compared with the September quarter 1989, while the private sector had a 10.9 per cent fall in private sector capital expenditure, the government sector had a 3.7 per cent rise. While recession is everywhere, it is not within the government sector. One wonders whether this sort of relaxed approach to government spending that has emerged, as is evident from Senator Short's questioning, does not reflect some sort of general lack of enthusiasm to restrain government spending at a time when the private sector is in serious economic trouble.

For example, in the September quarter, government final consumption expenditure went up by 3.2 per cent in real terms, seasonally adjusted, while in the poor old private sector it went up by 0.3 per cent. The whole problem that seems to emerge when we look at gross domestic product is of a private sector in deep disarray, suffering deep and serious economic problems, while governments, aided by some pretty lax administration as well, by the sound of it, are proceeding to spend merrily on their ways-although in New South Wales there has been considerable and effective restraint under the Greiner Government. It seems to me that in this discussion relating to the Advance to the Minister for Finance we are seeing a practical demonstration of the lack of will by a government to apply the appropriate fiscal restraint that is needed at a time of serious economic problem. The rhetoric is all restraint, but the practice is laxity.

In conclusion, the suggestions by the head of the Reserve Bank, Mr Bernie Fraser, that perhaps one could not see any further falls in interest rates before Christmas, emerge very clearly from the fact that there has been a lack of fiscal restraint by this Government. The latest example in an already lax environment is the fact that the much acclaimed wage-tax trade-off involves a reduction in fiscal restraint of over $1.5 billion.

This small discussion about the Advance to the Minister for Finance is of far greater significance in the sense that it no doubt reflects an enormous gap between the rhetoric of restraint and the fact of profligacy as is evident in today's disastrous national income figures.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wanted to ask a few questions following the discussion we had in the Estimates Committee hearing on the sale of the Moomba to Sydney gas pipeline. Senator Bishop, Senator O'Chee and I, in our reservation contained in the Estimates Committee report, said that we were concerned about what we saw as a failure to use proper administrative procedures by the Task Force on Asset Sales in relation to the pipeline. Since then the Government has introduced legislation to increase the haulage rates. The Opposition and the Australian Democrats have announced their intention to oppose that legislation. As a result, the Government, as I understand it, has said that that will affect the revenue to the extent of about $700m to $800m this financial year because the Government had hoped, although there was never any guarantee, that it would be able to complete the sale in the course of 1990-91.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask Senator McMullan what the figure of $700m to $800m, that I understand the Government is now citing as its loss for this financial year as a result of the decision by the Opposition not to support the legislation, is based on, given that in the Estimates Committee hearing officers were unable to provide a figure when asked about it. There were various reasons given. Is the figure of $700m to $800m that has been mentioned the sort of figure that the Government contemplated? If so, how has that been calculated?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised, as I expected, that the price is derived from the offers to purchase that were received by the Government. The matters had not been finally negotiated, of course, but the order of magnitude is derived from those offer documents.

—This matter was discussed during the Estimates Committee hearing of 25 September. That was two or three days prior to the closure of the purchase proposals deadline of 28 September. Is it possible for the Parliamentary Secretary to advise the Committee as to how many tenders have been received?

—The reason we could not provide, for example, the offer amounts, even in general terms as I just did, during the course of the Estimates Committee, was because the officers were and remain very concerned to protect the integrity and confidentiality of the negotiations. The $700m figure is sufficiently general and is extrapolated not to prejudice any discussions should the sale go ahead. The situation with the legislation or whatever might change, but if we get beyond that to how many offers have been received, et cetera, I think we would feel that we were straying into the area of jeopardising subsequent negotiations.

—I will not pursue that other than to ask whether that public figure of $700m or thereabouts makes an allowance for the amount of possible compensation that may be involved if the sale were effected. We discussed the question of compensation at the Estimates hearing, as the Parliamentary Secretary will recall. I recall the officers saying that they had not envisaged much likely compensation payment. Does the figure of $700m also include the assumption that there would be little compensation?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not an easy issue to deal with, of course, because of the way in which any such potential claim might be developed and dealt with. We do not want to start throwing around amounts of money we think somebody might get from us in future. I know Senator Short was not seeking that, but I am simply saying that therefore it is a little difficult. Nobody would envisage that any compensation would be out of this Budget, so the budgetary effects on this occasion would not have to net that off.

SPEECH.PARA: People would not be expecting that that figure would be resolved in the course of this financial year. In the simplest of terms, if Senator Short is referring to its effect on the 1990-91 Budget, he does not need to do that, but yes, the Government's overall estimation of the net benefit to the Commonwealth from the sale must take into account the continuing assessment that the Minister has made publicly that we do not expect compensation, if any, to be large.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just to get it clear in my own mind, that $700m that is being talked about does not include any significant amount for possible compensation-setting aside the question of financial years. Is that what Senator McMullan is saying?
(5.22) Senator Short is lifting to a level of precision the $700m.
—Or thereabouts.

—I make that point for a purpose. I am saying that the view would be that the $700m is a very conservative figure about what might flow from the sale under the terms the Commonwealth sought to make the sale. We hope that it will be substantially more, but there is no point in throwing around one's most optimistic figures. We think it is a sufficiently conservative figure such as not to be disturbed by the impact of such compensation as we think might be payable which, as the honourable senator correctly said, we continue to consider would be a small amount, if anything.
—I take it that means Senator McMullan is saying that in his view the net figure-net of possible compensation-of $700m would be conservative. Is my understanding correct?

—I am saying that it is sufficiently conservative as a `gross' figure-in this sense, although it is not quite a proper use of the word, but Senator Short knows what I mean-that it should accommodate any possible compensation amount that might flow. That is slightly different from what Senator Short said but the general understanding is the same; I am just trying to be specific about what I was saying, and that is what I was saying.

—The reason I ask is that, as Senator McMullan is aware, it has been mentioned publicly that compensation figures of somewhere between $200m and $600m could possibly be involved in this matter, depending on a whole complex of events which may or may not occur. But they are the orders of magnitude that were being mentioned at least by some people. I take it from what Senator McMullan is saying that he does not accept those figures. Is that right?
—Obviously.

—Since the Estimates Committee met, we have had the decision of the New South Wales Supreme Court in the case of the Australian Gas Light Co. (AGL) and its right of first refusal. That decision ruled in AGL's favour. Has that decision affected the Commonwealth's further consideration of the proposed sale?

—The Government's consideration of that matter is at this stage inextricably intertwined with its consideration of the responses, if I might put it that way, to the legislation which the coalition and the Australian Democrats have made. They are all matters in the equation for the Government to consider how it will proceed with the sale. The more immediate question is the legislative one rather than the judicial one, which is something which the Minister will deal with but which at this stage I am not in a position to make any statement about.

—That is a sufficiently Delphic response for me to wonder whether it is worth while pursuing it further. Senator McMullan says `inextricably linked'. If that is the case, has the Commonwealth given consideration to trying to sort out the legalities and to going back to negotiate with the potential parties affected by this matter to try to get some resolution of the outstanding, obviously very strong, differences between the Commonwealth and AGL about the way this matter has been handled so that there may be a hope of reaching a satisfactory conclusion? In other words, are any further negotiations planned to take account of the difficulties that have emerged so strongly over recent months?
—Really this is not the forum for that. We have gone well beyond what I think is the appropriations matter. It is a matter that Senator Short can pursue elsewhere, and I am sure he will.
—So Senator McMullan will not give an answer to that question?
—I think I have been fairly flexible and generous in going beyond the matters that are really appropriations matters.
—I think the Chair has too.
—Yes, Mr Chairman, and Senator Short probably appreciates that more than I do; nevertheless it is proper that we try to be as cooperative as possible. I am simply drawing the line.
—I appreciate that, and that was my last question anyway on that point. I just want to ask a couple of questions now about the cost of the Tax Pack.
—The problem is that matter relates to the Treasury.
—Senator McMullan-

—Could I make a suggestion about that, Mr Chairman? I may be pre-empting what you were going to say, but I had a discussion with Senator Harradine about some matters to do with Tax Pack and I understand from the Whip that he plans to put some questions on notice. I am happy to take those, and if Senator Short has some questions I am happy to take any of those on notice as well. They do come up under Treasury estimates; we have already dealt with that and the officers have left. If my understanding is correct, I am happy to cooperate with both proposals to take the questions on notice.

—Senator Harradine did approach me before about the Tax Pack. I was not aware that the officers had gone, but I realise now that they would have. If it is the wish of the Committee, we will go back to that part of Treasury and I will call Senator Harradine. There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) said, one of the questions is a technical one, which obviously I would not expect him to know the answer to. But as the other questions go to an area of Government policy, I am sure that he is quite capable of answering those. I am raising this as a result of questions that were raised by me at the Estimates committee hearings, at Hansard pages A392, A394 and A395. I have now answers to those questions and I just want to follow up on them.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Committee will be aware, I did raise a series of questions with the officers of the Australian Taxation Office in Estimates Committee A as to why the bulk of the Tax Pack was printed on imported paper when in Tasmania, for example, Associated Pulp and Paper Mills Ltd has equivalent paper and is actually making stock. One of the technical questions was whether the purchase of the imported paper was made in American dollars. I ask the Parliamentary Secretary to take this on notice and get a response for me. I presume, because the paper was purchased in United States dollars by News Ltd, that the cost of the Finnish paper was lower. If so, what is the difference between the actual purchase price of the paper and its cost had it been purchased in Australian dollars? If I could have the answer to that or if the Parliamentary Secretary could take that on notice, I would be obliged.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly will.
—Two answers were given to me as a result of questions being taken on notice at the Estimates Committee. I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: What are the guidelines (referring to those used to determine purchase of paper)? Do they include a weighting for Australian-made products?
The answer that I have been given is as follows:

Currently the only guideline in place for the purchase of goods and services is that the best value for money be obtained. In respect to print procurement, Australian made paper is naturally preferred but is no longer weighted to the advantage of Australian manufacturers.

I am really appalled at that, particularly from the Tax Office, which spent millions of dollars on the Tax Pack. Most of the paper was imported paper-80 or 90 per cent-from Finland. The Tax Office's job is to collect taxes. It collects not one red cent from the Finnish company in company tax and does not collect anything from the Finnish workers in pay as you earn tax. None of that is weighted for the purposes of purchasing paper for this Tax Pack. Frankly, I feel that there needs to be an answer given by the Government as to why there is not some weighting given to Australian manufacturers. It appears that there is absolutely none given. The decision to purchase paper is made just on the basis that the best value for money is obtained.

I know that this is a very difficult area and that you, Mr Chairman, would not allow me to use the consideration of the Estimates for this purpose, but I simply raise this issue again in the hope that the Tax Office on this occasion, since it has decided again to publish the Tax Pack, looks seriously at Australian manufacturers and obtains quotes from them. The Office did not in this case, because it stipulated a particular type of paper which was not produced in this country. But there was other equivalent paper that could have been used. I hope that the Tax Office gives some weighting to Australian manufacturers.

I am not in the business of feather-bedding Australian industry to such an extent that it does not become at all competitive, but I am advised that in the area of paper products we are fairly competitive. On this occasion, we were told in the Estimates Committee-without any proof; it was just asserted-that the Australian product would have been considerably dearer. That was an assertion. When we asked for the basis of that assertion, we were virtually told that we could not know the cost of the purchase because it was presumably commercial in confidence. So we are flying in the dark a bit. I simply ask the Government whether it would have a word with the Tax Office on this occasion so that, when it is considering what paper the Tax Pack is to be printed on, it does give every consideration to Australian manufacturers. The Tax Office does not put onto the scales the fact that if Australian industry cannot sell its products to a major purchaser such as the Government then the Office will not be able to recoup pay as you earn tax and company tax from the people who will miss out on providing the paper from Australian sources.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine raised two very closely related questions. I will certainly undertake to ensure that the Taxation Office gives consideration to the availability of equally useable Australian paper. I well remember the discussions that he had with the officers during the course of the Estimates Committee about factors as well as price. I am sure that they have taken those factors on board, but I will raise it with them again to ensure that proper consideration is given.

SPEECH.PARA: The question of the weighting of Australian products is not a matter that will be decided independently by the Tax Office. It is a matter of Government purchasing policy and industry policy. Broadly, the direction is as outlined in the answer which Senator Harradine read which is to do with value for money for the taxpayer's dollar. I will ensure that the Tax Office, in dealing with this matter, does adhere to those guidelines and does give reasonable consideration to those issues that Senator Harradine has raised.

TALK.START.PARA: —I really do not want the Tax Pack to adhere to the guidelines as they have been given to me in the answers, because the guidelines refer to `purchases of goods and services at the best value for money be obtained'. The question is: what is the best value for money? I hope that the Australian Taxation Office will put in some of the factors that are meant. The best value for its money, in my view, is to buy it from people who will pay them tax.

—Very briefly, the Australian Taxation Office will not unilaterally determine that matter. It will be a matter of government purchasing and industry policy and the Taxation Office will comply with those requirements.

—I refer to the matter we were discussing in the Estimates Committee on the role and independence of the Auditor-General. At the time of the Estimates Committee, from memory I think Senator McMullan said that the Government was looking at the question of the independence of the Auditor-General, whether the office should become a statutory body and whether the status of the Auditor-General himself as well as the office should be altered along the lines that have been recommended by many, including in particular the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. Has the Government, in the month or more since then, come any closer to taking a decision on that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The very short answer is no. There is not a lot I can add, other than to say that there are three pieces of legislation involved, and discussion papers on all three are under consideration at the moment.
—Does the Minister have any idea at all on possible timing?
—No. I am happy to make any inquiry and let the honourable senator know, but there is nothing available to me at the moment that would help on that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill reported without requests.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) proposed:
That the report from the Committee be adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Senate is aware, there was a debate yesterday in relation to the postage allowance. An amendment was sought to be moved by the Opposition in relation to that matter requesting the House of Representatives to reduce the appropriations for the Department of Administrative Services by $1,028,596 as an offset to the amount that the Government has failed to seek to recover, following the ruling by the High Court of Australia that the increase in postage allowance to members of the House of Representatives was invalid and contrary to section 83 of the Constitution. We divided on that yesterday in Committee and the amendment was lost.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition does not propose, and has therefore not sought, to divide the Senate again on the matter. But I do want to make it quite clear and have it on the record that, despite the fact that we are not dividing on that issue again, our opposition to the situation so far as the postage allowance is concerned remains at least as strong as it has always been. We believe that the Government has acted very improperly on this matter, indeed illegally, and quite contrary to the spirit of the Parliament and the Constitution. I want that to be recorded, whilst not seeking to divide the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

REPORT OF ESTIMATES COMMITTEE A
Motion (by Senator Bolkus) proposed:

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, as the Committee is considering the Department of the Senate, I assume that this is the correct point at which to raise the matter of the discontinuation of the citizenship visits program which is covered by the Parliamentary Education Office.
—Yes.
—I therefore ask the Minister whether the Government has changed its position on the discontinuation of the citizenship visits program and whether this program will continue in the next year.

—I am advised that the citizenship visits program was initiated by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins). It was at a later stage transferred to the parliamentary departments for them to operate. They are now of the view that they do not have funds to do so. The current status of this matter is that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training is considering how to proceed hereafter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I suppose at this time it is appropriate for me to make a comment on the citizenship visits program, because I believe it is very important.
—I am not sure about a comment, because we are supposed to be examining matters.
—We are in committee, Mr Chairman.
—You go ahead for the moment and I will check my facts. I think that you may have just chosen your words wrongly; that is all.

—At the outset I would like to take this opportunity of congratulating the President on much of the fine work that is being done by the Parliamentary Education Office-fine work that, I believe, is sometimes underrated by some of us this chamber, and unfortunately so. I have a great deal of satisfaction in talking to school students who visit this Parliament and in fact have been known to grab some of my colleagues and take them up to Senate committee room 10 to show them mocked up Parliament--
—Is that mocked up or mucked up?

—The mocked up Parliament. This is the mucked up Parliament. The Parliamentary Education Office is an integral part of the visit to Canberra in the education of those students. At this hour the glassed-in galleries that surround the Senate chamber are empty. My concern is that in the forthcoming year they will be empty much more frequently than they are at the moment. I believe that is a very sad matter indeed, because the people who usually fill these glassed-in galleries-especially during Question Time but also at other times during the day when we are sitting and conducting our business as members of the Senate-are young school students from all over Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Many of those school students come here only because they receive financial assistance under the citizenship visits program. The money required to run this program is some $1m in a full year. I fully appreciate all the arguments about fiscal restraint. Fiscal restraint is very important but, as a young person in Australia, I believe the education of future generations of Australians in the parliamentary processes and the Westminster system is equally important. Every one of us who sits in this chamber has a certain degree of pride-I hope not misplaced pride-in the fine institution of Parliament and everything that it stands for, and has a pride in what this Parliament has to offer the people of Australia. The Parliament should also offer the young people of Australia a citizenship visits program.

The program, as proposed for the forthcoming year, involves subsidies to students from distant schools on a formula based upon the distances they reside from Canberra. Those students who reside less than 1,000 kilometres from Canberra receive no funding. If the students reside between 1,000 and 2,000 kilometres from Canberra, they receive $50 for their visit. Students residing between 2,000 and 3,000 kilometres from Canberra receive $100, and those students who reside further than 3,000 kilometres from Canberra receive $150 under the proposed scheme.

Representing Queensland, most of which comes under the proposed formula, I think it is very important that young Queensland children have the opportunity to visit Parliament to see what it is all about, and for them to see that Parliament is not just an imaginary place but is a real place where real people make real decisions. What is most important about this is that I know a lot of school students receive a lot of satisfaction from their visits.

In the Estimates Committee A Hansard, at page 4, the President was kind enough to advise that some 162 schools had been able to attend the Parliament using the citizenship visits program, at a total cost of $498,700; and some 6,000 students attended from those 162 schools. Six thousand students may not sound like a lot but, given that many students will visit Canberra only once in their 12 years of schooling, if one adds up the number of students who will receive this funding over a period of time, the number becomes substantially more than what will be indicated in one year.

Mr Gilbert also said in that hearing that there was a fairly significant multiplier effect-they were his words-when he talked about the educational fall-out from this funding. In other words, students come down here and they tell other students about their experience. They tell their friends about their experience. They say, `We met a member of the House of Representatives and we met a member of the Senate. They are real people; they can talk to us; they are interested in our problems; and we believe that they are trying to do their best by the people of Australia'.

It is also very important if we want the next generation of young Australians to take an interest in what this Parliament does and if we are to bring up good parliamentarians in 10 or 15 or 20 years time. If the young people of this country turn their back on the Parliament, we cannot expect to receive the informed decision-making that we, as Australians, look forward to in the future. We, as Australians, after we leave this place, will be dependent upon our successors to make the right decisions for us.

The support that this scheme gives to distant schools is quite substantial. For people from Townsville or Cairns, for example, the money is sufficient to meet most of the costs of the students travelling down by bus or coach. Obviously, it is nowhere near the money that would be necessary for students to fly down, but those students who could afford to pay the rest of the money to fly would not need the money in the first place.

I am concerned that, if we scrap the citizenship visits program, we run the very real risk of making Parliament and Canberra a reality only for students from New South Wales or parts of Victoria, or for students from very rich backgrounds. I am concerned that this Parliament is a parliament of the people-a parliament where all young people, irrespective of the wealth or income of their parents, have an opportunity to attend and see the workings of Parliament and see how decisions are made in this country.

In May of this year-and unfortunately I do not have the Hansard with me-one of the education Ministers was asked a question in relation to whether the citizenship visits program was successful. His answer, in very general terms, was that the citizenship visits program was an enormous success. He said that it was a very fine program, and so on. Yet we find now, the responsibility having been shuffled off onto the Joint House Department, that the scheme is going to be scrapped because, although the Government gave the responsibility to the Joint House Department, it did not give the Joint House Department the money to run the scheme.

There is a substantial investment in educational infrastructure in Parliament. For example, I have already referred to the glassed-in galleries that surround the Senate. We have a substantial investment in the skills that have been developed by the Parliamentary Education Office; they are very fine and talented people who work very hard for a cause, which is to educate young people.

We have another investment in the facilities that exist in committee room 10 and elsewhere in this Parliament: the technology that has been purchased to make the visit to Canberra of these young school students an interactive and exciting process. What I am concerned about is that we maximise the access and equity-to use two of the Government's favourite words-of all young Australians to Parliament and what is going on in this country.

As a final comment, I would suggest that we have some 10 years to run until the centenary of Australian Federation. In 1988 we had enormous celebrations to celebrate the bicentenary of white settlement in Australia. For those of us in Parliament, the centenary of Australian Federation is in some ways a more significant date; it is a more significant occasion because it marks 100 years of self-government of Australia as a nation. If this event is to have the significance in this country that it so richly deserves, I believe that the citizenship visits program-enabling, as it does, young Australians from far-flung corners of this country to come and see the processes of Parliament, to see all the things that we hold in such awe in this chamber, and to see all the things that we as parliamentarians are so rightly proud of-should be allowed to continue. I believe it is fundamental in the lead-up to the centenary of Australian Federation.

For those reasons, I would beg all those who are responsible to assist in whatever way possible to allow sufficient funds to be made available for the citizenship visits program so that it can continue and so that young Australians can be proud of their Parliament, the people's Parliament, and the Parliament of which we are all rightfully proud servants.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As another young senator-39 years is not old!-I join Senator O'Chee in speaking on this subject, which I did not expect to do. In looking through some papers in my drawer I was reminded of the Hansard on which Senator O'Chee was unable to lay his hands. Mr Dawkins said:

SPEECH.PARA: I can report that the citizenship visits program has been extraordinarily successful, even more successful than we thought when we introduced this pilot program last year. The reason the program was introduced was that for those who live outside New South Wales and Victoria, we noticed that there was a very important program of school visits to Parliament House where groups of young people came here to observe and, no doubt, be edified by our activities and to learn something more about the democratic process generally, particularly as a result of the education programs that have been put into place in the Parliament House.
In a press statement launching the program with the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Mr McLeay, Mr Dawkins stated:

As the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training emphasised in its report on `Education for Active Citizenship', it is important, said Mr Dawkins, `that all young Australians have a solid understanding of how our government and democracy works. First hand experience is one of the best ways to achieve this understanding . . . The Citizenship Visit Program will be piloted as a Project of National Significance.

For the Government to retreat from a program and a project which it judges to be of national significance because it feels it is no longer able to fund it is to me a matter of grave disappointment. I support the views put forward by Mr Dawkins at the time of that launch.

The schools most disadvantaged by the dismantling of this program are those from Western Australia, simply because they are the furthest away and it costs the most to get the Western Australian students to Canberra. Senator O'Chee talked about entertaining school children from Queensland and introducing his colleagues to them. I do not remember any school from Western Australia visiting this Parliament in the last five years-except some kids from my daughter's school who won an economics prize last year and some kids who won an economics prize from my boy's school this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —You must send your kids to good schools.

—No, they just have good genes. I am sure that there are some schools from Western Australia which have visited Parliament House that I do not know about, but the disadvantage for them is gross. This scheme, modest as it might have been, gave them some opportunity because, in the case of Western Australia, the children were to receive $200 per student. The return economy air fare from Western Australia must be $700 or $800, and with accommodation and that sort of thing the expenses quickly add up. It is almost impossible in this economic climate for schools from Western Australia to be able to visit the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I understood Senator Bolkus to be saying that the matter now rests with the Presiding Officers, but their problem is that they do not have funding. I know from going through the Budget how difficult it is to find any extra dollars, but in my view there would be justification for going back to the Government on this matter. I thought it was the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) who said that no more funding was available. I thought that was where the matter rested, but perhaps I am wrong about that. Can the Minister bring us up to date and tell us whether it is possible for this program to be reintroduced?

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated earlier, the matter has been referred by the Presiding Officers to the Minister for Education, Employment and Training (Mr Dawkins), who previously had responsibility for the program, with a view to requesting him to see whether moneys can be obtained for its continuation after 31 December this year.
—It comes in his budget?
— That is right. It has come from his budget in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen The Hon K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I could assist Senator Crichton-Browne. I wrote a letter to him on 19 November about this matter and on the same day I wrote to the Honourable J.S. Dawkins. In the letter I said:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Minister

I attach, for your information, a copy of my reply to Senator Noel Crichton-Browne concerning the Citizenship Visits Program. The Speaker and I are aware that the program, funded by your Department but administered by the Parliament, is due to end on 31 December. I understand that you have undertaken to raise, in Cabinet, the possible continuation of the program-
Minister Dawkins had given a verbal commitment to the Presiding Officers, who strongly support the program-
You should be aware that I have already had a number of representations from Senators expressing their concern at the possible ending of the program.
I do not have the exact date of that letter but it was about 19 November.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it that it would be blind optimism to imagine that the Presiding Officers could find any money in their own budgets.
—We look very carefully at our budgets and it is impossible to find that amount of money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing the matter that has been brought forward by Senator O'Chee and Senator Crichton-Browne, I refer to the responses given in Estimates Committee A when this matter was being discussed. Some lengthy answers were given to a set of lengthy questions by Senator Peter Baume about the Parliamentary Education Office and in particular the schools visits program. Many of Senator Peter Baume's questions asked about criteria which were used for decision making. I remind the Minister that Senator Peter Baume asked for performance indicators which could be used to judge the success of the program.

SPEECH.PARA: I will pick up one of the words that Senator O'Chee used. As far as I was concerned, there was pride permeating the answers. As far as I can see from the answers to Senator Peter Baume's questions about performance indicators, there was a constant theme of pride in terms of meeting the performance indicators which had been set to measure the degree of success of the schools visits programs. Following through that theme, I want to know whether the performance indicators were found to be unsatisfactory and then used as a basis for transferring this program to another supervision. What criteria were used to justify this transfer?

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to Senator Bell's question is that the decision to transfer was in a sense a Government policy decision rather than one which could be based on the criteria that we are talking about.
—You are not suggesting that Government decisions are made without any basis?
—No, never.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a serious question. I wanted to know the reasons for the transfer. If it is simply a matter of Government policy, we would all be enlightened if some indication could be given as to whether there was a basis for that decision or whether it was just a matter of convenience.

SPEECH.PARA: What it boils down to now is that we sit in anticipation of some success from the President's supplications to another Minister to see whether it can be continued, regardless of its degree of success. If there has been a change, surely there must be some sort of criteria by which this change has been made. That is all the question relates to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did intend to give a serious res- ponse. It was a policy decision taken by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins). As a consequence of that, the program was transferred to the Parliament. In terms of any more padding to my answer, I should best approach that Minister for a reply. As I represent him in this place, I will endeavour to get one as quickly as possible. It is fair to say that since it was part of the parliamentary functioning-it was in Parliament-it was felt by him that it was appropriate that it be run by the Parliament. If there is anything further to add to that I will get back to Senator Bell.

—Mr Chairman, perhaps you could guide me. I want to raise a matter which impinges upon the facilities available to the Commonwealth car drivers on the Senate side. Is this the appropriate occasion to raise it?
—Depending on the actual detail of the question, I imagine it would be.

—I am not sure. What I would like the honourable senator to do is outline, if he can, which particular reservation or general matter in the report this refers to, because we are only supposed to look at reservations or matters in the report. I cannot find anything in the report about it.
—I understood there was a general reservation on it. Am I not correct? If there is not, I will deal with it at another time.

—As there are no further matters to examine in relation to the Senate, we will move to the Department of the Parliamentary Library. I cannot find a general reservation in relation to the Parliamentary Library so, in that case, we will move to the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As is becoming increasingly obvious to all of us, Hansard has been burdened with additional work as a result of the committees of the Senate. I understand that, in fact, this year the committees of the House of Representatives are consuming more of Hansard's time than those of the Senate. That has led to considerable delays in the presentation of the printed Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: The question that obviously has to be raised in terms of cost and benefit is whether or not it is judged that Hansard has an optimum level of efficiency which militates against having excess resources in times of troughs and, in part, accommodates the peaks. It is my view that Hansard ought to be able to provide a regular and standard service irrespective of the demands of the Parliament. Of course, that inevitably and inexorably leads to some inefficiencies because the resources will not be used to an optimum capacity in the quiet times.

I will cite two recent examples. As a member of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority (NCA) I was confronted with a very difficult question in respect of privilege. I could not address that matter because I did not have a Hansard for over a fortnight. It was a grave difficulty for me, I can say. More recently-yesterday-we sought the Hansard for an NCA Committee meeting that took place in Brisbane early last week, and that was not available. In fact, as a result of certain unravellings today we were not able to have access to the tape.

What is the view on the level of resources that ought to be available so as to provide the sorts of efficiencies and services that inevitably are going to be called upon by senators both in this chamber and on the various committees?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crichton-Browne, I have allowed latitude for the question even though my detailed examination, and that of the Clerk's, indicates that there is no particular reservation by which the question should have been asked. Seeing as it has been asked, I will ask Senator Sibraa whether he is able to provide an answer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen The Hon K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do have some figures which I am sure will be of interest to Senator Crichton-Browne. Since 1 July, Hansard has reported 227 committee meeting days, in addition to the sitting days of both chambers. A further 31 meeting days have been foreshadowed for December. This will come to a total of 258 reporting assignments, a figure which is a significant increase on the last directly comparable Budget sittings of 1988. I say `1988' because in 1989 the Budget sittings were disrupted by the effects of the pilots strike which resulted in the cancellation of many committee meetings.

SPEECH.PARA: The raw figures are useful in themselves. However, the figures do not include considerations such as the length of committee hearings or the number of simultaneous hearings. I am sure that honourable senators are aware that this current round of Estimates committees has set records in respect of hearing times. Honourable senators will also be aware that the new procedures of the Senate, whereby legislation is referred for consideration by standing committees of the Senate, have also had an impact on Hansard.

Senators will be aware that in recent years there have been problems in Hansard which have manifested themselves in serious staffing shortages and unaccept- able delays in the production of some committee transcripts. As a result of the significant changes which are being made to Hansard, additional staff have been and will be appointed. The first priority has been to appoint additional chamber reporters and, over the past five months, eight new chamber reporters have been either appointed or promoted. As well, considerable effort has been made to employ additional transcript editors and additional committee reporters. Moreover, considerable overtime has been worked at night and on Saturdays on a regular basis to deal with the backlog.

At present, the delay in transcription of committees is around two weeks, although this does change as workloads reach peaks. I can assure honourable senators that every effort is being made to clear the backlog. Seven additional repor- ters-in-training will commence duty with the Department within the next week. They will be trained as speedily as possible to enable their use on committee assignments.

At the end of this sitting period Hansard will review the impact of legislation committees, extended meetings of some Estimates committees and the increased sitting hours of committees generally with a view to providing advice on possible action to provide improved service to senators. I have available a table which sets out the committee assignments undertaken or anticipated by Hansard from 1 July this year. I think it would be a good idea if I incorporated that table in Hansard.
