DEBATE.TITLE: COMMUNITY SERVICES AND HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 November, on motion by Senator Tate:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990. This Bill includes all the Budget announcements on aged care and many health related issues including pathology, the registering practice of State deregistered doctors in other States, safety net concessions, funding of nurse education, the Medicare Benefits Advisory Committee, therapeutic goods, the separation of radiologists from general practitioner clinics and the performing of X-rays by GPs.

SPEECH.PARA: I should not let this opportunity pass without saying that, when this omnibus Bill covering a wide range of health and aged care related issues was brought into the House of Representatives, the shadow Ministers in that House had almost no time to consider or look at the Bill. There was a total of 50 minutes debating time for every stage of the Bill in that House. That says something about the way this Government manages its business. Fortunately, we have more time here in the Senate. Again, this demonstrates the importance of the Senate for the review and consideration of legislation which covers a wide area.

Given that this is an omnibus Bill, I would have thought it was an appropriate opportunity for the Minister for Community Services and Health, Mr Howe, to have addressed the plethora of issues of concern to people with disabilities and their carers. At the time of the Budget, the Minister said that he would bring the attendant care scheme under the Disability Services Act. Yet, given all the proposals put forward in this Bill, there is no mention in it of the attendant care scheme and what the Government will do with it. I ask Senator McMullan, who is in the chamber representing the Minister, when that Budget proposal will be brought before Parliament. When will we see the necessary legislation to give effect to what I consider to be an important and long overdue change?

The legislation we are debating tonight implements the Government's Budget decision to abolish hostel care subsidy in respect of residents of aged persons hostels other than those who are financially disadvantaged. It also enables private organisations, as well as non-profit bodies, to be eligible to apply for recurrent funding but not capital funding for aged persons hostels. As from 9 January next year the payment of hostel care subsidies, which is currently $2.50 a day, to non- financially disadvantaged persons, will cease. The Government expects this cut to raise $27m in revenue in 1990-91 and $53m in 1991-92. It states that by extending their maximum fee scale combined with the interest they receive from entry contributions, hostels will be able to compensate for reduced funding.

This Bill also includes a charter of rights. I raise that here because it says a lot for what the Government thinks about old people's rights. I believe that this legislation infringes on the rights of current hostel residents-people who have made a decision to go into hostels. Many of them chose to leave their own homes and enter residential accommodation. They have signed contracts with fees calculated at a particular level. In some ways the carpet has been pulled from underneath their feet. It may have been appropriate at least to have some lead time for them to reorganise their financial situations and to accommodate this change that the Government has brought upon them.

We have been told by a number of people running hostels-the shadow Minister has also been told-that this cut will have an impact on standards. As I move around nursing homes and hostels I realise the tremendous support that is given to older people by volunteers who often not only visit their relatives in those hostels but also offer support and care to other people. In fact, the other day I had a letter from somebody whose friend had been in a nursing home and whom she visited five hours a day. She commented on the care and support that the staff had given. No doubt, she herself had given a lot of support and care, not only to that resident but also to other residents in the nursing home. One sees similar things in hostels.

Only with that volunteer support will they be able to maintain the standards which the Commonwealth has set and the standards which they themselves want to maintain for older people. So much for social justice from this Government that continually tells us about its social justice policy. It seems to think that it has a monopoly on caring. The Australian public is beginning to realise what the Government's economic policies are doing to older Australians in residential care.

In October this year the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) met with the delegation from the Australian Affiliation of Voluntary Care Associations. He said that there was a possibility of a clause which would overcome the retrospective nature of the proposal I referred to. It was suggested that the withdrawal of the subsidy, say for two years, might be appropriate. Like the children of Australia and many other people, we know just what we can make of the Prime Minister's word, because no such amendment and no subclause has appeared in the Bill.

Another decision that the Government has made is to allow private participation in the Commonwealth hostel program. There has been a policy to reduce the number of nursing home beds. The policy has been to move towards more hostel places. Hostel places required for the elderly are not being built at the rate sufficient to meet expected demand. But the Commonwealth has failed to provide the incentive for private operators to augment the supply of hostel accommodation needed. All around the place the Government heralds, especially during election time, the number of beds that it has approved in various areas. I have seen this happen in Victoria; so many beds have been approved. It is so hard to get from the Department how many beds have been taken up. How few of those beds have been taken up is not really publicised. Neither the voluntary sector nor the private sector can afford to take on new hostel beds and operate at a loss.

Mr Acting Deputy President, if you want to, I will take you to Stawell and to some of the other country towns in Victoria and introduce you to some of the managers of those voluntary sector hostels; they are frazzled-that is the only word I can use. Over three or four years I have visited them and I have watched them dealing with residents who have increased dementia.

The Government's policy has ensured that category 4 and 5 nursing home residents go to hostels rather than nursing homes. As we know, those residents are more dependent than are hostel residents. We are now seeing the Government's policy start to have an impact on those hostels. Managers of nursing homes are putting in extra time. In fact, one in the southern part of Melbourne was in tears. She said to me, `I can't continue to give the sort of standard of care that I have been used to giving, because I just do not have the resources in staff or physically'. This is not somebody out to make a profit; this is a person running a hostel for local government.

As I have said in this chamber over and over, we will see an exodus from the aged care sector. It has not been fashionable to be in geriatric nursing or to be in aged care. Gradually, with tremendous work being done by some of the tertiary institutions, especially the one from which I came, the Lincoln Institute of Health Services which is now at La Trobe, there has been an increase in the status of the aged care sector and of those people working in that sector. Yet it is being eroded; people are not going to stay.

The people in the community are not going to go into the nitty-gritty about funding for hostels. They will say, `You know, Molly who has been in that hostel for years as a manager is not coping as well now, and the standard has dropped'. Many managers have said to me, `Senator, I cannot let the standard drop and let the people in the community think it is me. They are not interested about government funding, they think it is me. So after 15, 20 or 23 years I am going to leave this hostel'. That is what the policies of this Government are doing. We are going to stretch hostels to a point where many staff will reach breaking point. We will see an exodus and I will say, `I told you so'.

In this Bill there is also provision for nursing home residents to have unlimited hospitalisation leave. What did we see in February of this year? We saw Mr Staples gallivanting around the countryside-I should qualify that; gallivanting around the marginal electorates-saying `We will fund multipurpose centres', and `We will abolish the 28-day rule'. Then he leaves the Department and the aged care institutions to pick up the pieces. Some of these places were designated and approved as multipurpose centres in February. On 12 October I asked about this in the Estimates Committee hearings. I was told initially that these people had not received their cheques and then, subsequently, they received their cheques on 18 June-yet the cheques were dated 26 June. It took months for those people to get their funding.

What happened to the others who have had residents who have been hospitalised and took Mr Staples at his word that there would not be a 28-day rule? They bore the cost of the empty bed while the person was in a nursing home. How long did it take them to get their money? It took 10 months. The Minister seemed unaware that he needed to bring in legislation to meet the promises. This Government has the attitude that Parliament is irrelevant and that it can go around the countryside handing out all sorts of things, but there comes a day of reckoning. The legislation has to be put through the due processes, and that takes time. If the Minister had been a little more careful in choosing his words, then we would not have had people believing that they were going to have these conditions.

This Bill also supplements changes being made to the respite care regulations to facilitate the use made of respite care provisions in nursing homes. Changes to the Act are necessary to allow nursing homes to charge prospective respite care residents a booking fee, which is refundable on admission, and to limit the size of that fee to 25 per cent of the resident respite cost or one week's respite fee, whichever is the lesser. Current provisions in the Act prohibit nursing homes charging any fee prior to the admission of a resident.

We welcome these new changes. They remove the financial disadvantages of providing respite beds in nursing homes, and we understand that a geriatric assessment team coordinator will be appointed next year to develop awareness of respite beds and to develop respite referrals. We have to give credit where credit is due. We know that there are many people in the community caring for their aged relatives who could continue to do so if they had that respite care. We also welcome the establishment of more than one nursing homes fees review committee in each State to clear the backlog of cases.

I would like to stress that the nursing home industry is suffering as a result of the reduction in the care aggregated module (CAM) funding for categories three and five. Mr Braithwaite referred to this in his speech in the House of Representatives. I reiterate how fascinated I was to see that in the Budget. When I asked in the Estimates Committee hearings about the CAM review committee and its report, I discovered that the Minister had received that report on 8 October. So it is obvious that the Cabinet in making its Budget decisions pre-empted its own review committee.

This Bill also refers to a number of significant changes in health. I wish to address two of these changes. Firstly, an anomaly exists at present in the definition of `medical practitioner' which allows a doctor who has been deregistered or delicensed in one State to practise in another. The legislation we have before us allows deregistered doctors to continue to practise but to be ineligible to claim Medicare rebates for their services for the period of their suspension or deregistration. This goes a long way towards addressing the problem we found of people using the loophole of being deregistered in one State and practising in another.

Secondly, I wish to address the Government's proposals which pertain particularly to government restrictions on radiology practices of doctors. At the moment, general practitioners can undertake some X-rays. These proposals will look at a number of issues, such as general practitioners undertaking X-rays, and will put the radiologist at arm's length from the general practitioner.

What has been going on-I guess it has been happening in pathology as well-is that a few doctors who were not scrupulous brought into disrepute many of their profession who were behaving and acting in an honourable fashion. I suppose it is a bit like this place. One or two bad apples can bring all politicians into disrepute. Some doctors were referring radiology patients on and there were some scams and schemes being undertaken. This legislation aims to close the loophole. We support that. We think it is not appropriate for there to be opportunities for people to abuse the system and to take taxpayers' money in the form of Medicare payments-and it is taxpayers' money, because the Medicare levy does not cover the costs of medical care in Australia. So we are seeing an abuse of taxpayers' money.

We do not know the exact size of the problem, but we are told by the Department of Community Services and Health, the Royal Australian College of Radiol- ogists and the Australian Medical Association that it is significant. We really only received anecdotal evidence rather than quantitative evidence. My concern is that the Department of Community Services and Health has refused to provide the shadow Minister with quantitative evidence of the size of the problem. Surely this evidence exists and can be obtained by researching provider numbers and medical profiles. It would seem to be appropriate to back something that we may agree with, but it is also appropriate to see the extent of the abuse which the Government is trying to prevent.

We support the fact that the Government has tried to close this loophole. The proposed system will allow the general practitioner and the radiologist to continue practising and even practising on the same premises, but only if a normal commercial relationship exists between them; that is, if there is a proper charging of rents, rates and medical expenses. We support that.

One of the areas we do have problems with, and one of the reasons that we have referred this to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs, is the restriction on the types of X-rays that can be undertaken by general practitioners. There has not been evidence to suggest that this type of overservicing is significant. I think Dr Woods in his speech in the House of Representatives indicated that, of the 25,798 GPs in Australia, about 1,172 take spinal X-rays in their own practices. Only 109 of these take more than one spinal X-ray per week. Only nine take more than one spinal X-ray per day.

These figures show that it is quite easy to detect cases of general practitioners who may be undertaking excessive or unnecessary X-rays. It does not take much to follow up those few. We know there are only 109 general practitioners who take more than one spinal X-ray per week. There are relatively few GPs who undertake X-rays anyway. The majority of medical practitioners use their professional judgment to refer X-rays that require a great degree of speciality, and maybe very costly equipment, to specialist radiologists. So only a few general practitioners could be accused of overservicing.

There is no evidence that there is a problem with the health or safety of patients or the ability of GPs to perform these services. There is no evidence that the Government's proposal will benefit patients at all. In fact, the proposal may be financially detrimental, because patients will have to pay for a second consultation subsequent to having the X-ray taken outside the GP's surgery. Also, there is the further cost on Medicare. The other thing is that in country areas a considerable journey may be involved for a patient who is ill. We would like to see medical practitioners, who have ensured that they have the expertise and the equipment to undertake more complex X-rays, exercise their professional right to do so.

The Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) foreshadowed in his second reading speech that there would be the provision of a grandfather clause that would allow some GPs to continue performing restricted X-rays until 1 January 1993 and that any exemption beyond that date would depend on the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners developing a general practitioner radiology accreditation and quality control program. I found it interesting that we did not see the amendment in the House of Representatives and, as far as I know, we have not had the amendment here. The Minister foreshadowed this amendment in his second reading speech and we have not seen it.

Given that we have some concerns about this part of the Bill and that a number of people have come to us with concerns, we thought it appropriate that the relevant Senate committee examine the amendments that have been put forward in the House of Representatives. I give notice that I will be moving the amendments in the committee stage of this Bill. The Senate Committee has been given notice of those amendments so that they can discuss them. Given the fact that the Minister has foreshadowed the insertion of a grandfather clause, which did not appear and has not yet appeared, we believe that it is appropriate that the Senate Committee examine the matter. Perhaps when the Minister has had time to consider the matter, we will see that grandfather clause, or at least the Committee will find out why the grandfather clause has not been included.
As I said, I will be moving the series of amendments in the committee stage of the Bill. I seek leave to incorporate those amendments that I will be moving in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The amendments read as follows-
(1) Clause 14, page 7, proposed subsection 16b (1), line 22, after ``subsections (6),'' insert ``(6a),''.
(2) Clause 14, page 8, proposed section 16b, after subsection (6) insert the following subsection:
``[Exemption-professional discretion]
`(6a) Subsection (1) does not apply if the providing practitioner was a medical practitioner:
(a) who determined that the service was necessary;
(b) who used professional judgment to determine that to render the service was within his or her expertise; and
(c) whose patient the person was.' ''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are addressing this evening the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). I am sharing the responsibility of debating this Bill at the second reading stage with my colleague, Senator Lees, so I will be restricting my remarks to division 3 of the Bill which deals with prohibited diagnostic imaging practices. Senator Lees will be addressing other sections of this Bill which seek to amend parts of health legislation in various other Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: The background to this particular division is that, unfortunately, as Senator Patterson has just indicated, there are some among my former colleagues who have abused their privilege as professional people. Initially, in relation to more specialist services, this practice came to light on the provision of pathology services where general practitioners were providing unnecessary pathology services and charging for them. This became particularly obnoxious when automated devices for doing large numbers of tests became available.

Some of those excessive tests were clearly a great burden on the public purse. This also exposed patients to unnecessary risks of having blood, various body fluids and so on taken as specimens. That loophole was closed, and division 3 of this Bill before us seeks to do much the same sort of thing with respect to the taking of X-rays. As Senator Patterson indicated a moment ago, the Bill seeks a clear arms-length relationship between a general practitioner and the specialist who takes the X-rays or, as it is described, diagnostic imaging services. That, of course, extends beyond X-rays, but most of what we are talking about involves the taking of X-rays.

This section seeks to ensure that that arms-length relationship shall hold. We have no objection to the principle which lies behind that, because unfortunately that loophole does exist. If general practitioners take their own X-rays, there is an opportunity to order unnecessary X-ray exposure and to collect fees for that. If they refer a patient to a specialist, there is an opportunity to receive kick-backs by way of what is called in the profession fee splitting from professional radiologists. That is also an objectionable practice.

In relation to X-rays, there is a further reason why one should be very wary of unnecessary exposure. Exposure to X-rays is not without risk. I will have to diverge somewhat here from what Senator Patterson has just said, in that it seems to me that the sort of equipment which general practitioners would have available for their immediate use is likely to be of the less expensive, less current kind and, therefore, more likely to expose patients to higher levels of radiation than the most modern and expensive equipment-more likely to be found in the offices of specialist radiologists. I think that, for reasons of both economy and excessive exposure of patients to X-rays, we need to address this matter seriously.

I have no complaint whatsoever with the intention which lies behind this section. It has already been explained that the practice of those general practitioners who have traditionally taken a range of X-rays and provided a range of X-ray services, to the extent it has been done in the past, will continue into the future. Eventually that practice will be replaced by the accreditation of general practitioners under the scheme which has recently been introduced as a result of other legislation and a Senate committee report.

It is envisaged that general practitioners who wish to take their own X-ray images will be accredited, I presume, to take either a range of X-rays or perhaps a limited number of types of X-rays. That seems to be highly desirable, particularly in view of the risk of exposing people to excessive or indeed to any amount of X-irradiation because any amount carries a certain risk. A person behaving in a fully professional and competent manner should seek to minimise absolutely the amount of X-irradiation to which people are exposed and ensure that the benefit arising from that irradiation will, as far as possible, be judged to be greater than the risk associated with the exposure.
Having said that, we have some slight problem with one clause of this legislation. Proposed new section 23 dzg (c), under the heading `Prohibited diagnostic imaging practices', reads:

. . . the person is a practitioner, or the employer of a practitioner, who, without reasonable excuse, asks, receives or obtains, or agrees to receive or obtain, any property, benefit or advantage of any kind for himself or herself, or any other person, from a service provider or a person acting on behalf of the service provider;

When one takes those words literally and interprets them broadly, that excludes the use of any ordering of x-rays by any general practitioner at all. Turning the wording around, where it says that a practitioner may not receive an advantage of any kind for himself or herself, clearly when a general practitioner orders an X-ray for a patient and a disease is found in the patient as a result of the interpretation of the X-ray by a radiologist, that doctor is then able to better manage the patient and has been given some advantage from ordering the X-ray.

If one takes a broad reading of that section, one finds that effectively doctors would be prevented from taking X-rays at all. Clearly that is not what is intended; some narrower reading of the section is intended. Where it says `or obtains . . . property, benefit or advantage of any kind', clearly it is referring to advantages of a pecuniary kind or advantages which could be generally interpreted to be of a pecuniary kind, such as a lower rental in a building or something like that which could be translated into a pecuniary advantage.

The section as it is worded is broadly drawn and it catches some practices which I believe are inappropriate to catch. I give the example of the Pacific Medical Centre, which has approached me on this matter. The Pacific Medical Centre leases rooms to general practitioners; at the same time, the centre employs a radiographer, and a general practitioner in that medical centre may order an X-ray to be taken of a patient and may ask for that X-ray to be taken anywhere at all, but may choose to use the radiographer who works in the medical centre. That would seem reasonable because it is in the same building. The X-ray is then sent off to a radiologist for interpretation; that radiologist reports on the X-ray and gives some part of the fee back to the radiographer because there is no mechanism within Medicare for a radiographer, as such, to charge a fee for the taking of an X-ray.

The relationship between the general practitioner and the other practitioner providing a service-that is, the radiologist who interprets the X-ray-is at arm's length. There is no advantage to the general practitioner from ordering an X-ray and there is no mechanism which connects the general practitioner to that particular radiologist because the general practitioner may well ask for the X-ray to be taken somewhere else or indeed send the patient off to a specialist radiologist somewhere else.

TALK.START.PARA: —So the legislation would not apply.

—I am glad that Senator Walters interjected because this operation is caught by the words `or any other person'. It is extremely difficult to see why these words are there when the whole section is attempting to ensure an arm's length relationship between one professional person and another professional person so that there are no kickbacks or advantages in ordering extra, additional or unnecessary diagnostic imaging services.

SPEECH.PARA: I have just been handed my proposed amendments. I suggest that the words `or any other person' in proposed new section 23 dzg (c) be deleted. The deletion of those words would not in any way remove the intention of the section but would ensure that it does not unnecessarily catch an operation such as the Pacific Medical Centre, where, as far as I can see, there is no illicit practice, no kickbacks and no loophole for the possibility of abuse. To ensure that the words `property, benefit or advantage of any kind' are properly understood, I suggest that the words `directly or indirectly' be inserted between the words `obtain' and `any property'. That is simply doubly dotting i's and doubly crossing t's to ensure that emphasis is given to the nature of the advantage.

That is the only other matter I wish to address. As I have indicated, we support the thrust of this legislation. It is an unfortunate matter of history that in the past there has been abuse of pathology diagnostic services. That loophole was closed and we have since operated very well under the system. However, there is potential here for abuse in the system and it is appropriate to close it. As far as possible, the operation of diagnostic X-ray services should come under the professional control of people who really understand the danger of exposure to X-irradiation and indeed have the best and most recent equipment so as to obtain the best images with the least exposure. That is a not inconsiderable reason when one realises that some estimates suggest that roughly half the X-rays taken in Australia are taken unnecessarily.

In this country people are exposed to quite large amounts of X-irradiation. As there is a linear dose response relationship between radiation exposure and mutagenic effects, resulting in birth defects, cancer and so on, not only the doses to individuals but also the total community dose of X-irradiation should be kept as low as possible. For those reasons, we find ourselves in strong support of this section. As this Bill is going to a Senate committee tomorrow, we are putting this amendment on the table now.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not going until Friday week.

—I am corrected; I thought it was going tomorrow. But it is going to a Senate committee, and it is appropriate that we put this proposed amendment before the Committee so it has plenty of opportunity to look at it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No 2). It is divided into two parts. One part amends the Health Insurance Act and the second part amends the National Health Act and the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act. I intend to debate only that part which deals with the Health Insurance Act because my colleague Senator Patterson has dealt very thoroughly with the National Health Act and the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act. Several proposed amendments have been put by the Government to alter the Health Insurance Act. Two of these we agree with and the third one we do not agree with. I will deal first with those two that we do agree with because it will be simpler that way.

SPEECH.PARA: The first relates to the closing of the loopholes for those doctors who have been deregistered or delicensed in one State. When that occurs-and it is very rare-it is for a very serious reason. But the medical practitioner in the past has been able to overcome this by simply moving from the State in which he is deregistered to another State where he takes up practice and is able to carry on as though nothing has happened, even during the time of his deregistration. We believe that this is not appropriate and therefore we support the Government's action in saying that, if a doctor has been deregistered or delicensed, should he attempt to take up practice in another State his patients should not be entitled to a Medicare refund. The Government has done that by redefining `medical practitioner' in the Health Insurance Act.

The second area on which we agree is that area where a problem exists in the medical centres. The Government has brought this on entirely of its own making-nothing more, nothing less. The Government's ideology of encouraging bulk billing-and it encourages it very vigorously-has been the source of this great problem. It is the infamous Edelsten centres and all the similar entrepreneurial centres throughout Australia that have created this problem. Instead of the Government doing something sensible about it by abolishing bulk billing for all except the disadvantaged patients-all the card holders, all the pensioners, et cetera-it insisted on its ideology and said that doctors should bulk bill. This only encourages the problem that we are faced with in this Bill tonight.

We have the entrepreneurs setting up clinics. They are not even doctors. They are businessmen, all sorts of people. They set up these medical centres. They employ doctors and specialists, and they get a very large financial reward. As has already been pointed out tonight, many of them employ doctors who are unethical. We find that a general practitioner will order X-rays to be done by the radiologist in such a centre when in some cases-many cases, no doubt-those X-rays are not needed. So we find that the general practitioner is able to order an X-ray and send the patient on to the radiologist, and they share in the finance of that particular order-on, as well as the entrepreneur, who has his fingers in the till too.

I mentioned the very infamous case that we are all aware of, the Edelsten centres, that were first set up in New South Wales. When that particular doctor was deregistered in New South Wales, he immediately moved to Victoria. As I indicated earlier, the closing of the loophole of the deregistered doctor moving from State to State will stop that sort of thing occurring. These entrepreneurial centres are rife in New South Wales, but in my state of Tasmania they have not arrived, and I hope they never will.

Let me explain to honourable senators what has happened in my State because I think it is a very salutary exercise for these entrepreneurs. We had a Mr Rodney Richards come down from the mainland boasting that he was the one who had set up all the Edelsten centres throughout Australia and he intended to do so in Hobart, and throughout the whole of Tasmania following his undoubted success in Hobart. As we know, these centres are very plush, with chandeliers, plush carpet, velvet lounges, grand pianos, soft music and dim lights-the whole lot. The patient goes in feeling like a king or queen, gets treatment, and is sent around to the various specialists in the centre and, because all of this is bulk billed-with the blessing of the Government-the taxpayer has to foot the bill.

Mr Rodney Richards came down to try to do the same in Tasmania. He built a large centre which included the $7,000 chandelier, the plush carpets and the velvet lounges, all set up with the most elaborate advertising campaign one can imagine. He boasted that he had entered Tasmania and intended to set up the same type of centres he had set up for Dr Edelsten in the rest of Australia. Tasmania is different from other States in the Commonwealth. The local doctors refused point-blank to take part in the centre. Rodney Richards not only did all he could to entice doctors to do so but also threatened them. Indeed, the President of the Australian Medical Association (AMA) had death threats because of the action he took in opposing this sort of centre. He was invited, very lucratively, to be part of it. Of course, he refused.

It was not just the local practitioners that did not accept Rodney Richards's invitation. It did not seem to matter where he went in Tasmania. Even though he attempted to bring in South African doctors, he was thwarted. So the clinic has not gone ahead. This very lush centre is still completely empty. No radiologists in Tasmania would serve in it and no general practitioners would serve in it. Finally, Mr Richards has had to leave. He said he pulled out because he was being harassed by his financiers on the mainland.

The Australian doctors fund assisted the local practitioners in explaining to the public why they were not going to support such a clinic. It is very enticing for a patient to be told, `Here is this luxurious accommodation. You can come in and have a complete overhaul-X-rays and all the treatment you could possibly desire-and it will not cost you a cent'. One can hardly blame patients for thinking this was a rather wonderful idea.

If we look at what Medicare benefits actually cost us, we find that in New South Wales, where these entrepreneurs abound and where these sorts of centres are set up all over the place, 61 per cent of general practitioners' fees are bulkbilled. In Tasmania, 47 per cent of fees are bulkbilled. The cost of doctors' fees per head, that is, for every man, woman and child, to the taxpayer in New South Wales-and I think it would be a good idea if Senator McMullan heard this because it might change his philosophy-is $225. In Tasmania, it is $174 for every man, woman and child.

If the cost in Tasmania equalled that in New South Wales, an additional $22 1/2m would be taken out of taxpayers' pockets through Medicare, all because of the idiocy of the Government's ideology that bulkbilling is a good idea and encourages these entrepreneurs-entrepreneurs who are not medical practitioners-to set up such centres. Then the Government complains of abuse of the system. We agree that because of the abuse that the Government has been responsible for encouraging, there should be an arm's length arrangement for X-rays. We support the Government in this, even though we believe that it is going about it incorrectly.

The thing that I and other Opposition members disagree with is that the Government is now attempting in this legislation to override the professional and medical judgment of the practitioner. It tells us that general practitioners' patients will receive Medicare benefits only if general practitioners take X-rays of extremities, chests and abdomens. For any X-ray of the spine that the general practitioner, in his medical judgment, sees as necessary, the patient will not receive a Medicare rebate.

Tonight Senator Coulter agreed with that change to the legislation. He made the sweeping statement that it is needed because some general practitioners' equipment may not be up to standard. If he believes that and if he is quite serious, he should say that for any X-rays taken with substandard equipment the patient should not receive a Medicare rebate. But he does not say that. He just says that general practitioners with substandard equipment should not have access to Medicare benefits. If a specialist has the older type of equipment, bully for him. His patients can still get the benefit even if he happens to have the same sort of equipment as the general practitioner. It just does not make sense to go down that line.

The Government is taking action to interfere with the professional judgment of the medical profession. I believe that it is the thin edge of the wedge. The Government is saying that no matter how much a general practitioner believes his patient needs an X-ray at the time, he cannot do it unless it is for certain areas of the body.

Let us look at how big the problem is, as did Dr Bob Woods, our shadow Minister for health in the House of Representatives. He said that there were something like 25,798 general practitioners in Australia-that is, nearly 26,000 general practitioners-and of those only 1,172 have actually taken X-rays of the spine. That brings the figure down a bit and puts it into perspective. Only 1,172 general practitioners out of nearly 26,000 have taken X-rays of the spine. He went on to say that out of that 1,172 only 109 took more than one X-ray of the spine per week. Nine have taken more than one per day.

The Government already has in place all sorts of mechanisms for accusing doctors of overservicing. It has doctors' profiles from which it can say that it believes that those nine doctors are overservicing. It can have them checked out. There may be quite legitimate reasons for a general practitioner to take as many X-rays as he is taking. He may be specialising in backs in his own way in some country area. He may specialise in insurance work.

There may or may not be a legitimate reason for the X-rays being taken, but the Government is able to establish that quite easily without passing special legislation to deal with nine general practitioners. I am surprised that Senator Coulter believes that this is the way we should go about dealing with nine medical practitioners who may or may not be abusing the system.

To me it is very obvious why the Government is going about the matter in this way. It has always maintained that it should have the say over what doctors are doing and charging. It is now attempting, through backdoor methods, to say just what it believes general practitioners should do. This is the thin end of the wedge. Of course, it is quite qualified to do it. The Government is there to say that it does not believe that doctors should X-ray certain parts of the body, and so it will not allow Medicare benefits to those doctors who do.

The Australian Medical Association and the Royal Australasian College of Radi- ologists have agreed that this should take place. It is going to be very interesting when the AMA and the College of Radi- ologists appear before us next Friday week. They are coming before the Committee and I will be most interested to hear what they have to say in this regard. The radiologists told me recently that this occurs in other areas. I remember how upset they were when the Government refused to allow access to Medicare benefits by all of their patients who were having magnetic resonance imagings-MRIs-if it was done outside certain hospitals. They were very concerned and they lobbied me and said that it was not fair, that their patients should be entitled to these benefits. It is all right for them; it is not all right for the general practitioners. It will be very interesting next Friday week when they appear before us to find out why they believe it is all right for the goose but not for the gander.

As far as the AMA is concerned, I am not quite sure what it is up to. If it wants this centralised Government to keep having a finger in the pie as to what it is entitled or not entitled to do, I will be very interested to see the result. I believe the Government is entering this field because it likes to have a say in what doctors do and what they cannot do. It provides another foot in the door for the Government when it can deal with the matter very efficiently through its over- servicing mechanisms. I am very concerned that this is the way the Government is going and that the Australian Democrats see this method as overcoming a problem of nine general practitioners who appear to be taking more X-rays of the spine than they should be.
As I said earlier, my colleague dealt with the other areas of the Bill. I see no point in going over the same areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented by the previous speaker and I wish to make a personal explanation.
—The honourable senator may proceed.

—It was claimed that I had said that general practitioners were using substandard equipment. I did not say that at all. All radiographic equipment has to be inspected by State inspectorates and all radiographic equipment has to conform with certain standards. However, what I did say was that the newer equipment was able to take high quality pictures with less exposure to radiation than some of the older equipment, even though the older equipment may conform. A professional person who is in full time radiological service-a radiologist-is more likely to have the more modern equipment, the more expensive equipment, and therefore expose a person to less radiation than a general practitioner whose practice comprises only a tiny fraction of X-raying and who is likely to have older equipment. While it would conform with the standard, it would nonetheless expose people to higher levels of radiation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish only to speak on one area of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990, the other area having been covered already by my colleague Senator Coulter. I will be dealing only with the charter of residents' rights and responsibilities in approved hostels and nursing homes. This is one part of a two-part package which also contains the agreement that will be considered by this chamber some time within the next couple of weeks.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite last minute disagreements-very public disagreements-the charter and the agreement represent the outcome of very responsible and extensive consultations. These have been carried out over the last two years by the Government. We believe that in this case these consultations were broad and proper, and I want to stress that this is a most refreshing exception to this Government's usual style of bulldozing ahead regardless; of not consulting, or at best consulting in a very minimal and casual manner.

In particular, I wish to contrast the process that has occurred here with the process that occurred in relation to the $2.50 pharmaceutical charge and the deeming provisions which we are still dealing with in this chamber. In those cases they have not only caused considerable difficulties for elderly citizens, but also the actual stress that has been placed upon senior members of our community and the anxiety and concern that have been caused will surely mean that consultation processes such as we have now seen with the charter will in future be the pro- cess that the Government will follow.

In this particular case with regard to the charter, I do want to congratulate the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, Mr Staples, and his staff for the long, tedious and sometimes difficult consultation that has occurred. Unfortunately, some of the peak bodies that have taken part in these negotiations and consultations do not appear to have been in regular touch with their own constituents. Some of the difficulties that we now see and some of the very public comments that have been made, I believe, have come out of a breakdown in communication within some of these groups. It has been most unfortunate that this has all occurred at the last minute.

I want to stress that the Australian Democrats very strongly support the charter and the agreement that goes with it. It is most unfortunate but true that there has been, and still is, a very small minority of nursing homes which abuse the trust placed in them by residents and their relatives in the community who, after all, are the ones who subsidise these positions in nursing homes and hostels. While it is fair to say that the level of abuse varies, whatever the level, we believe it should be and must be a priority of Government to make sure that constraints are imposed, and the rights and responsibilities laid down in this charter will go a long way towards doing that. We have only recently seen the closure of a home in Victoria, and I trust and hope that the Minister will be more energetic than his predecessors in pursuing and closing those homes that are not caring properly for their elderly residents.

The enormous growth that we have seen over the past 20 years in this industry has had very little by way of regulation to follow it until very recent times. We acknowledge that the Government is taking significant and positive steps to rectify this situation. We also want to state that we believe it is a great credit to the Australian Nursing Homes Association that it has been involved very extensively in the development of this charter and agreement. It has been involved in a very sensible and positive way. It has seen and acknowledged its potential for enhancing the services provided by the Association's members.

The area of aged care still requires significant reform, especially in relation to community and home based care. I think the Government needs to look very seriously at the way it funds these types of care, and it needs to take immediate steps to overcome the split between Commonwealth and State responsibilities in this area.

The charter and the agreement represent but one plank of the Government's eight-stage strategy to reform nursing home care, and it needs to be seen in that context, as part of a much broader strategy. We welcome these documents but wish to stress that we believe there is still a need, firstly, for more advocacy services, particularly outside the metropolitan areas; secondly, for Commonwealth pressures on those States that have not introduced guardianship legislation and protection of estate legislation to do so; and, thirdly, to ensure that standards are monitored and enforced.

These documents should not be seen as signalling even the slightest shift away from a wholehearted commitment to outcome standards and the rigorous monitoring and enforcing of those standards. We do not believe that we can simply now hand over to the residents responsibility for totally monitoring the services provided. Finally, we believe that we still need a vastly improved financial commitment generally from the Commonwealth in relation to nursing homes and hostels, particularly in respect of the hours of care each patient is entitled to receive.

As I mentioned, we are generally supportive of the charter but it does not give nursing home residents additional rights to those they already have. What it is doing is ensuring that the rights the residents previously enjoyed simply move with them and carry on into the nursing homes and hostels. It ensures that their rights are protected.

The Democrats will be moving a number of amendments in the committee stage to the charter and an even larger number of amendments to the agreement when it is tabled. The amendments are mainly intended to address the practical concerns and difficulties, to allay some of the concerns of consumer and industry groups, as well as to tighten certain provisions.

I do not want to speak for too long tonight. I will conclude by saying that the charter and agreement have the potential to greatly enhance the rights of residents in all nursing homes and hostels whether operated by private, religious or voluntary organisations. Combined with other policies being pursued by the Government and with some positive developments in these areas in various States, we believe the charter and agreement offer the best chance in many years of improving the delivery of nursing home and hostel services to those people who have to move out of their own homes and into this type of care.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990. I wish to direct my remarks this evening to those aspects of the Bill that deal primarily with changes to the practice of radiology in Australia. While the coalition does not oppose those changes that prevent what can be an abuse of the system through the association of specialist radiologists with certain medical centres associated with bulkbilling, it does oppose what are heavy-handed, bureaucratic restrictions on the professional judgment of doctors as to who and what they should X-ray.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition agrees that it is proper to insist that there be in effect an arm's length professional relationship between a general practitioner who requests an X-ray and a specialist. There should be financial and, in general, physical separation between specialists and medical centres. I do not believe that the problem of specialists in effect using their names for bulkbilling is necessarily widespread, with the medical centre actually owning and operating the X-rays. Nonetheless, the coalition has consulted with the representative bodies of the medical profession and has been told that the problem does exist.

Therein lies the difference between the coalition and the Government. The coalition is prepared to consult with practitioners to find out what their position is, in the same way that it is prepared to consult with any interested body on any piece of legislation. Of course, not coincidentally this piece of legislation also contains items about residents' rights. I recall quite clearly the Minister for Community Services and Health, Mr Staples, saying after the event, after he had announced it and after various nursing homes had kicked up sufficient fuss, that what the Government was doing was wrong. He then said, `We might consult'.

I do not think it has ever crossed the mind of this Government to consult beforehand. Quite frankly, I believe that that is how change should be examined, particularly in this area-by first of all asking the health professionals concerned for the integrity and reality of medicine. This is, to say the least, not always the approach of the Hawke Labor Government in regard to health.

Of course, this Government always believes that it can do better for a patient, whether it is in the delivery of straight-out medical services, whether it is in the delivery of pharmaceuticals or whether it is in the delivery of radiology or pathology-and the list goes on. I find it rather sad that this is all geared to dollars and cents because the Medicare system has failed this country miserably.

In supporting a necessary check on an undesirable practice, I would at the same time note that the problem has arisen through what can be described as bulkbilling medical centres. A little earlier, my colleague Senator Walters described the Geoffrey Edelsten medical centres where all of this ran riot. If one were to say that all of this legislation had to be geared to wipe out those types of practices, that would be fine. But that is not the reality. Those practices are not the manifestation of a predatory free market in medicine. They are the direct result of the socialistic Medicare policy of this Labor Government that seeks to encourage bulkbilling and then professes concern when the national cost of medical services rockets and a few entrepreneurial doctors take advantage of the situation.

It is this Government that has created the problem. It is this Government that continues to insist that the health system is self-financing when in fact we know that it is hard-pressed even to self-finance through the levy 30 per cent of the cost of medicine. And yet the Government pushes on, hoping that people will believe it.

Again, I must emphasise to the Senate that the Minister for Community Services and Health actually boasts that 55 per cent of all medical services are now bulkbilled, including 65 per cent of general practitioners' services. The Government actually boasts about that but therein, once again, lies the problem. The Government is not prepared to correct the problem. It is not prepared to look at the root cause of the problem. It just wants to put a bandaid on the bucket wherever it can and make the final judgment as a government on who best can deliver health services.

The Minister and his Government should be especially pleased that in New South Wales the rate of bulkbilling has reached 75 per cent. It is no coincidence that this State has been regarded as the main area of entrepreneurial medical clinics. If people can get away with it, they will. And people are getting away with it, so they continue. Does the Government change that practice? No. It still encourages more and more bulkbilling.

While there is an unquantified but real problem in the relationship between some specialists and medical centres, any supposed problem in regard to overservicing by general practitioners through the use of spinal X-rays can be identified precisely. The facts of the matter are that of just under 26,000 general practitioners in Australia-25,798-only 1,172, on last available figures, actually took spinal X-rays. This is less than 5 per cent of the total. Only 109 of these doctors take more than one spinal X-ray per week and exactly nine take more than one such X-ray per day, which equates to less than one per cent of general practitioners taking spinal X-rays.

We are talking about a practice by less than one per cent of general practitioners that this Bill is designed to stop. I ask: how much more absurd is this Government going to get? If it was a big problem, one could understand the need for legislation. It is such a small problem and in most cases spinal X-rays are warranted. Yet, this Government sees the need to swat flies with sledge-hammers. This Hawke Labor Government is, therefore, changing the law to prevent general practitioners from taking spinal X-rays because of the practice profiles of literally a mere handful of doctors.

It is a classic example of the regulatory, bureaucratic approach of this Government, and the coalition will move amendments to clause 14 in order to delete it. It will, of course, be up to the Australian Democrats to decide whether they are prepared to back the commonsense and integrity of the medical profession and support this amendment. I do hope that the Australian Democrats will back the medical profession, as opposed to backing the Government, because there is great sense in making sure that it is the medical profession that delivers quality health care and not some government that believes it can do so.

When this amendment was moved and defeated in the disgracefully short time allocated to this Bill in the House of Representatives, the Minister did not even bother to respond to the argument of the coalition. The Government decided to allocate about 30 to 40 minutes of total debate to a Bill as substantial as this. The week before last the Government decided to guillotine through the House of Representatives 39 Bills in three days, allowing an average of 30 to 40 minutes debate on each Bill. Is it any wonder that there was no proper debate and no opportunity for commonsense to prevail? But, of course, the simple attitude of this Government is `Who cares?'.

As a matter of principle we do not believe that Ministers and departmental officials should be telling qualified practitioners what services they can supply to those patients who in their judgment require them. Quite clearly, the Government has shown that it is not imposing this restriction for reasons of medical safety. If this were the case doctors in isolated areas would not be permitted under this Bill to continue to provide spinal X-rays.

The Government certainly cannot say that the whole background of this piece of legislation is to protect the patient for medical reasons. This Labor Government decrees that general practitioners may X-ray chests, abdomens and extremities, but not spines. This is frankly an absurd and demeaning restriction placed upon the medical profession for non-medical reasons. I suppose one does not necessarily need a particularly vivid imagination to understand why it would not want spines X-rayed; I suppose it would be fairly difficult to X-ray a jellyback. There would not be too many on the Government side who would have any bones that would show up in an X-ray either.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. I understand that Senator Knowles was referring to a member of another place and ask that her comment be withdrawn.
—It is not unparliamentary.
—Did I hear you talk about a jellyback?
—Who is that?
—I was trying to pay attention to Senator Knowles' remarks. I do not know whether I did.
—Senator Knowles, I think if you withdrew that word and rephrased that sentence the Minister would be happy.
—With due respect, Madam Acting Deputy President, I did not mention a name. I have simply mentioned the word `jellyback'; no names. Is that an unparliamentary word?
—I do not really think it is an unparliamentary expression. I have heard many worse unparliamentary expressions in this chamber previously. No-one was mentioned by name, Minister.
—If there was no linking to any member of either chamber-I thought that there was-then I do not take offence.
—I thank the Minister and you, Madam Acting Deputy President.
—They are a bit too sensitive over there.

—Senator Walters is quite right. This whole thing really does make a farce of the professed concern of the Hawke Labor Government. Only last year it required the higher training of general practitioners through changes to Medicare rebates. The profession is now to have its judgment overridden and a further restriction placed upon the doctor-patient relationship.

SPEECH.PARA: In one essential respect, the Hawke Labor Government is perfectly consistent. It is unwavering in its resolve to legislate, little by little, more centralised control over medicine and, in particular, the general practitioners who are in constant interaction with the Australian public. If I needed medical attention I would prefer to see my general practitioner than to see the Minister for Community Services and Health, Mr Howe, Dr non-medical Blewett, or any of these people who happen to profess to know more about medicine than my general practitioner.

It does not greatly matter what the pretext is for this centralised interference with medical judgment. A rebate of $122 for a full spinal X-ray is significant, but it still does not amount to a major financial problem when only a handful of doctors may be abusing the system. I use the term `may' advisedly. Unlike the supporters of this Labor Government, I do not condemn doctors simply on the basis of statistics. The fact remains that any abuse by so small a number of doctors can easily be investigated, not in respect of the number of X-rays, but whether they were medically necessary.

I come back to the same point time and time again: who is best equipped to decide whether a patient needs an X-ray, a doctor or this Government? I put to you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that it is the doctor. The procedures are already in place for the investigation of any such overservicing and there is absolutely no reason for intrusive legislation on the matter.

The coalition supports another aspect of the legislation-the provision for a committee of medical peers to examine questions of overservicing, providing that it is in practice independent and representative. With such a mechanism there will be even less need for a blanket prohibition on spinal X-rays offered by general practitioners. The logic escapes this Government, or rather it regards the question as irrelevant and distracting from its real purpose of doing what comes naturally-regulating doctors for the sake of it.

The observation must again be made that overservicing will inevitably arise so long as this Labor Government encourages bulkbilling. It may not be a matter of doctors supplying unnecessary services, but of some members of the public seeking supposedly free consultations. There is one area that really highlights how bulk billing is abused by many people. Senator Walters could correct me but I think it was only last year when information was supplied to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs, inquiring into health matters, which said that during the course of World Expo 88 in Brisbane the number of people who actually visited bulkbilling doctors declined. When Expo was finished it increased. People had something else to do. Yet this Government continues to push forward on bulkbilling. It may not be a matter of doctors supplying unnecessary services. True to form, it is the medical profession once again that is scapegoated for the inherent failings of Labor's health policy.

There have and will be far more significant pieces of legislation that affect the medical profession than aspects of this Bill to which I have referred. Nonetheless, the people of Australia should be aware that quietly this Labor Government is taking another step in restricting the professional freedom of general practitioners for non-medical reasons. Next year perhaps abdominal X-rays will be banned if a dozen general practitioners are said to be performing an excessive number. The precedent that this aspect of the Bill sets threatens proper doctor-patient relationships even further, and the coalition opposes it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank those honourable senators who contributed to the second reading debate on this particularly important legislation relating to community services and health. I believe that the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990 deserves to be given a second reading by the chamber. I will briefly outline the main features which I believe should commend the Bill to the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators will know that the Bill contains a number of Government initiatives relating to care for the aged, Medicare, therapeutic goods and nurse education. Of course, there will be great discussion at the committee stage in relation to the charter of residents rights and responsibilities for approved nursing homes which form a schedule to the Act in accordance with previous decisions of this chamber. I believe it is encouraging to hear the support that was notified by the Australian Democrats for the general outline of this particular charter and the dependent agreement.

I believe that the charter and the agreement reflect the basic philosophy of this Government. It is that those who, at a stage in their life when they are frail and becoming somewhat more feeble than in their more youthful and hearty days, move from their ordinary accommodation into a hostel or nursing home should carry with them as many of the usual rights, expectations and dignities accompanying their home life-in this particular case I am considering nursing homes-as is possible and which are compatible with their growing frailty and their need and dependence on others for their personal care.

If people are in a communal situation and a situation of growing dependence in a community of fellow residents and in a nursing home which may have a particular outlook-and of course we are talking about a whole range of such accommodation for the elderly-I think it is important to retain fundamental rights and expectations. It is important that a person not lose those matters which are important to their individual dignity when they make the transition outlined in the charter and agreement contained in the Government's proposition. As I say, no doubt that will receive extensive examination in the committee stage. I do not seek to dwell on matters which have been of great controversy over the last several weeks, but the philosophy of Government is a very sound one and I believe that, as I say, the Bill should receive the support of the chamber.

Two further measures in this Bill are important to the care of the aged in our Australian community. The first relates to the inclusion of the private sector in the Commonwealth's aged care hostel program. Of course that refers to recurrent funding. I believe it is an important matter which should encourage growth in the number of places available in hostels for our aged population. There is also the abolition of the hostel care subsidy for persons who are not financially disadvantaged. I understand that this aroused some concern during the second reading debate but the idea behind the abolition of the subsidy is to enable the hostel to receive from those residents who are assessed as financially better placed to contribute to the costs of their care such a contribution rather than receive that particular funding amount from the general taxpayer.

This is a difficult and delicate area but quite clearly there will be occasions when those who are not financially disadvantaged are in a position to make a greater contribution by way of fee to the funding necessary for the running of a hostel. In that situation, the Government considers that that extra fee ought to be forthcoming. Of course, that will enable a greater amount of government funding to truly support those who are otherwise without the financial resources to pay a substantial or significant contribution towards the residence that they occupy.

Some other matters are of great significance in the practical living of persons within the nursing homes. I know from my experience in Tasmania that the ability of persons to take unlimited medical leave when they require hospital care and up to 28 days social leave each year will be greatly welcomed as it enables people to undertake that hospital care or to have 28 days in every year away from the nursing home with the absolute security that that bed will be available to them when they return from hospital or from that recreational or social leave. That gives a certain sense of security without the feeling of entrapment, and I think that is an extremely important part of the measure before us this evening.

I could go through various other sections, but I ought to deal with the questions of unethical practices which, I think it is acknowledged generally, have grown up, particularly those relating to radiology services. Generally speaking, those radiology services ought to be paid for by way of Medicare in cases where the service has been provided at the request of a practitioner who has no direct financial interest in the ordering of those services. The Government believes it is important that such a nexus not exist and will take steps to ensure that that unethical practice is curbed.

It is known that this is not something that has simply emerged from the Government. I recall that former Senator Georges, the then Chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, stated that what that Committee had discovered in the area of pathology seemed to be emerging in some instances in relation to radiology.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only where it is bulk billing, nowhere else.

—I do not know whether one can make such an exclusive and general claim but there is no doubt that there are various factors which lead to this overordering of services in a way which could be regarded as unethical, and I suppose the growth of entrepreneurial activity in the provision of radiology services is only one aspect of the entrepreneurial activity that is gripping some sections of medical practice.
—You know it has happened in Hobart.
—Without being caught up in responding to interjections, which I know I ought not-and you were about to reprimand both of us, I think, Madam Acting Deputy President--
—Yes. Senator Tate, you should address your remarks through the Chair.

—The fact is that in Hobart we do have an instance of this type of enterprise. I read something that made my stomach turn, a press release or a letter from a proponent of one of these centres saying it was going to have a $7,000 chandelier in the foyer and a 24-hour service. I would have thought that the ordinary residents of Hobart looking for medical care were not looking for that sort of lavish and sumptuous setting but simply wanted to have available to them a proper medical service. I know that the Australian Medical Association (AMA) in Tasmania, headed by the admirable Dr Nelson --
—Brendon Nelson.

—Brendon Nelson, who has a very good pedigree of social concern-I think he was a joint practitioner with Dr David Crean, the brother of Mr Simon Crean of another place, and, as I say, of impeccable pedigree in relation to social concern-is President of the AMA in Tasmania and has campaigned very effectively and actively to alert his fellow medical practitioners and fellow Tasmanians about the dangers of this type of practice.

SPEECH.PARA: I am getting a little side-tracked, Madam Acting Deputy President. The fact is that these medical entrepreneurs who were responsible for the emergence of self-referral radiology and other arrangements designed to encourage excessive services have been a blot on the copybook of the medical profession and I have no doubt that it is for that reason that the specific provisions in this Bill dealing with the introduction of a formal mechanism for the requesting of diagnostic imaging services and so on have now found the full support, as I understand it, of the Royal Australasian College of Radiologists, the Australian Medical Association and now the general practitioners through the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners.

I understand that honourable senators who have contributed to this debate have not given enough weight to the amendments to the Bill which were made at the House of Representatives committee stage by way of Government amendment, which enabled Dr Kinder, the Secretary-General of the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners, to put out a press release on 6 November 1990 quoting the College's President, Dr Buhagiar, as saying:

The college supports the Government's objectives with the legislation, but has been concerned to ensure the legitimate interests of General Practitioners providing diagnostic imaging services for their patients are effectively protected.
The Minister has shown a willingness to listen to reasoned argument and his co-operation on this matter will be welcomed by the General Practitioner community . . .

The College will be working closely with the Government and the Australasian College of Radiologists in the development of appropriate accreditation and quality assurance programmes for GPs providing diagnostic imaging services after 1 January, 1993.

With the inclusion of an amendment moved by the Government in the House of Representatives at the committee stage, one now has a situation where the fears and misgivings which Senator Walters was expressing on behalf of many general practitioners have, to a great extent, been allayed and the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners has given its support to this proposal along with the Royal Australasian College of Radiologists.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why I said that on Friday next it will be very interesting to see the response to our question.

—It will, and the committee stage of the passage of this Bill through the parliamentary process will be interesting. I believe that the proceedings next Friday morning-and I hope that they do not go into the afternoon because I have to leave for Hobart on the 1.45 p.m. flight; that will not be of interest to those listening to this debate on the radio-will be of great interest for many concerned with the charter and this aspect of this legislation as it makes its way through the parliamentary process. At this stage I commend the second reading to the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Clause 5, page 3, lines 34 to 36, omit proposed subsection 4b (2) and insert the following subsection:
