(b) the level of public liability and professional indemnity insurance cover taken out by the operator of the centre is adequate; and
(c) the centre has adopted appropriate audit and accountability standards.
2. Clause 5, page 3, lines 37 to 40, omit proposed 4c (1) and insert the following subsection:
``(1) The Minister may make guidelines, not inconsistent with this Act, with respect to the exercise of any of the Minister's powers under section 4b (1).''

By moving the first amendment, we seek to decouple the fee relief scheme which has now been extended to the private sector from the accreditation system. Indeed, that was a sleeping Trojan horse until fairly recently when the Government, through the agency of Senator Tate, was effectively flushed out during the examination of the Bill by the Standing Committee on Community Affairs. I would certainly be grateful if Senator Tate could tell me whether a copy of a letter which I wrote to Mr Staples, the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, on 15 November, and received by his office on that date, has come to the Minister's attention.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The officers with me from the Department of Community Services and Health have not seen it, but it may be that Mr Staples's personal staff have received it and are considering it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply want to record my puzzlement-and this is no reflection at all on the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples)-because the letter was circulated through the normal channels of the Parliament, and I have no reason to doubt that it reached its destination. When I inquired today of the Minister's office, I was told that no letters addressed to the Minister were kept in his office but were forwarded to the Department of Community Services and Health. I then inquired whether they could come back to me with any form of reply. I have finally been given an answer, but unless I can identify the person to whom I spoke this afternoon-which I cannot-then the Department is not even in a position to say who took the original call. Suffice it to say that the Department does not know where any letter might be and does not have any answer to it. I simply put that on the record as a matter of concern because, on its face, it suggests a fairly cavalier approach to correspondence.

SPEECH.PARA: The gravamen of the letter is that it seeks confirmation of certain assurances given to the Standing Committee by Senator Tate on behalf of the Minister. I just want to run through those quickly to see whether Senator Tate agrees that this is a fair representation of those assurances. Firstly, the fee relief for child-care centres will not be linked with accreditation in the guidelines to be implemented on 1 January next. That is the first proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is yes.

—I am content with that answer. The second proposition is that the full extent and cost implications of fee relief and of abiding by any accreditation guidelines will be made known to child-care centres and the relevant Senate committee before compliance is sought from those centres.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that I did say something to that effect and I am sure that, if that is a true representation of what I said, it must be accurate and will be fulfilled.
—I suppose that I was really asking the Minister to confirm that it is accurate. That is, indeed, what we have done our best to encapsulate as a fair summary.
—Those who have had more recent reading of the Hansards advise me that that is a fair summary.

—I am indebted to the Minister. The third proposition is that there will be full and open consultation with all areas of the child-care industry, including parents and private child-care centres, before any fee relief or accreditation will be implemented.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, of course, consultation is an absolutely key part of this Government's mode of operations, and that will occur.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to state why the Australian Democrats will not be supporting these amendments. We are very concerned that, if these amendments are accepted, there will be the removal of any link between fee relief and accreditation. We do understand, however, the concerns that the Liberal Party has with this. But we do emphasise that the guidelines, which I understand we will be seeing very shortly-they are being drafted now-are, indeed, a disallowable instrument. So we are not in fact dealing with their contents tonight, but simply looking at what Senator Alston has quite accurately described as a breaking of the link between the fee relief-in other words, the money provided by the Commonwealth-and any ability that the Commonwealth will have in the future to actually check up on what is happening by way of standards in child-care.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree that the particular points (a), (b) and (c) are indeed necessary, and one would hope-and we will be able to check-that, when the guidelines do come before this place, all of those areas will be covered. But one would hope that there will be considerably more considerations as well as these three items. Our concern is that we are tying the Minister in to including only these three areas in the guidelines which are being drafted.

Other areas the Democrats would like to see particularly deal with standards and outcomes, and I realise that these are difficult matters. They are very difficult to tie down precisely. It is going to be a long and, hopefully, very detailed consultation that goes on. The people that we had appearing before our committee, we have been assured by the Minister, will indeed be part of this consultation process.

The Democrats believe that we will be able now to quite adequately monitor progress of the guidelines and, indeed, any accreditation system that comes out. However, we are very concerned that, if we pass this amendment tonight, we will be cutting off a real opportunity to assure quality control on child-care centres.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would certainly be grateful for the Minister's response, but my understanding of what was agreed to at that Senate committee hearing is that there will be guidelines issued in relation to fee relief, and that will enable fee relief to commence on or shortly after 1 January 1991; and there will be at some later time additional and quite separate guidelines in relation to the accreditation system. I take the Minister's nodding as an assent to the proposition. Therefore, I say for the benefit of Senator Lees that what we are proposing tonight by way of amendments would simply provide an objective basis for the granting of fee relief to centres which will presumably be receiving that fee relief from 1 January 1991.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a matter of regret that Senator Lees, I think, is not able to hear what I am saying at the present time. I will just say it again. The Minister accepts the proposition that there are indeed two separate and distinct sets of guidelines. One in relation to fee relief will be available shortly, and that is quite separate and distinct from later guidelines that will be developed in relation to accreditation.

It seems inconceivable to me that granting fee relief pursuant to certain guidelines from 1 January 1991 will at some later time be withdrawn on the basis of subsequent accreditation guidelines. So we can have, if you like, a parallel system where fee relief is provided to commercial centres, as the general proposition has been accepted that it ought to be extended to the private sector and that there are these agreed minima which are objective and in normal circumstances would not require value judgments on the part of the Minister. They would be matters that we could simply test by checking whether a centre was registered, whether it had proper insurance and whether it complied with the audit and accountability requirements. That ought to be a matter of mechanics. The fee relief is then granted. That does not prevent an insistence at a later stage on accreditation guidelines. Indeed, that is what I thought was going to be done at a much later point in time.

I cannot see how there can be a link on that basis. There can be a link between the two only if at some later stage it is decided to withdraw fee relief because it is judged that a centre is not complying. If it is complying on 1 January 1991, on what basis is it withdrawn later on? It will have to be-unless the centre suddenly embarks upon a deliberate deterioration in standards-because a judgment has been made after the event that it should never have got fee relief in the first place. That seems an extraordinary proposition. What I say to the Committee is that, if one does believe in federalism and if one does take the language of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at the Special Premiers Conference at face value, then one does acknowledge that there are areas of responsibility for State and Federal governments in the area. The Federal Government's responsibility can quite simply be in the area of fee relief. We do not accept that there is a need for an accreditation system.

But if it is accepted that there is a role to be played by the States, surely it is to maintain and improve upon the system of regulation that has been in place for many years. It will vary, it does vary now and it ought to vary. We do not believe that there ought to be an across the board system that can somehow define absolutely precisely how all child-care centres in Australia ought to operate. Quality control will be a matter of subjectivity and it will be a matter of constant debate. But those matters can be resolved through a ministerial council, and that is the way to do it.

I have not heard criticisms in the specifics of child-care centres. I often hear people say, `Some are better than others; I can tell you some crook ones' or `Some States are better than other States'. But one never gets down to the point of demonstrating that there is a sufficient quantity of poor quality child-care centres to then lead on to a justification for overturning a State system of regulation. Indeed, the Government has said, `Well, this is not going to be a duplication; this is going to be complementary'. All that means in practice is that there will be a continuing State system of regulation that will continue to insist on a whole range of standards from childminder-childcarer to child ratios, the size of child-care centres, the physical area, and a whole range of other matters that currently operate. Those will continue in any event. But overlaid on top of that there will be an accreditation system. I do not understand what that is meant to achieve, unless it is to basically put those State regulations out of business.

If that is the real agenda, we are talking about a Federal takeover of child-care, which would be utterly contrary to what the Prime Minister has said and to all the rhetoric that has been waved around on the subject. It will not mean `complementary' at all; it will mean `a substitution for'. If that is the situation, it strikes me as verging on a nonsense because the Government might as well come out in the open and say, `We want to dismantle the current system of regulation; what we want to do is put in place a whole new system of Federal regulation, and we are going to tie your entitlement to child-care to compliance with those federally determined standards'.

I do not accept that that is feasible, politically or otherwise, and I certainly do not accept it as desirable. What it will do is play into the hands of the child-care industry and those professionals who want to put in place whole new career structures, with the inevitable outcome that the costs will be jacked up. If that is what the Government wants to do, this is probably the best way to go about doing it. There is very little doubt that the Australian Council of Trade Unions' agenda in this whole exercise, having had a very strong fundamental objection to the extension of fee relief to the private sector, is now to concede it on terms-and those terms are that there ought to be an accreditation system inextricably linked to fee relief so that there cannot be one without the other.

What that would have meant is that one would not get one's fee relief until one met these ever-increasing standards. What Senator Tate did in that last Committee was to decouple those two principles. Once one does that, one ends up saying, `We are prepared to grant fee relief to the existing private sector centres. We will go on doing that but at some later point we will talk about standards under an accreditation system'. If the Government is going to tell me that at that later point it will then turn around and say, `We are going to take away your fee relief even though you were worthy of having it on 1 January and nothing has changed in terms of your performance other than that after the event you do not measure up to new standards that we have put in place', I think that is a charade.

That is certainly not in the interests of child-care users. It can have only one outcome. It can turn child-care into an industrial relations issue. It can move right away from putting child-care preferences in the hands of parents. It will suit what I would have thought was an ideological objective that had been disowned by this Government. I would be very interested to hear from the Minister and the Australian Democrats whether they think that that is the way in which a subsequent accreditation system is going to operate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lees was not guilty of confusion between the sorts of criteria put down in the Opposition's first amendment, in trying to insert a new subsection with three different criteria for the Minister's satisfaction. I think what Senator Lees was saying was that this itself may not be an exhaustive list of even those more mechanical matters. For example, one may wish to cover in the guidelines questions like the hours of opening, the provision of more statistical information to the child-care authorities--
—Accountability.

—And a type of accountability, but in the provision of statistical information as to the number of children who are cared for over any particular period and so on. In other words, there are other matters that could come into the guidelines. I think Senator Lees was simply saying that one should not adopt this particular provision, which might cut off the development of these guidelines-which after all will in a sense be brought back to the Senate in that they will be made by way of a disallowable instrument.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills when reporting on the proposed amendments to the Child Care Act said:
The Committee notes with approval that in each case the guidelines concerned are disallowable instruments within the terms of section 46(a) of the Acts Interpretation Act.

I suppose that is the point that I understood the Australian Democrats to be making: that there may be more matters in the guidelines than are covered by the Opposition's set of three criteria and that we ought to allow the guidelines to be developed. They will be published, as I understand it, very shortly and, of course, as they will be disallowable we will be able to have a look at them.

It is true that the accreditation system is distinct. I decoupled it during that very useful and constructive session of the Committee meeting to discuss this Bill. Those quality measures will be deliberated upon and consultations will occur, particularly with parent groups. This was an important emphasis that came out of that Committee discussion. This is not a matter that should be taken over by the professional providers of child-care services nor by, in some cases, the proprietors of those homes or the boards that run the non-profit child-care centres. The parents have a very real and pre-eminent role, and their voice must be heard in any consultations to do with the quality of the care that is provided.

The Government will not be supporting the particular amendments moved by the Opposition, because we believe that the guidelines will be developed in accordance with the undertakings which I gave to the Committee in our deliberations. They will be available in a form which, as Senator Lees says on behalf of the Democrats, may embrace other criteria but of a more formal kind than accreditation qualitative matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is now almost three weeks since that last Committee meeting. Can the Minister indicate when it is expected that the guidelines will be available?
— I understand that they are within a week, or not much more, of being able to be published.

—Can the Minister explain why it has taken more than three weeks, and whether indeed there has been any sense of urgency at all in terms of meeting tonight's timetable-or has that been a matter of indifference?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It has not been a matter of indifference. The committee system in this instance is working pretty well. We had a very constructive session of the Committee. It led to certain assumptions that had been made being blown out of the water on all sides. Departmental officials went away with a very clear idea of what the Government and the Committee expected of them in the period leading up to 1 January 1990, with a major consultation process in this succeeding year. It may take a year or a year and a half to look at the questions of accreditation in regard to the quality of child-care. But there was no sense, I am sure, of indifference to the undertakings given to the Committee, and I think accepted in good faith by Senator Alston, as he apparently responded by way of a letter to the Minister. I am sure that the guidelines will be in accordance with those understandings.

—I understand from that that there has been a sense of urgency, and I therefore ask: in view of what must have transpired over the last three weeks, will the Minister now make available the guidelines, in whatever draft form they have reached at the present time, so that we can-and I stress that this is a very important principle-conduct a sensible debate in the committee stage and can ultimately vote knowing what we are voting on? I do not like blank cheques and I would have thought that was precisely what we were being asked to give today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am told that they have not reached a stage where the Minister has made a final determination as to their content. There has been considerable work done. I have indicated that we are virtually within days, but certainly within a week or so, of their final publishable form. But the Minister has not reached that stage and I think it would be pre-empting the scope of his decision making to put drafts into the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I indicated very clearly to the Committee the other day, and I do so again, that the matters-properly distinguished from quality matters-will be accountability, audit, eligibility, a sense of licensing, and the factual elements going to the operation such as hours of opening and so on. As I understand it, they will be those sorts of measures. Senator Alston need not have any misgivings or fears that something will be slipped in by way of quality control. That is not the intention and I will be as concerned as Senator Alston to ensure that that is the case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it absolutely extraordinary-and this is no reflection on Senator Tate-that those advising him and the Minister have not been able to reach that point where final guidelines have been approved by the Minister. Unless people have simply been sleeping on the job, there are books on the subject-I have read books on the subject-and there are background papers that have been circulated. Since the election we have had people like Mr Wight writing letters pointing out that as soon as the election was over the Department started beavering away.

SPEECH.PARA: I simply cannot accept that there is anything other than a deliberate attempt to ensure that the guidelines are not available until after this Bill has passed through the Senate. I regard it as absolutely extraordinary that those guidelines cannot have been made available in the first instance to the Standing Committee, and secondly made available tonight.

I would very much appreciate an explanation from Senator Tate, on advice, as to why it is that presumably some very senior bureaucrats have not been able to cobble together some objective standards along the lines that he has indicated, which is a much simpler task than trying to build in all those wonderful quality control guidelines that might emanate at a later time. Why have they not simply come up with the sorts of things that Senator Tate has mentioned by now?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not make the assumption that the bureaucrats, as Senator Alston referred to them, have not been able to reach a reasonable set of drafts in relation to these guidelines. The Minister has not had an opportunity to reflect on them and to make a decision as to how they should be finalised and published. I am sure that will occur within the next several days when honourable senators will be in a position to see the guidelines. There is perhaps a sense of something being done in an underhand way, to smuggle something in, which lies behind Senator Alston's question. That will not be the case. Once honourable senators see this disallowable instrument, they will be in a position to make a proper assessment.

—Let us be quite clear. It may not be a nefarious intent; it may simply be incompetence. I want to make clear what I was saying. I thought that the Minister said initially that the guidelines were not yet in final form. If that is the case the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) cannot be blamed for not having put pen to paper. The Department of Community Services and Health must accept the responsibility for not having got the guidelines into final form in the nine months almost since the election and in the three weeks in which presumably the departmental officers have been intensively beavering away since the hearing of the Senate standing committee.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Alston is playing on the words `final form'. By `final form' I mean a final form as approved by the Minister that is not subject to any further direction by him as to some modification, minor amendment or clarifying expression to be used. In other words, it is almost at that point, but until the Minister clears and approves the final draft that has been offered to him, we cannot say that it is in the final form which is ready for publication as a guideline which will then be disallowable.
—Let us not engage in too many semantics.
—I am not in the Magistrates Court.

—I will elevate the Minister to the Supreme Court, if he likes. Is the Minister suggesting that the guidelines have not been put before the Minister in a form which the Department regards as acceptable for final signature?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not prepared to speculate on what might be the state of play in relation to the Minister taking advice from his advisers as to the final form of a matter for which he has to take responsibility and publish as a disallowable instrument. These are matters which are subject to continuous discussion up to the moment of his approval. Senator Alston has too strict a sense of the different roles. There will be toing-and-froing up to the last act by the Minister in approval of the guidelines.
—Can the Minister give us his word that we will have those guidelines in time to debate them and, if necessary, disallow them before we leave this place on 21 December?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. As I have indicated to Senator Walters, on advice, I hope that the guidelines will be published in a week. That will give the chamber time to use its normal processes. I suppose honourable senators will keep in mind that there are many people who are anxious to secure this fee relief. The guidelines will be in the narrow categories that I have spoken of and, therefore, ought to meet the approval of honourable senators when they see them. I give an absolute undertaking that the guidelines will be available in a timely way to allow honourable senators to consider them and to exercise such powers as the chamber has if they so desire.

—I seek clarification of the contents of a letter signed by Mr Wight dated 20 November. It is suggested in regard to questions about extra funds included in the Department's estimates that $19.2m will be expended on extension of fee relief to commercial services, $4.2m for extension of fee relief to non-profit, non-children's services program services and $29.7m for extra costs to improve fee relief in CSP non-profit services. The balance of the new funds relate to the expansion of the non-profit community based sector and to other initiatives announced in the Budget. I ask what that latter figure covers and whether it is the difference between those three and the figure of $70m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I found it difficult to follow. I am told that Senator Alston is dealing with a very difficult equation based on this year's estimates. I cannot answer that question on the run. I will undertake to provide Senator Alston with a formal written answer to his question after the Committee is suspended.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to correct an answer that I gave to Senator Walters. On reflection, because of our peculiar arrangement, thanks to a move by former Senator Puplick, a happy memory-and former Senator Macklin; an even happier memory-we are in a situation where, until the legislation comes into operation on 1 January, no regulation can be made under it. Therefore, a disallowable instrument will not be available.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hang on.

— That is correct. We went through this in the Committee. There will not be a disallowable instrument available whilst the Parliament is sitting during December. I gave an undertaking to the Committee the other afternoon that honourable senators and the proprietors would get a copy of the proposed regulation in a good and timely way to enable any questions, queries or misgivings to be raised in this chamber. Given the very unusual situation that came out of that alliance between Senators Puplick and Macklin, we are not in a position to make a disallowable instrument before 1 January.

—Does that mean that we will have time to see the guidelines, as they will be in their final form; we will have time to debate them -the Minister will make sure that time is made available for them to be debated in their final form-and any disallowance will have to wait until after the whole system starts? I do not anticipate disallowance.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall saying to the Committee that I would ensure that all honourable senators received the guidelines as soon as they were approved by the Minister. I cannot give any undertaking-I am not the Manager of Government Business in the Senate-as to time being provided in the last two or three weeks of this sitting. I am sure that were a matter to be of concern, the forms of the chamber would allow that concern to be expressed.
—I am sure the Minister could prevail upon him.
—Should I take that to mean that the Minister will make available a copy of the final draft form of the guidelines within the next week or so when he expects it to be approved by the Minister?
—Yes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 2, page 2, line 2, after ``commences'' insert ``, or is taken to have commenced,''.
(2) Clause 20, page 11, line 31, omit ``1 November 1990'', substitute ``Day of Royal Assent''.
(3) Clause 21, page 12, line 11, omit ``1 November 1990'', substitute ``Day of Royal Assent''.
(4) Clause 23, page 12, line 34, omit ``1 November 1990'', substitute ``Day of Royal Assent''.
(5) Clause 25, page 14, line 5, omit ``1 November 1990'', substitute ``Day of Royal Assent''.
(6) Clause 26, page 14, line 12, omit ``1 November 1990'', substitute ``Day of Royal Assent''.
(7) Clause 29, page 21, line 15, omit ``1 November 1990'', substitute ``Day of Royal Assent''.
(8) Clause 30, page 21, line 25, omit ``1 November 1990'', substitute ``Day of Royal Assent''.
I also wish to table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the amendments moved on behalf of the Government.
Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 31, page 21, paragraphs (a) and (b), lines 28 to 34, omit the proposed paragraphs.

We certainly recognise the need to publish aggregate data on pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) prescribing and support the publication of that data as long as it does not identify the individual manufacturer. Confidentiality of individual company data is maintained for other industries and the argument is that surely pharmaceutical manufacturers should be no exception.

The Government says that the manufacturers want information about the sale of drugs and, therefore, it is releasing it. However, it was the Australian Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, which represents some 93 per cent of manufacturers, that put this concern in its submission to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs. Its submission stated:

The APMA supports in principle the ability of DCSH to publish aggregate data on PBS prescribing which is of benefit to the community. However, the amendment goes too far and has the potential to identify individual manufacturers, which is not acceptable.

The Government says that there is a lack of data to ensure that subsidised drugs are used in ways that reflect sound medical practice and cost effectiveness, but the pharmaceutical manufacturers disagree with this and claim that the Government already holds aggregate details of their market share. It would seem that for this reason alone the Government's argument does not hold up, and the manufacturers see no reason to publish those figures which are already collected.

The manufacturers do not believe that the publication of such data will necessarily have any positive effect on doctors' prescribing habits. We agree with this conclusion. Doctors' prescribing habits will be improved only if the Government provides them with some incentive to prescribe a cheaper alternative and undertakes a comprehensive education program informing them about generic equivalents and convincing them that they can be safely prescribed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment proposed by the Opposition, as Senator Patterson said, deals with the revelation of information, even though that information may go to the extent of identifying particular manufacturers. Of course, in certain instances where a particular manufacturer has a product which is used by a very large number of practitioners-as a hypertensive agent, or whatever-it may be that that manufacturer has a very dominant share of the market, and it may also be a particularly profitable line.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Patterson said, it is quite clear that the public revelation of this information could identify that market share and could, potentially, open up for other potential competitors the idea that it would be useful to make a duplicate of that particular drug and get it onto the market. Of course, the general proposition that that is the case would become known through the detailers who go round to general practitioners, knock on their doors, leave free samples and so on. What is available through this mechanism is far more precise information.

Having looked at this, I would like to be persuaded by the Government as to why it needs to reveal this information to this extent. If there is a good reason I am prepared to be persuaded that that reason would be sufficient to keep this clause in the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill. If there is not a substantial reason as to why one should go this far with the public revelation of information-because, after all, the information is privately held by the Department and the Department can make decisions about it; why this information should be more generally available is not at all clear to me-I would certainly like to hear from the Government as to precisely why it wishes to go this far. As I have indicated, if the Government can provide a substantial reason, we are prepared to support the Government. If the reason is, in our opinion, not sufficiently substantial, we are prepared to support the Opposition's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the sort of statistical data which is considered to be important to be gathered is not identifiable, and I think that is the key point. So long as there is a situation where that privacy consideration is upheld, the sorts of concerns which usually accompany the gathering of statistical data are satisfied. I believe it goes without saying that the provision of general statistical information can be extremely important in the formulation of policy and an understanding of whether a particular scheme or provision of a service is working correctly and in a way which satisfies the original policy objectives. If one is carrying out research into these areas, of course, one needs the best possible statistical data, but in a way which does not trespass upon privacy considerations.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know whether Senator Coulter was at the Standing Committee on Community Affairs hearing-I think Senator Patterson was there-but I thought we touched on this whole question and that the Committee had been satisfied in this regard, so I am a bit surprised by the amendment. As I understand it, this has not been a cause of great concern. I believe that, despite some sort of theoretical misgiving, the way in which this will operate should not give practical grounds for those concerns.

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding is that because of the small number of players in the field there is a potential to identify individual manufacturers. I do not know that what the Minister has said has convinced me otherwise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it from what the Minister has said that he has not actually read the proposed new subsection. While it may be true that in most instances the statistics would not identify a particular manufacturer, the sole purpose of subsection (5a) seems to be to ensure that those statistics shall become available even though the manufacturer may be identified. I remind the Minister that it reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Statistics relating to the supply of pharmaceutical benefits may be published in spite of the fact-
and this seems to be the critical point-
that the manufacturer of any of those pharmaceutical benefits may be identified through those statistics.

If that is the purpose of this subsection-in other words, to overcome that specific difficulty, namely, the identification of a particular manufacturer-I ask the Minister to address himself to that particular matter, because that is the matter upon which the Australian Democrats will be deciding whether or not to support this amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It would have been nice to have had this brought to our attention before the Committee consideration got to this stage. As I understand it, the fact is that no manufacturer has raised concern about this particular provision. Manufacturers do not regard this as being a provision which will cause them great difficulty. I believe that in that situation, while there may be some concerns relating to identification-which is always the case where statistics are being gathered and where, as Senator Patterson said, there is a small field of players-the concerns are perhaps magnified to a greater extent than they need to be. The Government believes that the policy objective of securing the best statistical information outweighs the small risks that might be attendant upon that by way of identification of the manufacturers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: -I take this opportunity to address the matter of the Ravenshoe sawmill. I want to respond to some of the comments made earlier today by Senator Richardson after Question Time and set the record straight on a number of technical matters that relate to the document that was tabled in Parliament earlier this week in respect of this mill.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Richardson said that he has been advised by the receivers that the document was not prepared for them. That may be the case. It was my understanding at the time at which the document was made available to me that it had been prepared for the receivers. Whether that is the case or not, I believe that the evidence contained in that document is very important evidence. From what I can see of the document itself, given its detail, it has quite clearly come from the accounts of the company.

I say that because there are details in the particular document that has been tabled that have not previously been available to the Senate. For example, we did not know the date on which funds were received for the veneer mill that was sold in November. It was only this document that told us that it was 14 November. That fact leads me to the conclusion that it must be reasonably well sourced from within the company.

There are other factors as well, such as the particular breakdown of the veneer timber that was sold out of Ravenshoe, sent to Sydney and never paid for. The ageing of the accounts and so on makes it very clear that the material was obviously sourced from the accounts of the company at Ravenshoe. Proof of the importance of this document is the fact that Senator Richardson has passed it on to the Attorney-General's Department. He has done so because he believes it is worthy of investigation.

Senator Richardson also has not taken issue with a number of parts of the document. For example, he takes no issue with the apparent fact that $1.15m of veneer timber left Ravenshoe, was sent to Sydney and was not paid for. These are the important aspects of this document. Whether or not the receivers had seen it before is irrelevant. The relevant fact is that this document discloses new information on the company and it is of critical importance to the investigations that I have been urging for some time now.

I take this opportunity wholeheartedly to congratulate Senator Richardson for passing the document on to the Attorney-General's Department. I am very pleased to see that Senator Richardson is treating this matter with the gravity that it deserves. The Ravenshoe sawmill is a very sad case, and I am pleased to see that Senator Richardson, as a result of the work I have been doing, is treating the matter with the degree of seriousness that it warrants. As I said before, Senator Richardson deserves to be congratulated on this.

I have said before, and I say again, that I am only too happy to cooperate in whatever investigations are suggested and I hope that the Department will cooperate in a similarly frank and open way with my investigations. I am also pleased to hear Senator Richardson's advice that the Attorney-General's Department is supposed to report within two weeks. I hope that that is the case so we can clear the air once and for all.

It is very clear, as a result of all of the evidence that has been amassed, that if the Ravenshoe sawmill were given a fair go it would be a viable financial proposition. Nothing that anybody in this chamber has seen can contradict that. That is why I am concerned to see that the matter is dealt with as speedily as possible and I thank Senator Richardson for the attention he has given to it. I wanted to take that opportunity to set the record straight.

There is one other matter that I was intending to raise earlier today but was unable to do so. I refer to what the Inter-State Commission (ISC) has had to say about road transport. In particular, I want to refer to a number of issues that were raised with me in north Queensland concerning the implications of the implementation of a national road registration scheme along the ISC guidelines.

Earlier this week in the Committee of the Whole Senator Collins admitted for the first time that the Government does intend to introduce on 1 July 1991 a national road registration scheme for heavy road transport. For the first time we had an admission from a Minister in Parliament that the intention is that the registration fees will be along the lines of those proposed in the Inter-State Commission report.

Everybody has heard the figures before but I will cite them once again. For example, the road transport operator of a 40-foot semi-trailer registered in Queensland will be expected to pay a charge which will increase from the current figure of $2,500 to $18,500. For the ordinary person in the street, this translates into a 20 per cent increase in national freight cartage charges. Let us look at the implications for north Queensland of that 20 per cent increase in road transport costs. For example, the Atherton Tablelands Co-operative Dairy Association Ltd spends $3m a year transporting its milk and dairy products from the Atherton Tablelands to Cairns and Townsville. A 20 per cent increase in that transport charge would mean about $600,000 in increased costs for the dairy cooperative. On top of this, the dairy cooperative has five milk trailers for which the increase in charges would be something in the vicinity of $80,000. We are talking about an increase in charges of roughly $680,000.

The response from the Government has been that these companies can pass on the increase. But, unfortunately, dairy industry companies cannot pass it on because the price of milk is regulated by law and the price of other dairy products, for example butter, is effectively set by a market price in Brussels. This is why so many industries throughout provincial Australia-industries that affect the lives of each and every one of us-will be devastated by the introduction of these increased road transport charges.

I have also spoken about the potato industry. Potato growers are currently earning about $8 a bag for potatoes coming off the Atherton Tablelands and marketed in Sydney. Unfortunately, the cost of getting the potatoes out of the ground, bagged and down to Sydney is $9 a bag-$5.50 of which is the road transport charge. If there is a 20 per cent increase in road transport costs, it will mean that the cost of transporting each and every bag of potatoes from the Atherton Tablelands to Sydney will become $6.60. That will mean that the effective cost of getting the potatoes out of the ground and down to Sydney will be over $10-which is the top market price for top quality potatoes in large quantities.

The effect of that will be to devastate-totally destroy-the potato industry in north Queensland. In addition to the cost of harvesting the potatoes, bagging them and so on, there is also the cost of planting them, fertilising them and tending them in the growing season. This extra cost would destroy that industry in north Queensland.

A final example of the implications of the increase in road transport charges is demonstrated eloquently when one looks at the sugar cane industry around Bundaberg. I attended a rally recently where I spoke to a number of young sugar cane farmers from the Gin Gin area and they said that one of the problems the sugar cane industry faces is that the type of soil found in the Bundaberg area, while very fertile red soil in every other respect, is very low in calcium. They solved that problem by trucking up gypsum and putting it over the soil to increase the calcium content.

A tonne of gypsum goes for something like $15 in Brisbane. By the time it gets to Bundaberg and the surrounding areas the cost after transport is $50 a tonne. In other words, there is a $35 a tonne transport charge. An increase of another $7.00 in transport charges puts that gypsum out of the reach of the sorts of farmers who need it. These farmers were talking about spreading between two to five tonnes of gypsum on every acre of land planted to sugar cane. The consequence of this increased charge will be that those farmers will not be able to afford the gypsum, therefore their productivity and their yields will shrink and more of them will become marginal operators.

At a time when the Government is talking about micro-economic reform and making the Australian economy more efficient, it seems ludicrous that it should impose increases in charges that will make more operators marginal, make it more difficult for Australian primary producers to be competitive in international markets and make it more difficult for them to improve their rate of return. For these reasons I believe it is necessary for the Opposition to oppose the implementation of the scheme along the lines of the Inter-State Commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to get specific answers from the relevant Ministers on two issues. The first relates to the gardens and environs of the old Parliament House. I refer to an answer the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) gave to a question on 22 August when he referred to funds being allocated for the continuing care and maintenance of the old Parliament House. As far as I am aware nothing has been said about what is to happen to the environment and gardens of the building.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to know whether in returning the building to its 1927 configuration the Minister had in mind the gardens of the building. For those who know the design of the 1927 building, the gardens were very much an integral part of it. My understanding-it is certainly the view of the National Trust-is that the retention of the park and garden areas around the building is absolutely essential to maintain the integrity of the building.

I am concerned about what will occur because the previous proposal of the Government was to place a child-care centre in the gardens on the House of Representatives side. I believe that is not now going ahead but nothing has actually been said about what will occur or whether anything else is planned to go into the location of the grounds on either side of the building. I believe the proposal for a child-care centre is out of character; it was certainly a very expensive way of providing child-care.

For that reason I am concerned about the commitment not only to the building itself but also to the areas which surround it. I think in the longer term, if the building is to be made a museum or an historical place, these matters are very important. I request that the Minister for Administrative Services respond beyond the information he has given to the present time, provide an assurance that the gardens surrounding the building be recognised as a significant and integral part of the heritage of Australia and of the building itself and give a firm commitment to their preservation.

The other matter I wish to raise relates to the portfolio of the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) and the apparent recent intervention by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the question of where the Sea Safety Centre will be located. I am sure the Senate remembers the saga of the centre and the decision originally made that it should go to Newcastle. This would have had a number of severe consequences, and the reasons for maintaining the centre in Canberra were undoubtedly very sound. They included the lack of suitable accommodation in Newcastle and the very likely loss of expert staff which would have occurred and which would have seriously interfered with the capacity of the unit to function. In addition to those reasons there was also the question of disruption to the staff who for some time have not known whether they would be staying in Canberra or whether their employment would be disrupted.

It was my view that the decision to shift the centre to Newcastle was more to win votes in the Newcastle area than to do something that was in the best interests of sea safety and rescue operations. Subsequently a delegation from Newcastle came to see the Prime Minister and at that time he agreed to review the decision even though it was clear that Senator Collins was firmly of the view that the centre should remain in Canberra. In respect of that I would like to know: what is the nature of the Prime Minister's undertaking to the delegation from Newcastle? Who is conducting a review of the Cabinet decision not to move the centre? What are the terms of reference of the review? What is the time frame within which this review is to take place? The time frame is particularly important because the lives of those involved, who have worked in the Sea Safety Centre for a long time, are virtually being put on hold again by not knowing what the Prime Minister's commitment to review the decision really meant.
Those are the two matters I would like answers on from the Ministers concerned in somewhat more detail than has been given to the present.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday this week I asked a question without notice of Senator Collins, the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. My question read:

SPEECH.PARA: Is it the practice of Telecom Australia to intercept or monitor telephone calls between its employees and its employers, save for Telecom telephonists? Has Telecom knowledge of such a practice taking place in Western Australia? Under what authority does such conduct take place?
Senator Collins responded-I had given him notice to enable him to answer my inquiry-by saying:

I have asked Telecom for a response. It has provided me with the following information which, in fact, arrived just this morning. The answer to the first part of Senator Crichton-Browne's question is no-
-that is, whether it was the practice of Telecom. The answer continued:

The interception of telephone calls is regulated in Australia by the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979. The Act makes it unlawful for any person to intercept telephone calls without the knowledge of the person making the communication, except where it is done by an officer of Telecom in the execution of his or her duties in certain specific circumstances or under a warrant issued under the Act.
Senator Collins went on to say:

With respect to the second part of the question, in early 1989 Telecom investigatory staff in Western Australia incorrectly arranged for call charge analysis equipment-that is, CCAS equipment-to be placed on the services of some employees whose compensation cases were under review. CCAS equipment does not record details of conversations, but records the number dialled, the date and the duration of the calls. The error was detected and the matter was referred to the Australian Federal Police and the Director of Public Prosecutions for consideration.

Senator Collins went on to say that he would seek an answer as to the resolution of that reference. One might well ask what material benefit there was for Telecom to learn the number dialled, the date and the duration of calls of employees who had compensation claims afoot. I made it clear that I thought there was further information to be provided, and the following morning on an Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio program Mr John Lewis, the manager of Telecom Protective Services in Western Australia, said:
There is, I believe . . . some misinformation . . . currently being circulated. I suggest maybe . . . what the question is based on . . . is that misinformation.
The interviewer then said:
Right. So-who's putting around that misinformation, Mr Lewis?
He said:
. . . one could only guess that . . . anyone that may wish to . . . place Telecom or my particular . . . Region . . . that's the Security &Investigation Branch . . . in a bad light.

Mr Lewis was suggesting that my information had come from mischievous people or I was mischievous in providing it. That is a very unsatisfactory response from Telecom. The fact that I asked the question exposed to the world that Telecom had been bugging its own employees. Further, I am not satisfied that a proper and exhaustive inquiry has been conducted by Telecom, and it has allowed the Minister to answer in a less than complete way. I believe there is further information that is available to it. I believe that Telecom management, at least at the customer/plant management level, is aware of this practice; that it has knowledge of the interception by Telecom of telephone conversations between employees of Telecom and customers of Telecom without either the customer or the employee having knowledge of that interception, with the interception providing a voice recording of the conversation.

I am not Telecom's ombudsman, I am not its keeper, and I am not its investigator. It is up to Telecom to undertake a proper inquiry on the basis of the question thus far asked and to satisfy itself absolutely, impeccably, that the circumstances to which I refer either do or do not take place. I would have thought that Telecom should have been able to undertake that investigation and solve this matter internally. However, it ought not to be forgotten, as Senator Collins reminds us, that it is an offence under the Telecommunications (Interception) Act of 1979-with some very striking penalties for those who breach it-to listen, in an unauthorised way, to people's telephone calls. The great risk for Telecom is that it has at its fingertips the capacity to plug into any telephone conversation it wants to. That is the great risk for society. It is a great temptation for Telecom, and that is why the Act is as it is. I would expect Telecom now to pursue this inquiry and get to the bottom of the matter, and not suggest that anybody who asks questions of this nature is simply putting around misinformation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday in the consideration of Appropriation Bill No. 1 there were a number of occasions on which the Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Bolkus, gave commitments that additional information would be provided for the Senate's consideration. In the consideration of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) and a matter that related to libel and defamation that could have implications for the Government and for the Northern Land Council, again there was an exchange of questions and answers, and at page 4701 of Hansard Senator Bolkus said:

As I said, we will provide full answers. The request has been made that they be provided by lunchtime tomorrow, and I expect them to be available to me.

On four occasions yesterday Senator Bolkus gave a commitment to provide information relating to the Appropriation Bill. I took his undertakings in good faith, believing that he would honour that commitment, and in doing so did not hold up in any way the consideration of the committee stages of the Appropriation Bill. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have seen a marvellous performance from Senator Tambling of misleading the Senate. But I do have some sympathy. When Ministers genuinely promise, they should deliver. But tonight Senator Tambling has been very selective in his quotes. Let me go through the issues he has raised. In the first issue, Senator Bolkus said `hopefully'; that is not a definite promise. He said that hopefully the information will be available. Therefore, whilst it would be preferable for it to be here, he did not absolutely promise. Strike one! On the second one, Senator Tambling failed to quote from the top of page 4696. When Senator Bolkus promised to get an answer `today', Senator Tambling then asked another series of questions. Senator Bolkus had something else to say, and let me quote that to the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: I will ask officers to provide it to me by tomorrow and I will get it to him either tomorrow or Monday.
That is at the top of page 4696. Having asked one question and then a series of questions, Senator Bolkus--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is another question.

—No, because the first one related to the other. Senator Bolkus comes back and qualifies his statement by saying that he will have the answer by tomorrow and will forward it to Senator Tambling either today or by Monday. Senator Tambling did not include that quote. Strike two! Senator Tambling did not go on to quote from page 4701 where the Minister expresses the hope-I am paraphrasing his words-that he will have a full and accurate answer by lunchtime tomorrow. He then goes on to say that if it is provided he or someone else will give Senator Tambling the answer. Strike three!

SPEECH.PARA: I go over the page to Senator Tambling's fourth quote. He did not include this. On page 4702, Senator Bolkus said:
. . . and I expect them to be available to me.

One of the problems with all these questions on notice put by Senator Tambling is that there are so many that it is very difficult in the Committee of the Whole to get the answers immediately. In the Department of Defence, hundreds of questions were put on notice. I think I managed to answer every one before we came into this chamber. What happened in committee? We went off on frolics that had never even been conceived in the Estimates Committee.

If Senator Tambling is asking for good will and cooperation, he should have a look at what has happened to the Estimates committee process. A select committee reported last year on changes that one had hoped would improve the procedures and those changes were laid down in this chamber. We are supposed to discuss in committee only what is in the Estimates Committee report. But senator after senator on the other side reserved every one of the hundreds and thousands of questions they asked and perverted that new system. There has to be good will on both sides.

I draw Senator Tambling's attention to the fact that the Minister did indicate that urgent replies were required and that he hoped they would be provided on Monday. But I think Senator Tambling has been a bit unfair in his quotes because he has not batted on with them all and has not put the qualifiers in.

There have been two or three other speeches tonight. Senator O'Chee had a practice run on a couple. He raved on about Ravenshoe. I have not followed those details, so I cannot give him a response. Senator O'Chee also noted that the principle of user pays in the transport industry is not always of benefit to the community. I simply draw Senator O'Chee's attention to the policy of the Bjelke-Petersen Government on coal charging, whereby user pays charges were doubled; 200 per cent of the cost was paid. He might like to take that up with some of his National Party of Australia colleagues in Queensland and see just how the real experts did it.

Senator Reid raised two issues, neither of which I can add a lot to. I will pass on to the Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Bolkus, her comments on old Parliament House. In these stringent times of economic austerity, it is very hard to find the money to do the things we would like to do to the building. As far as I know, there was no formal inquiry into the Sea Safety Centre, but Senator Collins can deal with that in due course. I congratulate Senator Crichton-Browne on the briefest adjournment speech I have ever heard him make. Could I have 100 signed copies of it?
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 10 May 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Are there any Commonwealth or Commonwealth funded programs relating to interstate coach safety standards or monitoring; if so, what are the nature of these programs and the extent of Commonwealth funding.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Land Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes, the Commonwealth has programs relating to interstate coach safety.

Bus safety has been a priority on the Commonwealth Government's road safety agenda for some time. Australian Design Rules promulgated or already in preparation cover antilock brakes, bus rollover strength, speed limiting, improvements to bus seat strength and anchorages, seat belts for unprotected seating positions and improvements to driver's seat belts.

A new Australian Design Rule which provides for improvements to seat strength, seat anchorage strength and padding in coaches will come into effect from 1 July 1992 for heavy buses and 1 January 1993 for light buses. The Federal Office of Road Safety has developed the Rule with the cooperation of the coach industry and I am pleased to have secured the support of my State and Territory colleagues in having the Rule endorsed.

Further work is being undertaken to examine options for even higher levels of passenger protection, including further increases in seat strength and the provision of seat belts for all passengers. In addition, work is in hand on emergency exits, electrical isolation switches and window glass requirements. I have directed the Vehicle Standards Advisory Committee to give these matters high priority. The introduction of standards as a result of this work will keep Australia at the forefront of international bus and coach safety standards.

Funding for the support of technical committees developing Australian Design Rules is provided by the Department of Transport and Communications. In addition, the Commonwealth is jointly funding a study on seat strength currently being conducted at the New South Wales Crashlab.

The Government has also made a major commitment to the road safety of all Australians with the 10 point road safety package and black spot program which includes extra funding to help eliminate hazardous spots on roads with a history of serious casualties.

(16) Refer response to question 15.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 21 August 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What would be the total cost to revenue of allowing full tax deductibility for child-care expenses incurred by taxpayers whose children are cared for to enable them to go to work.

(2) What would be the cost to revenue if tax deductibility were to be limited to: (a) registered child care centres; (b) family day care schemes; and (c) allowed only in respect of children of pre-school age.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government offered the Opposition, in the course of the 1990 election campaign, the opportunity to have its policies costed by the Department of Finance and the Australian Taxation Office.
That offer remains open in respect of matters of Opposition policy.
The Government does not see it as appropriate for the limited resources of the Taxation Office to be utilised to provide costings on individual items which do not have any specific status.
The Government would welcome an announcement of policy detail from the Opposition, and would be happy to provide costings in that context.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 August 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of the anomaly that exists at the present time with the Australian Taxation Office's treatment of individual taxpayers and financial institutions with regard to the ability to claim any losses incurred from fixed-interest securities as a tax deduction for income-tax purposes.

(2) Why are fixed-interest investors caught up in a totally unjustified and inequitable system in that while financial institutions are permitted to write off any losses incurred from investments in fixed interest securities as bad debts against taxable income, individual investors are not entitled to claim any losses as a tax deduction for income tax purposes. (This situation is particularly relevant considering the present collapse of Estate Mortgage and the Pyramid Building Society.)
(3) Why should ordinary individuals be treated so harshly when the banks and other financial institutions which made similar mistaken investments are allowed full tax deductions for any losses.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The matter to which the honourable senator refers relates to the treatment of bad debts under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936.

Under the income tax law bad debts may be claimed as deductions under either of two provisions of the Act. One is a specific provision dealing with bad debts, section 63, and the other is the general deductions provision, section 51.

Firstly, the specific provision itself sets out two bases for deducting bad debts. Pursuant to paragraph 63 (1) (a) a debt which has, during the income year, been written off as a bad debt, will be allowable as a deduction if it has already been brought to account as assessable income in any year. Pursuant to paragraph 63 (1) (b), a bad debt will also be deductible if it is incurred in respect of money lent in the ordinary course of a money lending business.

Alternatively, a deduction may be allowed under the general deductions provision, subsection 51 (1), where the bad debt is necessarily incurred in carrying on a business for the purpose of gaining or producing assessable income to the extent that it is not a capital loss or of a capital, domestic or private nature.

In the circumstances outlined by the Honourable Senator, two distinct debts may arise as bad debts. The first is the non-receipt of interest which may have accrued on a fixed interest security, and the second is the inability to recover the full amount invested in the security. To illustrate the operation of the provisions to the non-receipt of both interest and the underlying investment, I will refer to three different categories of taxpayers-individuals, organisations carrying on the business of money lending, and other businesses bringing income to account under the accruals method of tax accounting.

Firstly, an individual who deposits funds in a fixed interest security clearly makes a capital investment. In general, unless the accruals method applies under division 16e of the Act, it is only when interest is actually paid or credited on the security that it will form part of the assessable income of that person. Accordingly, where a debtor institution is unable to meet its liability to pay interest on the security no amount will generally have been assessed to the individual investor. Consequently, there is neither an amount which has been brought to account as assessable income by the individual taxpayer in terms of paragraph 63 (1) (a) nor a loss or outgoing incurred in gaining assessable income in terms of subsection 51 (1). Therefore, no deduction is allowable in respect of the nonreceipt of interest income.

The return of an individual's capital outlay for an investment can never be assessed as income. As no amount will be brought to account as income the operation of paragraph 63 (1) (a) is quite irrelevant. As to subsection 51 (1), failure by the debtor institution to ultimately repay an individual's capital investment would amount to a loss but such a loss is one of capital and not deductible. However, that loss will be one which may be offset against any capital gains derived by the taxpayer in terms of the capital gains and losses provisions of the Act.

Secondly, where an organisation carrying on a business of money lending invests in a fixed interest security in the ordinary course of its business, the failure of the debtor institution to repay both the amount invested and the interest on the security will give rise to both amounts being deductible under paragraph 63 (1) (b). That is how the full Federal Court determined the provision applied in F.C. of T. v. National Commercial Banking Corporation of Australia Ltd in 1983. The same amounts are also likely to be deductible under subsection 51 (1).

Finally, any investment by an accruals taxpayer (other than a money lender) in a fixed interest security will usually be on capital account. Any failure by the debtor institution to pay interest on the security will be deductible under paragraph 63 (1) (a) where the taxpayer has already brought that amount to account. So far as the failure to repay the amount invested is concerned, that amount will be treated in the same way as for individuals and be regarded as a capital loss which may be used to offset capital gains for the purposes of the capital gains and losses provisions of the Act.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 11 October 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Minister's department or any agency for which the Minister is responsible entered into any contracts with Gary Morgan's company, Roy Morgan Research Centre, since 1975; if so, for each contract since 1975:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Social Security: Central Office Complex

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 11 October 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What will be the estimated total cost of the executive wing at completion of the Department's Central Office complex to be located at Tuggeranong.
(2) What will be the estimated total cost of the executive suite at completion of the executive wing of the Department's Central Office complex to be located at Tuggeranong.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Tuggeranong Office Park is not a Government building and the Commonwealth is not responsible for the construction and management of the project. This is the responsibility of Civil &Civic Pty Ltd which is part of the Lend Lease Corporation. The development costs are paid by a profit neutral, special purpose company, Tuggeranong Office Park Ltd. The Government has entered into a lease arrangement on behalf of the Department of Social Security for subsequent use.
The Commonwealth agreement to lease the complex on completion includes a fixed rental stream for the first ten years and an option to purchase the complex in the future.

The Tuggeranong Office complex consists of five module buildings. The executive wing will be accommodated within one of these modules along with other facilities which include a central stores area, conference facilities, cafeteria and staff facilities and security control. The Civil &Civic Pty Ltd building construction price is $86.275 million and a provisional sum of $20 million also was allowed for fit-out as required by the tender documentation. At the time of entering the agreement, broad indicative construction costs for each module, with the exception of the National Production Centre which is a special-purpose building, were comparable at about $10 million. However, details of the actual building cost of each module are commercial-in-confidence information of Civil &Civic Pty Ltd and have not been provided to the Commonwealth.
(2) As above.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Social Security: Work Based Child-care

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 11 October 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What plans does the Department of Social Security have to incorporate work-based child care in its new central office development at Tuggeranong.
(2) If the department does have plans to incorporate work-based child care in its new Tuggeranong central office complex, what is the estimated cost at completion for such a facility.
(3) What type of child care does the department envisage the facility would be offering.
(4) What contributions to the capital and recurrent costs of such a facility will the department be expecting parents to make for children in care.
(5) If the department does not at present have any such plans, is it currently considering the possibility.

(6) Has the department had any discussions or other such dealings with departmental Public Service Union (PSU) officials, PSU officials in general, or any other such employee representatives on the matter; if so, what stage have these discussions or dealings reached.
(7) If the department has decided against incorporating work-based child care into its new Tuggeranong complex, for what detailed reasons has the department reached this decision.

(8) If the department has yet to reach a firm decision as to whether or not it will have work-based child care incorporated into the new complex, what are the reasons for the delay in reaching a decision.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (8) The Department of Social Security and the Public Sector Union have established a joint Project Team to assess work-based child care facilities for the Department's Central Office when it is relocated to Tuggeranong. The Project Team is to examine the results of two surveys undertaken to identify requirements and to prepare proposals for consideration by the Department. Cost estimates and other details sought will not be available until the Project Team submits proposals which is expected to be by the end of 1990.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 6 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: As to the derivation of 1990-91 estimates contained in element 4.4 of program 4 in the Estimates of the Department of Social Security, explain how each item is made up or calculated and state the reasons for any increase additional to an inflation component.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The derivation of the estimate consists of two variations. The way each was calculated and the reasons for any increase are:

- the estimated variation in Running Costs for 1990-91 is calculated on the basis of the increased resources required to provide for the full year cost of those JET Advisers established in 1989-90 and the additional program enhancements (including a further 32 JET Advisers) described on Page 142 of the Social Security Portfolio's 1990-91 Explanatory Notes.

- The estimated variation in Child Care Expenses to Sole Parents Undergoing Training is calculated as the difference between the 1990-91 Estimate and 1989-90 Outcome. As indicated at page 142 of the Explanatory Notes for the Social Security Portfolio the under-utilisation of the appropriation for this item in 1989-90 was attributed largely to one-off factors. Accordingly, the 1990-91 Estimate ($5.5 million) allowed for a slightly greater expenditure than that originally estimated for 1989-90 ($5 million). The factors expected to generate this increase are set out at page 142 of the Explanatory Notes.
- It should be noted that the funds provided for Child Care Expenses are appropriated specifically for that purpose. Any unexpended appropriation lapses and reverts to Consolidated Revenue.
